column10:
I had to change my review to negative since we're in 2024, a new season is starting and there is no way to add the new Formula 1 circuits to the game. 
No DLC, nothing. I would of bought a DLC with all the circuits. 
I don't need updated driver names, teams etc. I just want to be able to drive on all the circuits in the F1 calendar.
I'm very dissapointed with EA for letting us down. Their greed is just huge, for selling a completely new game just to add 1-2 circuits. 
If they will launch a future F1 game with all the circuits, old and new, I'll buy it but the rating for this F1 22 will not change. It is a good game, but without updates is as good as dead now, only 2 years later.
Game is good but carreer mode is kinda bland and every game is basically the same every year

I like the game quite a lot but my enjoyment of the game in full race career was ruined. 
I play on 96 difficulty and I have been replaying this full race at Mexico over and over. The race starts off dry and goes to Intermediate, then full wets.  
I started 6th and got to P3 n about 25 laps. When the rains came I was dropping laptimes gradually and P1 and P2 (Max and Perez) were gaping me over a second a lap. 
The field closed up on two safety cars and by the second start my tyres were cold( 60c), even though i was frantically trying to get heat in them.
When the restart finally happened i was 20 seconds behind after 3 laps and illegally fending off the rest.
I had to replay the full length race 4 times now and each time the same. I have to forfeit the race and lose any hope of winning the championship. Hours of game play wasted. 
The Ai's tyres do not change at all no heat no wear, nothing. This is something i would expect from a game made in the 90's.
Will i be massive fool and by the next game and pray they fix this dumass game? yeah, probably.
Update; 
I didn't end up buying the new games (so far). Now that I have a Fanatec wheel and base I ended up playing mostly Asetta Corsa. Now that I am back, another observation is the long wait times for "communicating with server" over and over. Total pain in the butt when you want a quick race. 
As it is, I wont consider buying another F1 game until 2025, which is a shame, because I don't like F1, I love it.

Wow, for as much dislike I have for F1 games made by codemasters, they are absolute legends compared to a company like 2k. At least codemasters releases the same game version across all platforms. At least codemasters releases the new tracks the year they come out, and don't, for instance, advertise the new in season tournament as part of their game, only  for that new in season tournament to only be on consoles. Shout out to codemasters. Sure their games are copy and pasted, and sure the driving is arcadey more than sim, but at least they do a proper copy and paste job. Unlike 2k, who can't even get copy and paste right.

It was a departure from the story mode of F1 2021 and 2019 and the classic cars of 2019-20. Honestly a poor release overall. Terrible handling, weird physics, completely broken at launch. F1 Life was something literally no-one asked for, especially as it had no link to the actual Career Mode - rather the data used actually made Career Mode and My Team Career both much less in-depth.

Go and buy F1 2019 or 2020. Much better, and feature the amazing classic cars. Haven't touched this since I switched to iRacing, but I've played F1 2019 on and off.

I would only recommend buying ever other year when it comes to F1. Such a great game but just like Fifa - would I buy it ever year? no.

Buy it if on offer.

It must be difficult to produce a new game every year in an era of game development typically being many times that. Unfortunately, that difficulty really shows here. As the first F1 game with VR support I couldn't wait to try it, but it's virtually unusable, with stutters and frame drops, tearing and jumps (despite my relatively high-end PC). The tyres feel completely unconnected to the road and will randomly understeer or oversteer with zero warning. As others have mentioned the throttle input is completely oversensitive, and you'll spin out on corner exit constantly - again, with no warning. FP1 will have a 'green' track with no rubber down, which is realistic for real life, but unfortunately nobody told the other competitors, whose lap times don't suffer in any way. This has been a perennial problem for YEARS with these games. The Hot Laps could be a fun addition but the cars feel so horribly plasticky and unrealistic it's like their physics has been lifted from Sega Rally. Ultimately a really disappointing instalment of the game. I won't be back.

I took a break from the game just to jump into it again in December 2023. Game is unplayable, keep getting Ego dumper errors, tried different versions of Windows, gone through hours of tutorials just to get into the game and get crashes. I feel that it is the developers way of forcing the newest game on you and push sales by making earlier games unplayable.

I have less than 10 hours on this game and 8 of it has been trying to find a lobby that is bug free. The matchmaking is so bad that finding a quality game with real people is like trying to swim in the ocean with concrete boots...its very hard. Classic EA using the Copy and Paste technique for another F1 game without trying to make it better in anyway. Consider this a Job application EA. I will work from home on my Macintosh and I will produce a better game than this. Now if you will excuse me, I'm going to go play NASCAR on my DS because at least i can play online SUCCESSFULLY with that.

Out of the three F1 games I own currently this is the weakest entry, pretty bad launch, no braking point and really just nothing inspiring or crazy going on here.

The game also doesn't run amazing I had a lot of fps issues but this may of been ironed out now, crashing and stuttering.

Also the controls weren't great, the feedback wasn't as responsive as other games, not sure if they changed anything or it's just I'm not a fan of this game. It's the same old F1 formula however so even if I'm being a bit harsh on this game, just buy F1 21 or F1 23 instead

The only reason i play it is - it's the only F1 game i know. They're just milking the license with minimal effort put into the game. It's a bad racing game - from the UI to the car behaviour / handling / input, to the AI, bugs & crashes...
The only passable thing is the graphics (except the ray tracing, that's just a useless gimmick) but for me that's the least important thing about a racing game.
Avoid it if you can.

This game is an obvious downgrade from its 2 predecessors, which were arguably the best F1 games Codemasters have ever made (especially F1 2020), but we have to point out the obvious that EA has done some usual EA things with this game. Here are some features that were present in the last two games (either in one of them or in both), but went extinct here: Real-season start, classic cars, story mode (braking point).
Instead of these we got some supercars, which we can only show off to our imaginary friends in F1 life and drive them in challenges and in time trial only. Meaning: we can't race them, which could be fun, but EA says no... Oh yeah, F1 life. This breathtaking new feature is absolutely pointless packed with microtransactions (to make your living quarters or what they're called look better, but you only see that in the menu when you boot up the game, that's it...)

Overall, for its current price it is absolutely not worth it, I bought it on a discount too, and I wouldn't recommend it if I wasn't a huge F1 fan. I can still play my team, which is the best gamemode, I can play online where an extremely high rate of races turn into a crash-fest immediately and I can play co-op career with my friend and absolutely bully the whole field and cause the funniest crashes ever. Conclusion: worse then previous F1 games, but for racing it's a very nice game and I enjoyed myself a lot.

"Racing Through My Couch Potato Dreams: A Review of the 2022 Official Formula 1 Game" (By ChatGPT)

Ladies and gentlemen, start your consoles! If you’ve ever dreamt of being a speed demon without leaving your comfy couch, the 2022 Official Formula 1 Game is your ticket to adrenaline-fueled, tire-squealing joyrides. Buckle up and read on for a review that might just make Lewis Hamilton reconsider retirement (okay, maybe not).

Graphics:
I mean, wow! The visuals are so crisp that I almost spilled my virtual energy drink thinking a tire was about to roll out of the screen. The cars look so shiny; I could practically see my reflection in them—though, that might just be the leftover pizza on my shirt.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is smoother than a freshly paved racetrack. It’s so immersive that I accidentally tried to change gears with my TV remote during a particularly intense race. The thrill of overtaking rivals at 300 km/h is almost as satisfying as finding extra fries at the bottom of the takeout bag.

Realism:
They weren’t kidding about realism! The developers must have borrowed some magic from the F1 engineers because the handling and physics feel spot-on. But let’s be real; I’d probably spin out on a straight road in real life, so kudos to the game for not letting me embarrass myself.

Career Mode:
Becoming an F1 legend is within reach—well, virtually at least. The career mode lets you rise from rookie driver to championship contender faster than it takes me to finish a tub of ice cream. Plus, negotiating contracts and managing team relationships is almost as tricky as explaining to my mom why I spent the whole weekend gaming.

Multiplayer:
If racing against AI isn’t thrilling enough, dive into multiplayer. But beware, it’s like entering a lion’s den full of competitive gamers who drive like they're being chased by a swarm of bees. You might win or end up using more expletives than the number of laps completed. It's all part of the fun, right?

Soundtrack:
The soundtrack is a symphony of engine roars and screeching tires. It's like Beethoven for petrolheads. I almost forgot I was sitting in my living room and not in the grandstands at Monza. Just remember to turn it down if you live in an apartment unless you want your neighbors to think there's an actual F1 race happening in your living room.

Overall, the 2022 Official Formula 1 Game is a must-have for racing enthusiasts and couch potatoes alike. It’s as addictive as grandma’s secret cookie recipe and as thrilling as bungee jumping—without the risk of a faceplant. Just remember to take breaks, hydrate, and occasionally venture into the real world. Who knows, maybe one day you'll graduate to racing actual cars. But until then, happy virtual racing, folks!

Rating: 5 out of 5 virtual checkered flags 🏁

Realism and Graphics: The F1 series is known for its attention to detail in replicating real tracks, cars, and overall F1 experience. Graphics tend to improve with each iteration, aiming for a more realistic portrayal of the sport. This wasn't the case for the Drivers, they did them dirty to be honest, they don't look how they do in real like, Also it would been better to seen more animation when you win, not the same 3 animations and then you are showering the other on champagne their clothes doesn't get wet, and so on, the animations doesn't look well worked into. 

Gameplay and Controls: These games usually offer a balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for experienced players. The handling of cars, nuances of different tracks, and the overall feel of racing are significant aspects. Even tho I got issues while trying to connect my steering wheel and never got it to work, F1® 22 is very enjoyable with a controller but it would it been SO MUCH BETTER WITH A STEERING WHEEL!, when playing It would it been nicer to see the IA crash with the walls of the track or even with other drivers which this would make to pull out the safety car into the race, not go to a side of the race and disappear like nothing happen, I would love to see it more the track more "alive".

Career Mode and Features: F1® 22 includes a career mode where players can start as a rookie driver and progress through seasons, signing contracts, developing cars, and managing the team, The issue is that if you want to start on F2 there's no a lot to do, it will be less than 10 races and most likely after that you go to F1 races, so there's isn't much to do in F2. Also I would love to have a deeper customization while creating your own driver, like being able to create them from zero like how you do in other EA games (an example would be UFC), not having already pre-fabricated drivers which you can't customize other than the clothes, helmet, gloves, and car.

If you would like to a F1® game, don't end up wasting your money on F1® 22, just go and buy the F1® 23 which includes newer drivers and tracks or even just wait for F1® 24 and wait to see if they don't mess it up like they did with F1® 22

Bought my first F1 game in years since they finally bothered there arse to bring in VR.

The good: It finally has VR.
The bad: It's still a boring game that I can't stay interested in long enough to even complete one full season.

I dunno, I love watching F1, but it's just much more interesting to play iRacing, RaceRoom, ACC,  rFactor 2 (well maybe not bug-ridden  rFactor 2) and pretty much any other sim which has more car/track variation, more interesting gameplay and/or better online systems. Even Project Cars 2 was more interesting.

If you're ONLY interested in driving F1 cars, then you might find a decent game here. For me, F1 games seem to have lost their soul since the heady days of Microprose's F1GP series...

Appreciate the new one is out and getting good reviews but figured I would leave a review for this, in case anyone opted to pick it up on sale before it gets de-listed from Steam. 
I know this got Mixed to Mostly Positive (recent) reviews (and yes does have some bugs somewhere, as they always do), but I honestly think this game is quite good. I only play single player, career mode, and granted nothing has changed from last year in career mode but overall I prefer it to 21. Personally I prefer the way the cars feel and handle, and the FFB has improved from 21. Furthermore, whilst the AI can have their moments of madness (as they do in all sims), but overall the AI is pretty damn good in this game - I've had some absolutely fantastic races and battles against the AI. I've come to realise that across most sims, the AI is never perfect, each has their flaws in some places (for me, RaceRoom is my favourite sim and even the AI there, which is very good, do have some mad moments) and then you consider the AI of the likes of AMS2, ACC etc and you realise none is perfect. But anyway I digress, overall I think the AI is pretty good and provides for some very good battles in F1 22. 
As an aside, I have no interest in the EA add-ons like F1 life and the supercars, but I just choose to ignore that. Overall, I have enjoyed playing this game a lot.

First off; [u]this game had huge potential[/u]. F1 2021 was a great game that got many things right, providing a solid springboard forwards. Some things from F1 2020 were missing or changed for the worse, and I felt like 22 was the opportunity to correct those. With the new F1 regulations, new cars, it gave Codemasters the chance to make the best F1 game to date.

Unfortunately that's not what happened.

[b]The Handling:[/b] Changed to reflect the new cars, which is fine, but not in the right ways. Feedback from losing grip is almost non-existent, making pushing to the limits incredibly hard. I get this game is trying to cater to Sim and Arcade racers, but this middle-ground should be better. When real F1 drivers like Lando Norris are saying the Medium Traction Control option feels more realistic, something is not right. Wheel or controller, it's tough to enjoy the physics of the game with this limitation.

[b]Game Modes:[/b] The Driving Point mode is gone, which is a shame as it provided a Drive-To-Survive style story mode, perfect to get casual users and those wanting to try something different with unique stakes. [u]There's nothing new this year really, though, bit of a shame[/u]. The remaining modes are great though. Even online functions pretty well, as I've raced in several different leagues with few troubles (only issue here is the inconsistent automatic penalty system, but it's one of those things that's impossible to get perfected).

[b]The AI:[/b] I feel like Codies AI is... an illusion. Yes they make mistakes, but they are very obviously scripted. Watching an AI wheel-spin on a hairpin is hilarious, it doesn't look realistic at all. Restart a race multiple times, and the same drivers will retire each time, at the same time. This is compounded by how the AI difficulty can vary track-to-track, and it even varies through qualifying and the race. You'll see popular YouTubers constantly altering the AI level between tracks and sessions to balance it. Further proof was the early game bug, where the AI would gain insane traction out of slow corners, making them almost impossible to race. This bug still hasn't been fully fixed in my opinion, with AI being crazy fast in both wet and changing conditions. The AI is a lot more aggressive this year however, a huge positive change in my mind, as far too often they'd yield, letting human drivers get away with silly moves.

[b]Authenticity[/b]: One thing Codies are fantastic at, making you feel like an F1 driver with all the bells and whistles. Having F2 back again is great, and starting a career mode in F2 is honestly a wonderful option. The new cars and liveries look amazing, and while some tracks have not been fully updated, those that are here do look fairly good, even if not perfect. The new addition of lining up on your grid slot is great, through the timing of your pit-stop turn-in is very minor. Very little wrong here.

[b]"F1 Life":[/b] A huge waste of time really. The addition of SuperCars would be acceptable, but you cannot race them against other; just silly time trial style events. They added ridiculous amounts of filler too, like decorating an apartment, casualwear clothes, which are obviously meant to extract more monetisation. Surely the time and resources spent on this, could have been spent on updating the existing tracks like Spa to 2022 standards? Also irritating is how this is rendered in the background of most menus, maxing out GPU usage almost constantly.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
[b]Not bad, but not great either. Could have been so much better. Might be worth a punt if it's your first F1 game, but 2021 and 2020 offer much more compelling handling and modes,[/b]

F1 2022, the latest installment in the popular Formula 1 gaming series, comes with high expectations and excitement from fans, but unfortunately, it doesn't quite hit the mark. The most significant letdown in this iteration is the handling model, which feels like a step down from its predecessors, making it hard to recommend to long-time fans of the series.

The handling of the cars in F1 2022 is a key aspect that's taken a step in the wrong direction. Previous games in the series had achieved a level of realism and precision that made you feel like you were truly in control of a high-performance racing machine. In F1 2022, however, the handling model falls short. The cars feel less responsive and more unpredictable, making it challenging to maintain a sense of control, especially when pushing the limits on the track.

The lackluster handling isn't the only concern. While F1 2022 offers a visually stunning racing experience with impressive graphics and a good selection of classic cars, it falls short in other areas. The career mode, which has been a highlight in previous games, feels somewhat lackluster, lacking the depth and immersion that fans have come to expect.

The introduction of the new "Real-Season Start" feature is a promising addition, allowing players to join a current season in progress. However, it doesn't fully compensate for the disappointment in other areas of the game.

On the bright side, the multiplayer experience in F1 2022 remains a fun and competitive element for those looking to race against others online. The game's online modes offer a chance to go head-to-head with players from around the world, delivering the excitement of wheel-to-wheel battles on iconic tracks.

In summary, F1 2022 had the potential to build upon the success of its predecessors, offering an even more immersive and realistic Formula 1 racing experience. However, the disappointing handling model makes it hard to overlook its shortcomings. For long-time fans of the series who've enjoyed the precise and exhilarating racing of previous titles, F1 2022 may feel like a step in the wrong direction. While it's not a complete failure and still delivers some enjoyable moments, it falls short of its predecessors and, as such, might not be worth the investment for those seeking the pinnacle of Formula 1 racing on the virtual track.

[h1] Conflicted Emotions [/h1]

F1 22 has left me in a state of conflicting emotions. While undeniably a good game that offers a thrilling racing experience, it falls short in certain aspects compared to its predecessor, making it a clear downgrade from F1 2021.

[h1] Part 1: Visual Fidelity [/h1]

One area where F1 22 truly shines is in its graphics and visuals. The game boasts stunning attention to detail, with meticulously recreated car models, realistic weather effects, and immersive track environments. The visuals create a sense of immersion that truly captures the essence of Formula 1 racing. The upgraded graphics engine showcases improved lighting and shading, making the overall experience visually impressive.

[h1] Part 2: Gameplay and Mechanics [/h1]

The core gameplay mechanics in F1 22 remain solid, providing an authentic racing experience. The handling and physics model have been refined, resulting in more responsive controls and a heightened sense of realism. The game offers a comprehensive range of modes, including the career mode, multiplayer, and time trials, allowing players to engage in various racing challenges. The inclusion of new features, such as expanded team management options, adds depth and complexity to the gameplay experience.

However, despite these improvements, F1 22 also introduces a few frustrating elements. The AI behavior during races feels erratic at times, with opponents making questionable moves that can lead to unnecessary collisions. Additionally, certain aspects of the game's mechanics, such as tire wear and fuel consumption, seem unbalanced and can make the gameplay feel overly challenging and less enjoyable.

[h1] Part 3: Content [/h1]

F1 22 delivers an abundance of content, featuring all the teams, drivers, and circuits from the 2022 Formula 1 season. The inclusion of the new tracks, along with the updated liveries and driver lineups, adds an authentic touch to the game. The career mode provides a deep and immersive experience, allowing players to manage their team, make strategic decisions, and compete for championships.

Despite the extensive content, some players might feel that the game lacks innovation and fails to introduce significant new features compared to the previous installment. The absence of a meaningful upgrade in this aspect leaves a sense of disappointment, as fans had hoped for more groundbreaking additions to enhance their racing experience.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

In conclusion, F1 22 is undoubtedly a good game that delivers an enjoyable racing experience. The upgraded graphics, refined gameplay mechanics, and extensive content offer plenty of reasons to immerse oneself in the world of Formula 1. However, it is important to acknowledge that the game falls short when compared to its predecessor, lacking the innovation and significant improvements that would have elevated it to the next level. Despite its shortcomings, F1 22 remains a solid choice for Formula 1 enthusiasts, albeit with the knowledge that it represents a clear downgrade from the previous year's iteration.

Car setups:

Aerodynamics - There are only 2 items in this category and they refer to changes to the front and rear wings of the car. You can increase the pitch of the wings to improve both downforce and traction, or you can choose to reduce aerodynamic drag and improve top speed at the expense of less downforce.

Transmission - This tab contains Differential Adjustment. This can affect the way power is transferred to the car's rear wheels. Choosing a more open differential setting reduces tire wear, while choosing a more closed setting improves the car's grip.

Suspension Geometry - In this group of options, you can modify the Toe and Camber. Selecting a more negative camber value improves grip on long turns. However, a too negative camber can lead to increased tire wear.

Suspension - The tab here allows you to adjust the stiffness of the suspension and ride height. Going for a stiffer suspension may improve the stability of the car, but it will wear out the tires more and make the car drive unstable on uneven surfaces (you will feel it on tracks like the one in Singapore). Choosing a soft suspension will improve performance on uneven ground, but the car can tilt when you brake or accelerate suddenly.

Brakes - In this category, you can set the Brake Pressure and Brake Bias. The default pressure is 100%, but with ABS turned off, this can cause them to lock up frequently with more sudden braking. Balance modifications allow you to better match the operation of the brakes to the specifics of the track.

Tires - This tab allows you to select individual pressure for each tire. Choosing soft tires improves traction at the expense of steering sensitivity, while choosing higher tire pressure improves speed on straights but makes tires heat up faster.

F1 22. EA's first fully-published game after their 2021 takeover of Codemasters.

[h1] Positives [/h1]

There are not many positives from F1 22 - but here we go! The first improvement is in the wings. No longer does the car handle differently at Singapore than what it does at Melbourne. You have the full aero range from 0 to 50, which means that 0-0 at Monaco is entirely possible and so is 50-50 at Monza and Miami. 

Tire wear is more pronounced at every track, but this has its negatives.

The final positive is the kerbs. No longer are they going to murder you for the slightest offence like they did on F1 2021. 

That's it for the good. Now we move onto the bad, and holy crap there is a lot to talk about.

[h1] Negatives [/h1]

We're here. F1 22 is notorious for having the traction levels of black ice. It is possible to lose the car through wheelspin in the following scenarios:

- 4th gear at about 80-90 km/h
- 7th gear with all the aero on tap
- 5th / 6th gear at about half throttle

This makes for a frustrating handling model where you had zero clue what the car would do. Pushing over the limit meant an instant spin which you couldn't feel due to the god-awful FFB.

F1 Life is a joke. Who actually used the supercars after the first month?

The AI are professional punters. They also have twice the grip, which just makes them embarrassingly slow without this extra grip. They are not any faster or slower than F1 21's AI, just worse as it's significantly less fair. 

Online was plagued with issues right from the off and crossplay only made those worse. 

[h1] Verdict and Rating [/h1]
F1 22 was a major letdown for the F1 game franchise due to its horrid handling, poor AI and a dearth of content.

Being a Codemasters dev must be such an easy job. Every year, release the same game, halfway through the season, with slight physics and UI tweaks, and call it a day. This game is essentially the exact same game as F1 18, with updated teams and track selections. And let's not fool ourselves into thinking that this is EA's fault, because Codemasters has been pulling this same garbage for at least 5 years now.
I originally said that the adaptive triggers were better than they were in 21, but that's not true at all. In 21, the throttle trigger would stiffen up as you approached the limit, and pushing up to the limit required actual physical effort. Now the triggers don't really stiffen up until you're already spinning. Especially after having put dozens of hours into 21, and combined with the handling changes they've made this year, it's incredibly frustrating to suddenly spin with no warning through the triggers. They feel sooo much less useful than they did in 21.
"F1 Life" is an absolute joke, purely and obviously there exclusively to give you multiple ways to spend money or trigger FOMO (so that you spend money)
Whoever made the choice to put a significant emphasis on "supercars" in an F1 game should be fired. It is one of the most baffling decisions I've ever seen. If I wanted to drive supercars, there are dozens of other games I could, and would, be playing. I play the F1 games to, you know, RACE F1 CARS. Maybe if the F1 experience were perfect, I would be happy to see supercars in my game. But the F1 experience is not perfect, not by a long shot. 
I don't want to level up a podium pass. I don't want to drive supercars. I don't want to dress my driver up in absurd outfits and have him dance fortnite dances on the podium. I haven't spent a cent on a single in-game purchase in the years that they've been in the game. I just want to race my god damn F1 cars around the track and play through a realistic season/career. I would pay $60 a year, easily, if the game actually gave me what I wanted. But maybe 30% of the game is what I want, so I have no reason to ever pay full price for this game, and I encourage others to do the same.

As a devoted racing enthusiast, I can confidently say that F1 2022 is an absolute masterpiece that truly captures the essence of Formula 1. From the exhilarating gameplay to the breathtaking visuals, this game delivers an immersive and unforgettable racing experience.

The attention to detail in F1 2022 is nothing short of remarkable. The meticulously recreated tracks, stunning graphics, and realistic weather effects make every race feel like I'm right in the heart of the action. Whether it's racing under the blazing sun or navigating treacherous rain-soaked circuits, the level of immersion is unparalleled.

The handling and physics of the cars are spot-on, providing a challenging and rewarding driving experience. Each car feels unique, and mastering their nuances is a thrilling endeavor that keeps me engaged for hours on end.

One of the standout features of F1 2022 is the My Team mode. Creating my own team and managing every aspect, from hiring drivers to developing the car, adds a strategic element to the game that I absolutely adore. It's incredibly satisfying to see my team grow and compete with the giants of Formula 1.

The Career mode is equally captivating, offering a dynamic and evolving journey through the ranks of Formula 1. The ability to forge a career path, negotiate contracts, and compete against legendary drivers adds depth and replayability to the game.

Moreover, F1 2022 boasts an impressive roster of iconic drivers and teams, allowing fans to race as their favorite stars or challenge history by rewriting the outcomes of classic races.

Online multiplayer is seamless, offering thrilling races against real-world opponents from around the globe. The competitive environment pushes my skills to the limit, and the sense of accomplishment after a hard-fought victory is immensely rewarding.

The developers' commitment to regular updates and listening to player feedback further enhances the game's experience. They actively address issues, improve gameplay mechanics, and introduce new content, ensuring that F1 2022 continues to evolve and remain relevant.

In conclusion, F1 2022 is a racing enthusiast's dream come true. Its stunning visuals, realistic driving mechanics, and engaging game modes create an unparalleled experience in the world of motorsport gaming. Whether you're a seasoned Formula 1 fan or a newcomer to racing games, F1 2022 is an absolute must-play.

Disappointing.

[h1]Early nonsense[/h1]
The "3 days early access" (expensive version) meant that friends would get split up, as some had early access, and some didn't (just because of the greed of the publisher, although the launch was delayed). The "Pre-Purchase - Limited Time Bonus" was a horrid mixture of fear-of-missing-out (FOMO), [i]and[/i] you'd miss out on content if you didn't pre-order the even more expensive version [i]early enough[/i]. They'll write up lines like: "Don't miss out on the time-limited Miami content!" - but why make it limited then? Why can't they just make a good product for the customers? Money that could have been spent fixing the horrid penalty system instead went to making movie style advertising instead. 

[h1]As a product[/h1]
Steering degrees are 360, which is an important detail for wheel users (which was left out). They learnt absolutely nothing from the mistakes of previous games - there's a forced introduction to the game, and it'll forget that you've gone through it before. All the intro does is just force you to look at their driver avatar system where they added microtransactions for avatar clothing. They're trying to treat it like Second Life, but in reality it's a racing game that has a maximum shelf life of 1 year.

Again, there's no mouse input, and the F buttons are used for navigation, so you might be taking unwanted screenshots just to get around the menu. The input sometimes doesn't work. The wheel buttons are a mess, as is the menu (made more irritating when flashing alerts won't go away, and the microtransactions). Trying it with a wheel - the default T300 settings are wrong.

You can get stuck trying to reach the menu because "failed to connect to online services" with no way to quit, being left with a retry button and a useless cancel button. Trying cancel, and [i]then[/i] retry takes you to the menu for a second, before being booted to the retry/cancel screen again.

Sometimes I can barely even navigate the menu without the microtransaction screens popping up, saying things like "dont miss out!" or being glitched out blank windows. I had three ads for pitcoin and tokens within seconds of eachother [i]after[/i] I'd selected "don't show this again". There's menu advertising for EA play. The invasive microtransactions make this expensive game feel like a free-to-play game.

The framerate feels pretty bad, and there's micro stuttering even after turning the graphics down (even on a good PC), and game crashes. The game was not compatible with shadowplay when I tried it. A lot of the time the game won't minimize, and the Steam overlay sometimes doesn't work in it. Frustratingly the race settings don't save (save issues have been in this series since F1 2010, which is why I don't bother with singleplayer championships). The selected control scheme can confusingly be hidden off-screen when looking through settings.

They added a lot of hit and miss pop music, but they don't fit the theme like F1 2000's [i]Phat Planet[/i] did. You can hear music sometimes while on-track, which means that uploading videos of gameplay would run into copyright issues (if FOM didn't outright pull your video down).

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Time trial sometimes doesn't show the lap timing gap (or even the timing at all), and doesn't always upload times when it claims that it did. Rank percentages are missing in TT, and it's awkward to even reach the leaderboards. TT laps sometimes show as invalidated when the lead up and full lap were clean. The leaderboards feel meaningless when you have a lap that said it was invalidated, but it still uploaded itself onto the leaderboard like it was a clean lap.

Multiplayer involves a lot of waiting around, and you can't quit while waiting for another player to finish loading (which sometimes gets stuck, or throws you an error). There's a race mode with collisions disabled, but it never worked for me. In every other mode you consistently encounter dirty drivers (again, the penalty system has failed to be a positive addition). You can tell it's a console port, because the mics are open by default.

The cars can snap - suddenly losing all grip, and when you do have grip they aren't as fun to drive compared to the smoothness of the Race07 Formula Masters car, or the beautiful hint of oversteer of the Simraceway Formula Renault 3.5 car (both released over a decade ago). Something about tokens pops up while driving, which is distracting. Awkwardly you turn into the pit box by pressing a button, and I couldn't get the pit limiter to work, and found no indication for when to move on pit release.

Cars spin worse and worse as the race goes on, and can't be saved - apparently you need to lower the tyre pressure, but this level of engineering conflicts heavily with the playability of the console market, so it feels more like a frustrating oversight than a feature, and splits the league playerbase (some want to combat the tyre pressure issue, some want to disable it). Organizing leagues on Steam is considered "advertising", so it's all pointless anyway.

Supercars were added, which is not a unique selling point - many other games have them, and they clearly didn't belong in an F1 game - judging by the leaderboards, few players were interested in how they handled. They felt as horrible as their interiors look - like PS1 graphics on launch. There was no dashboard or HUD information. Their inclusion just bloated the game's download size to 47 GB. If anything - they should have added classic F1 cars (which some of the earlier games used to have, but the older games no longer work). Supercars steering degrees are 360, but this didn't seem to match the F1 cars, despite the F1 cars also being 360. For some reason the look behind button doubled as the handbrake.

[h1]VR[/h1]
Trying the game with a Valve Index - the menus are in your face, so you have to move your head around to see anything, but this leads to the angle of your default VR position to change, and frustratingly the offset conflicts with the reset. The menus are also blindingly bright (it feels like they didn't make any changes after testing VR mode, as if they just wanted it to be functional so they could advertise it as being VR capable). Stuttering is worse in VR, and the visuals are blurry, so I wouldn't take it seriously. Only the cockpit view is allowed - I couldn't even switch to the T-cam. The only HUD element appeared to be the front brake bias option (which was stuck on screen). As soon as the race ends it switches to 2D mode.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Few players got achievements (and they look mundane), which speaks to the overcooked design and the raw issues that were never addressed. The whole thing felt disappointing. They just use the news section on the Steam library to spam nonsense like [i]"Your time to race!"[/i] and advertise the next game. How long will it be until the game is axed? F1 2019 crashes when I try to launch it, and I couldn't even see it on Steam store.

Essentially - every year you lose your trophies, and have to re-do all the broken controls, re-do the customisation, and have to pay more (often for less features, such as the cutting of classic cars and additional track layouts) while the file sizes becomes more bloated, and the microtransactions become more invasive.

It's difficult to recommend an expensive product (at £49.99, which isn't even the complete edition) when it's already obsolete because they want to make an entirely new one, instead of make a base game with yearly DLC (which could centralize the community). Listening to esports commentators trying to talk around the glitches in live broadcasts was amusing, but F1 was supposed to be the best, and this just isn't it.

Title: F1 22 by EA: A Handling Disaster That Ruined the Game

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆

As an avid sim racing enthusiast, I had high hopes for F1 22 by EA. However, after spending countless hours with the game, I have come to the unfortunate conclusion that it is an absolute disaster, especially when it comes to handling. In fact, it has been so frustrating and disappointing that I have seriously contemplated selling my entire sim racing rig.

The handling in F1 22 is abysmal, to say the least. It feels completely disconnected from reality, lacking any semblance of the precision and responsiveness one would expect from a racing simulator. The cars feel floaty, as if they are gliding on ice rather than gripping the track. This lack of grip is exaggerated to such an extent that it becomes virtually impossible to maintain control, even under normal racing conditions.

Cornering, which is a fundamental aspect of Formula 1 racing, is a nightmare in F1 22. The cars inexplicably lose traction at the slightest provocation, resulting in frustrating spins and crashes that feel entirely out of the player's control. It's as if the laws of physics have been completely disregarded, making each corner a gamble rather than a calculated maneuver.

Moreover, the force feedback, which is crucial for providing the player with vital information about the car's behavior, is shockingly inadequate. The feedback is vague, lacking the necessary nuances to communicate the subtleties of the car's movements. This further exacerbates the handling issues and contributes to the overall sense of frustration and detachment from the driving experience.

The AI drivers in F1 22 are equally disappointing. They lack any form of intelligence or realism, often exhibiting nonsensical behavior on the track. They seem oblivious to their surroundings, frequently causing unnecessary collisions and impeding the player's progress. Racing against these mindless bots only adds to the frustration and undermines any sense of competitiveness or immersion.

Perhaps the most disheartening aspect of F1 22 is the fact that it was developed by EA, a company known for its history of producing quality games. I expected much more from a franchise that carries the prestigious F1 license. Unfortunately, EA has failed to deliver a game that captures the essence of Formula 1 racing and satisfies the needs of sim racing enthusiasts.

In conclusion, F1 22 by EA is a colossal disappointment, primarily due to its horrendous handling. The lack of grip, unrealistic physics, and inadequate force feedback make for an infuriating and detached driving experience. Combined with the subpar AI drivers, this game has managed to sour my passion for sim racing to the point where I contemplated selling my entire rig. Save yourself the frustration and look elsewhere for a truly immersive and enjoyable Formula 1 racing experience.

My review of F1 22, the latest F1 game release, and the first F1 game by EA since 2003.

[h1] Positives [/h1]

- The handling is a lot better than F1 2021, and I enjoy it very much. Only issue has been spinning but you have to be more careful on the throttle to prevent it.
(Since the update to the handling at the start, I have found it better and enjoyed it more, so I'm glad this happened)

- F1 Life is actually a cool mode. There have been memes on the furniture stuff, and people don't like it because EA, but to make it how you like is cool. You can also visit other players F1 Life place, and after an online session it also shows people you recently played with in that part.

- The engine sounds have changed and they are all really nice, they did a good job on that.

- The soundtrack is really good again, could even be better than 2021's soundtrack. I'm talking about the main theme, not the music that EA put in there.

- Some tracks have been updated and also more have been laser-scanned, which is good to see, there were complaints about inaccurate tracks last year and those updates are pretty good now.

- The features of lining up on the grid and pitting manually are good to have, it makes the game more immersive and realistic.

[h1] Negatives [/h1]

- The AI have been fun to race with when it's clean, but their biggest flaw is that they are absolute terrorists. They dive you a lot and go for moves in unrealistic situations.

- The supercars are pretty useless and were not needed tbh. For an F1 game I don't think they are needed.

- Unnecessary bugs like tyre temps resetting after the formation lap.

- Crossplay is massive for the F1 games, it's never been a feature until now, but I had a lot of issues with it involving desync and other things, it was during the beta though so it can be fixed, but it just made it unraceable for me. Hopefully it's improved over time.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Overall F1 22 is a really good game and I definitely would recommend. 
An extremely underrated game imo, I feel that it's better than a few other F1 games that I personally didn't enjoy. It doesn't deserve the negative ratings, hopefully the good run continues :)

This is probably the worst F1 game ever. I'm racing in a league regulary and this year was probably the worst experience I've ever had.
Here are my issues I've had in this years game:
- Disconnects from the server
- MINUS DEGREE Celcius tyres after rejoining!

- SC ended in the last corner once. Due to the limiter for the driver in front I rear ended him (front wing damage) + I got rear ended as well which sent me off track and I was able to spectate the SC restart from the gravel trap. Thank you EA
- My broken front wing doesn't get changed
- The weather forecast doesn't work in this game. One of the most important things for a race.
- You can't unlap yourself which destroys your race completely if the SC is getting deployed
- The grip/handling is so bad and random. If you have oversteer, most of the times you're not able to catch it for some reason.

To drive on this game was just pain. From the very first second until now.
And I didn't even started on this whole mini-transactions, living room thingy or the Super Cars which are so useless and unimportant.

1/10 because of game ending buggs and issues. More about that:

The Base of the game is solid, not going to lie. It's fun. But some of the buggs are just so dumb that they want you to stop playing the game entirely. 
We are talking you are on the second to last lap of a race, and drove Soft + Medium Tires but get a warning, that you have to put on "Soft or Hard" Tires or you get Disqualified. YOU DRIVE INTO the pits to change to hard tires, AND YOU STILL get disqualified for it. 

WHAT?! Not only is that dumb and annoying, but also can cost you 30 Minutes or more time of your Life. 
At the moment I would just recommend buying the old Codemaster games without EA influence. They are by far not as bugged. - This happend in a Crossplay-COOP- Career.

By the way: It does not matter if you pit when you get the warning. I have had this bugg happen to me TWICE within 49 hours of playtime, the first time I drove 3 tires (Soft, Medium, Soft) and ignored the warning to change (to Soft or Medium) and got disqualified. The SECOND time I mentioned in this Review I pitted for Hards and STILL GOT DISQUALIFIED. - So when ever this happens to you, you are F'ed because you WILL be disqualified no matter what you do.

3/10 - Rating Buggs like this should not exist in a released game.

UPDATE: MONTHS later maybe even a Year, and this Tire Compound bugg still isn't fixed, for the AI yes, but not for the player. This is a Carrear ENDING bugg in singleplayer campaigns. I CANNOT BELIEVE that this is still not fixed. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I expect this to be the issue in F1 23 too, or atleast that there are buggs of similar graditude. Codemasters and EA do NOT fix any buggs it seems. Thanks EA, for also ruining the F1 Games.
They even added another Issue, after 10 minutes in a race you can get frame drops down to 14-15 fps for a couple seconds. Which can send you into a wall quickly. this then continues to happen every 1 to 1 and a half minutes. None of the fixes I tried helped me in any way. By now this Game is pretty much unplayable.

1/10 - still looks good though but other than that...

The worst f1 game to ever exist. No traction, understeer on every corner, if not understeer then very sharp oversteer, the throttle inputs are more inconsistent than Liverpool in 22/23. The only somewhat playable mode is time trial because the tyre temperatures are fixed and even thats shit. Both Normal and My Team career modes get boring after about 3 races and the online races are an absolute joke. No person can drive normally in any online lobby, you either get some daft twat that brakes in eau rouge or tries to go flat round monaco, someone who sends it down your inside, your outside and up your arse in every corner, or people who have been doing league races for their whole lives, play 13 hours a day on their fancy fucking fanatec £15k wheel setups with a £50k pc just to play a game where cars go round in funny shaped circles for hours at a time. The tracks are the most boring things I have ever seen in my 16 years on this planet, and I watched  the Spanish Grand Prix in 2022 and 2023, just for a comparison to how boring the tracks are. All this game did was take F1 2021 (Possibly one of the best F1 games, top 3 for me since 2018.) and throw every good feature out of the window. The cars are shit, liveries are shit, they added a fucking battle pass (Get a grip you fat money hungry cunts), there was nothing for anyone to do except a career mode since they added fuck all. And for the entire year, people were left to wonder, 'When is F1 23 coming out?', 'When will EA update this shit handling model?' Well, hopefully, our prayers have been answered in F1 23, and it looks promising so far. Anyways, shit game, don't purchase it no matter what you do.

Well, while the game can be fun, it has a shitton of issues, and is most definetly not worth the asked price.
First of all, the AI. It drives ridiculously aggressive, with no regard for crashes or anything. Second of all, the physics. You're basically driving on ice, as you spin really quickly if you hit the gas a little with TC disabled. And once you lose the rear end, there is no way to recover. A lost rear end is pretty much always a spin. Last, the game just lacks content. There are no classic cars or anything similar to drive. They have been replaced with supercars, which are just plain boring. All in all, not recommended for the price, but decent if you can get it for under 10 €

Once they ironed em up with a couple a patches (hopefully please *edit: they didn't*), this "New Era" game is solidly a GOOD game, and i'm going to give my thumb up on this. Sadly, it is safe to say this is also my last game for the now literally EA-stamped codemasters. The greedy EA overlords(and codies themselves) have certainly aligned their direction to milk this franchise til it becomes a bone dry dead cow.

Physics is decent, has proper pronunciation of understeer and lame low speed oversteer thats found in the new era 22 cars, shame no porpoises tho. Features that are welcome: Driving supercars via Pirelli hotlaps is a good breather before the GP weekend, and VR FINALLY! F1 LIFE: This is a lame direction, this is purposely induced by EA to flaunt petty prestige. The rest is still the same graphics wise, but it seems they have polished DLSS a bit oh well...OH wait no more derpy aiden good riddance!

From 2010 to 22(except the worst of them all: 2014), we the f1 enthusiasts have raised them into a distinguished f1 game maker, we had great memories that will forever cherish and appreciate, but all good things should come into conclusion...but i feel this is going with a bang considering Ian Livingstone is raking his nostalgic masterpiece soundtrack leitmotifs all-out.

We'll let it sink in with the Miami sunset; a proper retirement package~

edit: With the F1 23 early access, I made the biggest lie regarding retirement. F1 22 is a decent game that I still enjoyed, but at the same time gave me a feeling of unbelievable dissatisfaction. Just like the anticlimactic recall of Felipe Massa during my personal fave 2017(coincidence?) TLDR; F1 22 didn't become my final EA-Codies F1 game...but I'll make darn 110% sure F1 23 IS.

Well..... this has been..... a pretty...... interesting...... one. This is why i only have 200 hours on this game:

My positives:
+Latifi

My negatives:
-Unrealistic and terrible traction out of corners and drivability itself like massive understeer and random oversteer. F1 22 has made me hate the new regulation of cars and i though the new cars were terrible until i tried them out on a different sim and actually found out the cars were drivable without assists.
-F1 World. Supercars, Houses, Clothing. Sounded pretty cool but old f1 cars like in F1 2020 and prior itself would have been better. You could only drive the supercars on tracks and not do races or something like a freeroam city. The houses which i was hyping about is just a little menu where you can like change a lamp and furniture + the wall and you couldnt actually see your multi million dollar villa as an F1 driver. I think it would have been cool being able to walk around and see your supercars and rooms of your villa. Clothing.... in an F1 game..... bro i just want to vroom vroom with car ok?
-AI were also an interesting one. The AI were i will say honestly..... diabolical. They would go for massive lunges, divebombs, or would just proceed to turn into you. Terrible.
-Game bugs. I only have 200 hours but i have encountered some from my sessions. Safety car deployed and never came in, Randomly disconnected, Thankfully i didnt do any leagues on this game, And just many bugs i cant be bothered to list here.

My conclusion for anyone who is reading this and is thinking of buying this:
My conclusion: I dont want to launch this game ever again

Should you get it?: No..... definetly not....

Overall, I'm getting a lot of satisfaction when I do get it right.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

F1 2022, developed by Codemasters, is an exceptional racing game that truly captures the exhilaration and authenticity of Formula 1 racing. With its stunning graphics, realistic gameplay mechanics, and attention to detail, this latest installment in the F1 series delivers an unrivaled racing experience that will leave both die-hard fans and newcomers to the sport in awe.

One of the standout features of F1 2022 is its breathtaking visual presentation. The graphics are simply stunning, with meticulously detailed car models, intricately designed race tracks, and jaw-dropping weather effects that immerse players in the world of Formula 1 like never before. From the scorching sun in Bahrain to the rain-soaked streets of Monaco, each race feels like a cinematic spectacle, elevating the overall immersion and realism of the game.

The gameplay mechanics in F1 2022 are top-notch, striking a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. Whether you're a seasoned racing game enthusiast or a casual player, the game offers various driving assists and difficulty options to tailor the experience to your skill level. The handling of the cars is incredibly responsive and realistic, providing a satisfying sense of control as you navigate tight corners and push your vehicle to its limits. The addition of the "Braking Point" story mode further enhances the single-player experience, allowing players to embark on a compelling journey through the world of Formula 1.

F1 2022 excels in its attention to detail and authenticity. The game features an extensive roster of real-world Formula 1 teams, drivers, and tracks, meticulously recreated to provide an accurate representation of the sport. The audio design is equally impressive, with the roaring engines, screeching tires, and the energetic commentary capturing the essence of the Formula 1 atmosphere. The inclusion of the official FIA Formula 2 Championship adds an extra layer of immersion and progression, allowing players to experience the thrill of working their way up the racing ranks.

The multiplayer component of F1 2022 offers an exhilarating and competitive experience. Whether you're racing against friends or challenging other players online, the game's robust multiplayer mode provides endless opportunities for intense wheel-to-wheel battles and strategic racing. The addition of the "Real-Season Start" feature, which allows players to join ongoing official FIA Formula 1 World Championship races, further adds to the authenticity and excitement of multiplayer gameplay.

F1 2022 also benefits from regular updates and support from the developers, ensuring that the game remains up to date with the ever-evolving world of Formula 1. The dedication of Codemasters to delivering a polished and enjoyable experience is evident, as they actively listen to player feedback and make improvements based on community input.

In conclusion, F1 2022 is a triumph in the world of racing games. Its stunning graphics, realistic gameplay mechanics, and attention to detail create an unparalleled racing experience. Whether you're a dedicated Formula 1 fan or simply someone who appreciates high-quality racing games, F1 2022 will undoubtedly captivate you with its authenticity, immersion, and adrenaline-fueled action. Strap yourself in, rev your engine, and get ready for the ultimate Formula 1 racing adventure.

Much more difficult than previous games in the series. Contrary to popular opinion I actually think this adds a greater element of skill and challenge to the game even if it is less true to life. This isn't a simulator after all...

Edit: 5/31/23 - It's been almost a year and my views still stand. Revisiting 2021, 2022 is still worse and is a clear downgrade. I've updated the pros and cons. 

I played F1 2019-2021 at least 100 hours each. Each pro and con will be in comparison to 2021.

Pros:
~ Visuals are slightly better
~ FFB is more responsive
~ Audio is a lot better
~ Variety of localization 

Cons:
~ Clear monetization efforts. Pay real money for Pitcoins to unlock cosmetics for things that don't matter like clothes and furniture. This is an F1 game, not Sims.
~ Clothing and furniture! Who asked for this? It's an F1 game, not Sims.
~ Removed classic cars and other modes. Why? 
~ There's no anticheat in Multiplayer, exemplified by the Esports community.
~ AI is extremely unpredictable. Others may say this makes racing more exciting, but the AI is overly aggressive, will try to kill you like Osama Bin Russell, and they seem to have traction control. I'm no Esports driver though.
~ VR lacks the depth perception of other VR racing games and is still extremely resource intensive.
~ Pirelli Hot Laps with the supercars are awful. The supercars are not enjoyable and are awkward to drive. Skip these as much as you can. Again, it's an F1 game. Focus on the open wheel cars.
~ Soundtrack isn't as good as 2021. 
~ Tsunoda still looks wack. Poor guy.

Watching the dev videos before launch, it seemed the devs had the best intentions in mind and wanted to improve on 2021, but somehow some pointless features made it into the game, probably forced in by some bald executive (EA) who thought it was a good idea.

I was disappointed by initial reviews and talks of hardware not working properly so I decided to wait for the game to show up on Humble next year or something.

Eventually, I decided to try it on my buddy’s Origin account with EA Play and experienced no bugs and my Fanatec wheel (CSL DD w/ McLaren GT3 rim) and Heusinkveld Sprints worked perfect, so I decided to buy the game on Steam.

First off, there’s a learning curve if you’re one to not use traction control. I was getting so frustrated by constantly spinning the car as well as getting major underwater in slow corners. This is an issue in real life with the new regulations as well, so I worked to adapt to it. Just be easy on that throttle and trail brake into corners. Practice, practice, practice, and it’ll come to you.

Overall, the game runs well on my system (2060, i7 8700, 16gb ddr4) and I don’t regret my purchase. The AI is harder than last year, but they race well and race hard. 

As for the micro transactions and such, it’s EA so they definitely shove them down your throat every chance they get, but I couldn’t care less about that BS and just click through it. 

The game exceeded my expectations so far and provides a great virtual F1 experience. It’s very similar to last years game in terms of features, but for the new cars, new and updated tracks, and small features such as pit stop errors, I don’t mind spending the 60 bucks on it.
Real realistic images of tracks, of course with the excellent simulation of dry or rain, and different time of a day, etc. Cars are also very close to the reality ones.

First things first, the developers have really hit the mark with F1 22's features. From the jaw-dropping graphics that make you question if you're watching a race or live-action footage, to the gameplay that gives you a taste of what it's like to be behind the wheel of a screaming F1 machine, this game has it all. I felt like I was right there on the grid, smelling the burning rubber and hearing the engines roar to life. It's a proper thrill, my friends!

The attention to detail is commendable, capturing the essence of the sport with realistic car handling and lifelike tracks that'll make you feel like you're at Silverstone on race day. The career mode, in particular, is a fantastic addition, allowing you to experience the ups and downs of a driver's journey, from battling for that first podium finish to negotiating contracts that could make or break your career. It's a captivating experience that keeps you coming back for more, just like a gripping battle for a championship title!

Now, let's address the elephant in the virtual room: the bugs. Unfortunately, like a pesky fly on your visor, F1 22 does have its fair share of gremlins on track. From occasional AI mishaps that make you wonder if they've mistaken the brake pedal for the accelerator, to minor visual glitches that might have you scratching your head in confusion, there are moments where you'll have to navigate through some virtual potholes. However, I'm confident that the developers will be in the pit lane, working tirelessly to iron out these issues and deliver a smoother race experience.

But fear not, my fellow racers, because despite these hiccups, F1 22 still manages to provide an adrenaline rush like no other. Whether you're engaging in fierce multiplayer battles with your friends or going solo in the career mode, there's no denying the excitement that comes with every lap. Just like a thrilling overtaking maneuver, the highs of this game outweigh the lows, and it's these moments that make F1 22 a worthy addition to any racing fan's collection.

In conclusion, F1 22 is a joyride that'll get your heart pumping and your inner racing driver revving. With stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and a career mode that puts you in the driver's seat of your dreams, it's a fantastic representation of the sport we all love. Yes, there are some pesky bugs to contend with, but like a determined driver pushing through adversity, I'm confident that the developers will fine-tune the game to deliver an even better experience.

So, my friends, get yourself a copy of F1 22, fasten your seatbelts, and prepare for a wild journey that'll have you shouting, "Banzai!" with every hairpin turn. Remember, in the world of F1, it's not just about the finish line; it's about the thrills, the spills, and the memories that last a lifetime. Happy racing, everyone!

EA have ruined it. Were you expecting anything less from EA. Don't get me wrong, the game would be a masterpiece if it weren't for game breaking bugs, glitches and design. VR is pointless because the programmers messed up the power output of the engines, so you hit a straight and lose 2 seconds off of your lap time because you can't even get into eighth gear on most tracks. 

Super aggressive ai that literally drives like you are not on the track with them. They have "patched" this and turned ai aggression down but it is still crazy. 

Too many issues to list here to be frank but you get the gist. 

The item shop is POINTLESS, unless all you want to do is buy lamp shades and rugs for your equally pointless lounge area!!! Really EA, you took away helmet and car liveries for this rubbish?

Sound issues in game that can only be fixed by disabling every last audio device attached to your PC. Yes, really. I have to disable my VR headset to have sound that isn't juttery ffs. 

Yeah the list goes on. I enjoy F1 2018 and 2020 way more than this. I'm never buying another F1 title with an EA stamp on it.

Edit:

In the run up to F1 23 launch, I thought I'd re-download this hot garbage (yes I deleted it when I made the initial review) only to find that all of the issues I left the game over are still standing. What a joke of a game. However, I am pleased I did because the timely reminder of how EA/CM have ruined this franchise settled my decision not to pre-order, or in fact even consider, F1 23. 

I learned my lesson with Activision and the COD franchise; Dead as a Dodo. I gave Activision rope and they hung me with it in the form of MW2 2022. Got my refund on that hot mess too. This is not about COD obviously but EA are doing the same with the F1 franchise now, taking away what we love about F1 games and implementing utter BS and a ton of game breaking problems and glitches. 

On top of that, I swear there is some kind of SBMM or boosting/Nerfing going on because when I play with my friends, I am clearly the fast, more experienced racer yet I get beaten 9/10 times. Why? because I have witnessed sooo many times where I'll be taking huge chunk of lap time, as I'd expect, to all of a sudden having no grip in corners for a lap or two until I lose touch with the race. Every time my fastest laps are 0.8 secs (ave) faster but I get crippled in the race at various points and it feels like it is to stop me stomping on my friends. 

Anyway, needless to say, don't buy this rubbish title and if you're smart you'll stay away from F1 23. Don't say I didn't warn you...


EDIT: Just out of curiosity I took a look at all of EA's other (sports) games released in 2022/23 and every single one of them has mixed reviews.....just another warning. Stop buying EA games!

Bought the game along with a PS4 Thrustmaster T150 wheel, best way to enjoy it. I play it whenever I have a chance. I’m glad they got rid the story driven for this version because I could care less about a story in racing games, they’re usually cheesy anyways.
Career is quite fun. I always play full 2 hour races and its cool it allows me to save midway in case I can’t finish it in one sitting. I really like the parts improvement in this game due to it being so much detailed than the usual parts in other racing games. It just lacks in the tuning department tho. The game does provide a good level of difficulty, but since as you get better parts it becomes easier, I up the level of difficulty to make races more challenging.
I do like multiplayer but I always end up creating my own race for people to join, mainly because I like to race around 15 laps with pit stops, other people’s races are always like 3 laps.
Last, game’s graphics are amazing, I hook it up to my 4K 55” TV in a mix between High and Ultra settings and it looks awesome without any slowdowns.

Interface is very difficult and controller setup and compatibility is a serious issue. Even if it works for a while, a simple reinstall can put you back in a state where windows recognizes your wheel fine. The game may even be sending things like gear selection and RPM to the on-wheel display. It just will not pick up any inputs. Windows can show all the axis and calibrations functioning fine and the game will still refuse to pick this up. It also won't let you disable other devices despite having a menu option for it. It just won't listen meaning even troubleshooting is a process of constantly plugging in and unplugging peripherals.

TL;DR: F1 22 is a good entry point for those wanting to experience certain aspects of Formula 1 in a selectively realistic space. The game is welcoming to newcomers, and despite its flaws, provides a bearable experience for those newly passionate for the series. It works well with a controller, and if I had a friend that was getting into the sport, I would tell them to snag the game on sale.

For those who are not newly passionate, the game is a shambles. Various bugs, development decisions, and blatantly incompetent physics quirks have built one of the most intolerable games in the series.

To qualify myself, since most criticism of this game is brushed off as a skill issue: I am extremely passionate for Formula 1, and have been playing the games since F1 2011. I have transitioned from console to PC, and from the controller to a full sim setup. I am consistently within the top 1-5% of the leaderboards, and love improving my skill behind the wheel.

The positives:

- F1 22 is the most beautiful game in the series, bar none. The graphics evolution took a very large step since F1 2021, and during long race stints it is quite common to look around and appreciate the work that went into the looks of the game.
- The audio is also a plus, with engine samples taken directly from the on-track cars this year. Though, the Red Bull’s engine still needs some work.
- The game, without context from the other games (especially F1 2020,) is very, very satisfying. For those who don’t mind the semi-arcade, semi-simulation “simcade” nature of the game, it provides a unique experience for those wanting to experience Formula 1 race weekends.

The negatives:

- F1 22 is plagued by bugs, server issues, and odd data errors that significantly degrade the experience. Some examples include, but by no means create an exhaustive list: 
    - Consistent server problems absolutely destroy online play, kicking players and sometimes permanently locking them out of online play. The multiplayer co-op has improved over the previous entry to the series, but the server issues and other odd quirks that impede gameplay destroy the experience.
    - Time Trial begins to be bugged for some players, and will remain bugged throughout the rest of the game’s life cycle. This leaves players without the ability to access some Time Trials, top setups, and will actively spread to other places in the game like a virus. This issue still has not been addressed, or fixed.
    - The multiplayer connection is laughable, at its best. Since the introduction of crossplay, online lobbies have been unbearable, with cars teleporting off the track, wiggling so violently that getting close to them is impossible, and a bizarre bug where any player in the lobby can tab out of the game and completely ruin the synchronization between players.
- F1 22’s physics are, at best, a lazy approach to the new era of Formula 1 machinery. Some positives have been made with the physics engine - namely, the introduction of a sharp peak when the tyres begin to slip, making “the knife’s edge” feel like one. The positives stop there. The cars are not anywhere near the handling characteristics of their real-life counterparts. These cars are allergic to any type of kerbs, save for the ones painted on the track, where their real-life counterparts sail over them due to the emphasis on ground effect with the new chassis. These cars are horrendously prone to understeer, and the term “boat” does not come close to describing the handling characteristics. Even when the cars are fully upgraded at the end of My Team or Driver Career, the cars’ understeer only worsens. Grip, oddly, seems to be connected directly to RPM, meaning shortshifting is currently the best way to drive. These problems become extreme if you have the ability to play the game above 60fps. For some reason, whatever it might be, traction loss over 60fps becomes a violent, unrecoverable spin. Kerbs, at 60fps, are generally annoying, but they become exceedingly violent and dangerous above that framerate.
- F1 22’s AI was, at launch, a step above F1 2021’s own. Somewhere along the line, though, AI meant to replicate professional racing drivers began to resort to dangerous divebombing, consistent lockups in braking zones that result in damage, and blatantly ignoring the player to the point of awkwardly pushing the player off over an extended amount of time.
- For being sponsored by FANATEC, the game not recognizing the CSL DD is quite odd. Nitpick, sure, but the game not recognizing wheelbases and other peripherals is worrying.
- The force feedback has taken a step back for controller players, and has not improved to the standard of games like Assetto Corsa, Assetto Corsa Competizione, or even rFactor and iRacing. On controller, the trigger rumbles for most controller types was removed, or was dumbed down. On the wheel, the force feedback is inconsistent, unhelpful, and most of it is noise (not generated from events the car experiences, just made to be filler for the experience.) The car has almost no force feedback on tracks like Miami, and on Portugal and Belgium, feels like the wheel noise will rip the wheel off its mounting.

At the end of it all, the game is a mess for those who want to play consistently, and at a level above sitting on your couch using every assist included in the game. The result of wherever this mismanagement of the game comes from has finally trickled down into the product, and its effects unfortunately have shown their ugly collective face. On the surface, the game looks to be well-polished, but anywhere deeper than the fresh coat of paint that is applied to the game every year in the form of features like F1 Life to desperately attract ultra-casuals, the guts of the game prove rotten with years of neglect.

F1 22 is one of the weakest titles in the F1 franchise and therefore I spent significantly less time in this years game. But what makes it worse than its predecessors? 

This years game has introduced F1 Life and supercars. Two very unnecessary additions... I've had a few hours of fun in the supercars but in the end it still feels extremely weird driving a supercar while playing an F1 game. I'd just prefer classic cars which I feel like would be way more fitting for an F1 game. But thats not everything... The handling model feels worse than in all F1 games the last couple of years. It often feels unpredictable with a lack of feel for the car and grip. The A.I. is more aggressive now and it feels like you can actually have a nice fight with them... until you are in the gravel because the A.I. either didn't see you or just didn't care that you were there. 

BUT even with all those negative aspects I still had a lot of fun in this game. No F1 game ever had this much content and there are also additions that I love because you can now choose between broadcast and immersion options. I can't tell you how much I loved the idea of driving to the grid positions myself before this game came out. And now I can just do that. 
Yes, F1 22 wasn't the greatest F1 game but you can still have a lot of fun, especially with friends. And now I'm excited to see if F1 23 makes a step in the right direction again.

Personally speaking, this is one of the first f1 games I have ever played and this review is solely created based on my personal experience. F1 22 is a  new F1 title developed by Codemasters and for the second time since published by EA since Codemasters has become a part of EA since its purchase. F1 22 offers a unique feature which has not been in the previous F1 games. Compared to F1 2015 and F1 2020 which I previously played, F1 22 allows you to drive a number of super cars around all tracks, but you are only allowed to drive the cars in time attack mode. Despite offering a unique and refreshing feature as aforementioned, you will not find any F1 classic cars as in its 2020 counterpart and any previous edition of F1 annually released, personally speaking the absence of this feature is one of the most significant flaws in the game, as the presence of the classic cars will allow players to immerse themselves fully in the F1 world. In addition to the fact mentioned earlier, F1 22 is a great game, which offers an unforgettable racing experience in which players have to prioritize the utilized strategy during the race in order to be able to come out as a victor, as in every F1 game, not to mentioned this game also includes My Team feature which will allow players to create their own team to compete in the Grand Prix of the F1 series. The AI is quite aggressive so be aware when you play the game that the AI will try to shake you off-track. Compared to F1 2021, which was the first time that the F1 game series has its own story mode, F1 22 does not have this kind of mode. The series could have been better if the developers had included the sequel to the story presented in F1 2021. F1 22 also releases new features such as F1 Live which will allow player to customize their own private space consisting of  super cars, which they can purchase in-game, using the credits earned during the race, create and customize their own preferred decoration and ornament and even place the trophies of every single Grand Prix they have already won which I find as an unnecessary addition to the series. Despite the flaws, this game is recommended for individuals who are fond of racing games.

If you're planning on playing the game with a friend and doing 2 player career then it's a good game to play together and progress through. But the overall experience of the game is very frustrating. There's quite a few bugs which can massively effect your chances of winning. And then there's the AI.... no spacial awareness, extremely aggressive and glued to the track like a train on rails. God help you if you're in the way of their racing line as you'll just get shoved out the way or piled through like you're not even there, and they take ZERO damage from it. But leave you with no wing or just totally wipe you out so you DNF. Unless you manage to get pole and escape the first lap madness you'll be frustrated every time you play the game. It's a shame because I love F1 and enjoy racing, I just hope they fix these issues for the next game.

Reviewed Edit: After another 8hrs since my last review, the AI are 100x worse. Absolute savages. Hate them.
