I'm a huge F1 fan including the games there big negatives but also positives. Starting with the POSITIVES  the graphics are beautiful and although some people complain about I like the A.I being good it makes it an actual challenge. The tracks are great and the race day gameplay is great. A small thing but the addition of music in the menu is nice and some the new mechanics are cool.

 Now for NEGATIVES . A lot of people we're concerned when ea was taking a bigger role in this game and for good reason. The classic staple of release the game early with ungodly bugs and issues "but don't worry we will just fix it" is very apparent with game. The french grand prix pit lane is so broken that the car will turn into wall early for no reason this happened four different times in a row and at one point i entered at 30kpm still didn't work properly. Don't worry because when my car did stop trying to imitate lance stroll in baku the car just missed my pit crew and reset on to the track without replacing my broken front wing (caused by the continuing wall slamming) nor my tires. Some other notable bugs the audio when booting up the game might just constantly cut in and out over and over again. Also for vr players if you're expecting something like Iracing lower your expectations its not great. There are too many compatability issues with the wheels but I've seen a lot of reviews on just those alone so check them out because there probably all valid. The sector colours don't show up. F1 life is just an excuse to get people to buy more currency because as we know ea is trustworthy and would never want to get a cash grab off of a sports game. 

All in all if you have F1 2021 and your okay with outdated designs just play that because there is nothing really new with this one and I'm being dead serious when I say that not only is this pretty much a re-skin but they straight re-used the clip of will buxton at the beginning of his intro for a new career mode. If you do not on any F1 games and want to try one I would wait a bit before they fix all the bugs then I would say try it out because it does have some upside.

This game, like many recent titles, is full of bugs and performance issues. Firstly, I have encountered an issue in which whenever I turn the "texture streaming" option to higher than "very low", the game stutters and becomes unplayable (and no, it is not my hardware limitation). Secondly, the online servers are extremely unstable and crash often enough to cause huge frustration for players. Thirdly, many people I know have complained to me about the game's performance in VR, saying that it stutters and hitches even on higher end hardware. To conclude, this game is not worth buying unless you get a huge discount on it; being full of bugs and performance issues, I can't help but wonder how long will this crapshow of badly made and incomplete games continue.

They also straight up stopped changing the daily and weekly items in the item shop. If you were to buy their currency, you won't even be able to spend more than a few bucks worth. That's how little effort they put into this. They can't even be bothered to be greedy. Absolutely pathetic entry in the F1 franchise. Little more than an interactive advertisement for clothing brands and luxury cars.

Mostly a decent game, but realism is not really present. Most of my time spent in the game is in time trial so i do have a good understanding how the physics are. I have traction control on OFF and I still have wheel spinning in 3rd gear and other issues within the game that are just to stupid to exist.

The core game in itself is fine much the same as the previous versions, a continuation with the new regulations in place, and I like the small additions in the form of manual pits stops and the option of cut scenes for formation laps etc. I enjoy it overall hence the thumbs up. If you are coming from F1 '21 though be prepared to alter your traction control if you use it as its a lot stronger this time around and makes quite the impact pulling away into straights. Knock it down a notch.

One thing though: Who the hell is F1 Life for? Seriously. If the life of an F1 driver is parking supercars in your glass house and inviting cap wearing pr!cks 'round to stare at them like idiots 24/7 then I'm not sure I'd want that life :'D

Also I "love" how they've hidden the item shop you might actually want to use (helmets etc) away in the menus but the opportunity to buy a branded EA shirt for real money to make your avatar look like an even bigger fool is front and centre. Way to prove the fan base right there EA. I hope the metrics are being followed\observed here and they dump this nonsense next iteration.

Honest Review
Bought this game on sale 85% off! Bargain.

I have recently gained a lot of interest in Formula One so I thought id try out the games on PC.

The game-play feels fine for the most, settings are critical to set right for optimal gameplay. Undeveloped cars did seem very hard to turn in, and lots of understeer but when you get along with research/dev this fixes a lot of this issue. Ive heard this SIM wise isn't nearly as good as F121 but I have not played it to compare
The sound studdering issue is very frustrating as I heavily rely on audio for gearing and braking and accelerating out of corners. There is no fix, no matter how many settings or 'fixes' are tried.
Other downsides are that the games graphics are a little behind, but ok (Ultra settings, 1440P is decent)
AI is also very 'dive bomb' at times, and I blame the devs using real life behaviour as Max and other drivers are terrible at pushing when there is no gap at all and causing damage or running drivers off the track or wall (poor sportsmanship) - sometimes they can clean overtake, but even when I drive along side and give room, AI does not.
I highly suggest playing 'my team' mode on full season 22 tracks with most of the simulation settings on. (I use TCS and ABS because I want to enjoy the game without rage quitting)
Score: 7/10

I am neutral about the game. I don't dislike it but I wouldn't recommend buying 22 unless dirt cheap.

Pros:

- Online mode is fun when you're in a lobby full of players that knows how to actually race.
- VR mode is excellent.
- Nice visuals with Ray Tracing.
- F1 and F2 cars feel great to drive on controller.

Cons:

- Career mode is a huge step back from F1 21.
- "My F1 life" is pointless and just a cheap cash in via micro transactions. You can tell EA had their grubby mits all over the game
-  Classic cars replaced by regular sports car that feels awful to drive.
- AI is inconsistent. One race, they can be dumb as a box of rocks. Next, they can be too over-aggressive such as not giving you room when taking a racing line. I can't explain how many times I've had to AI trying to "defend" when I am trying to complete a practice program and affecting my results.
- No punishment for the AI if they hit you or knock you off track. They simply drive like you're not there.
- No red/blue/black & blue flag system.
- Frustrating UI to navigate and use.

Typical EA product. Crap.

- The online matchmaking is crap. Countless times I've been dropped into a lobby that says Qualis are about to finish, so presumably I can join and start the race at the back of the grid. Nope, after sitting through the quali lap and the loading screens, the race starts and you have to spectate the entire thing and wait for the grid to get back into the lobby. And if you dare leave a session, the game punishes you by forcing you back into that same session when you try to find another lobby. Crap.

- The VR is crap. I'm surprised I haven't had a seizure yet with how shaky and glitchy it is. I can't play in VR for more than 10 minutes without a headache. Crap.

- The AI is crap. No matter the game nor the sport, leave it to EA to create AI that absolutely ruins your experience. The AI drivers are unpredictable at best, and will straight up plow you off the track at worst. I can't decide if EA's AI are worse at driving or playing hockey. Crap.

- The supercars are crap. And who asked for them? The models are unfinished and they're not even fun to drive. People buy an F1 game to drive F1 cars, not a cheap Wish version of countless other racing games. $20 says the first promotional video for F1 23 will have EA bragging about how you can drive the DHL moving trucks from one race weekend to the next. I bet you'll have to pay for it too.

AI in this game is truly laughable. While you may have to adhere to the laws of physics, they don't. Even on medium difficulty, AI are able to make passes and braking maneuvers that aren't possible as a player. On long straights, they always seem to have 50 more HP. 

Brake early in traffic to actually make the corner? AI will fly up the inside, lock up their tires, and play bumper cars. They make attempts at passing that no logical person would ever attempt. There are corners on all F1 circuit where overtaking isn't possible. This won't stop them from forcing you off the track despite never being wheel to wheel or even close to ahead in the braking zone. 

Another strange nuance is resource generation. It seems unless you increase the rate manually your team is always behind on R&D. Almost as if the AI gain them faster than you. Really makes it difficult when you want the full F1 experience and start as a back marker team. You stay as a back marker team forever without manually increasing resource generation. 

Gave this an honest try through several seasons in simulation mode while gradually upping difficulty into Hard range. This just makes it more ridiculous. You may become more comfortable driving and even get steadily quicker at each track. This doesn't matter with this games AI.

F1 2022 is a major disappointment and a step back from the previous iterations of the game. The graphics are unimpressive and lack the polish and detail that one would expect from a modern racing simulator. The gameplay is clunky and buggy, with poor AI behavior and inconsistent physics that make it difficult to enjoy the game. The sound design is also subpar, with lackluster engine sounds and uninspired track ambience.

Moreover, the game has been criticized for its lack of content and customization options, with a limited selection of cars, tracks, and game modes. The career mode is dull and repetitive, with little depth or replay value, and the multiplayer experience is marred by frequent connection issues and unbalanced matchmaking.

Written By ChatGPT, But I Agree With Every Single Word.

I regret purchasing F1 22 on Steam. The game is practically unplayable due to its network issues. Trying to conduct league races with friends has become a nightmare, as the game consistently drops connection and crashes. It's a real shame because I was excited to dive into the new features and updated graphics, but they're overshadowed by the game's insufferable network problems. I cannot recommend this game to anyone until the developers fix these issues. Hoping F1 23 will be better than ever or else RIP to this game.

Ever since EA took over the project, the game has turned into absolute horse shit. It was felt right from F1 2021 with the desyncs in the beginning which were stabilised by the end of its life cycle, but oh boy were we in for a treat with this atrocity of a game. Launch day issues which locked people, who shelled out DOUBLE the cost of the Standard Edition, for the Champions Edition, out of the game, desync issues which have been plaguing the game right from launch until today, broken AI, force feedback issues for pad (which are STILL prevalent), and these incompetent losers in the development side are releasing patches to FIX THE EYE COLOR of freaking Kevin Magnussen.
EA has proven through this game that they are here just to loot this passionate community off their hard earned money and make a mockery out of the love we have for this game. But I will not fall for this trap any more. And I urge whoever is reading this review to not fall for the temptation of buying this yearly cash grab that this game has been turned into by the company voted to be THE WORST COMPANY IN AMERICA multiple times.

As a racing enthusiast and a fan of the Formula One series, I have to say that F1 22 is hands down the best racing game I have played in recent years. From the moment you launch the game, the attention to detail is astounding. The graphics are stunning and the attention to detail in the tracks, cars, and weather conditions is simply remarkable.

The gameplay itself is top-notch, providing a true-to-life racing experience that puts you right in the driver's seat. The controls are responsive and intuitive, allowing you to push your car to the limit and make split-second decisions that can make or break your race.

What I particularly appreciate about F1 22 is the level of customization it offers. You can fine-tune your car to your heart's content, tweaking everything from the engine performance to the tire pressure. This level of customization adds an extra layer of depth to the game, allowing you to tailor your driving experience to your preferences.

The multiplayer mode is also a standout feature, with seamless matchmaking and a vibrant online community. Racing against real people adds an extra level of excitement to the game, and the competitive nature of online play is sure to keep you coming back for more.

Overall, I would highly recommend F1 22 to anyone who loves racing games, or anyone looking for a challenging and immersive gaming experience. The attention to detail, stunning graphics, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for any Formula One fan.

F1® 22 is a racing game, but not just any type. F1 is not just a game, it could be life. I recently got into F1 thanks to this game and the history and feel that this entire franchise gives is immense. I am so grateful and also sad that I got to witness this at the age of 17 and would like to have discovered this when I was younger. F1® 22 as a game could be a little bit broken at times but the general feel and atmosphere is delightful but the players in online mode needs IQ compensation. Playing solo is more enjoyable than playing solo in most games and Codemasters have a more friendly dynamic feel than most other sweaty racing games. Seek the enjoyment that I had witnessed and you will be much happier in life. Awesome game.

Bought the game on a big discount and it's great! Drives well, graphics look awesome - I don't understand why this has mixed reviews from people putting in hundreds of hours into the game and then leaving negative reviews along the lines of "it's the worst game ever" - if it's so bad how masochistic are you to then have hundreds of hours of it?

Went and watched Lando Norris and the Quadrant guys on YouTube and they've got dozens of "We had our own <country name> grand prix" and they looked like they had fun, no-one was complaining about bugs/gameplay/handling. Figured they wouldn't make those videos with something that's unplayable, so gave it the ol' 2 hour try and it's great! There's lots of settings to customise difficulty, including AI on a big sliding scale, and you can reasonably quickly find your level of difficulty and desired challenge.

There are some things that do annoy - F1 Life, super cars and PitCoin transactions - but they're easily skipped/ignored and you can just move into career mode/time trials/whatever floats your boat. There's enough challenge there to keep you coming back for more.

So yes, recommended to get this when it is on a big discount

F1 22 is a great addition to Codemaster's F1 Games. But...


EA.
The influence of EA is clear in the games, with the addition of F1 LIFE and Supercars, soundtracks, and a very "EA" menu. Microtransactions come in the form of PitCoin. But moving on to the gameplay itself, that's where I really like this game.

The graphics are spot on, nice shadows and backgrounds. Unlike any other game, there isn't a blurry image found if you look closely into the background, instead, the scenery remains clean as ever. However, the car itself looks too animated in my opinion.

The gameplay has drastically changed due to 2022's new regulations and cars. As soon as you start driving, you can feel how understeery and heavy the new cars are, and the devs did an amazing job of implementing that.

F1 LIFE feels a bit unnecessary, and I don't think F1 fans were expecting that, including me. I was hoping for a new feature for racing itself. MyTeam and Career are pretty much the same other than department events and starting points. I haven't tried VR yet.

Overall, with new tracks and menus, F1 22 seems like a definete improvement and fun to play, just like F1 2021. However, nothing drastic has changed, and I think people were wanting a big change. I would reccommend to those who want to have new cars and have fun with updated content, but those who only want to spend money on a huge and rebuilt game, wait for a sale.

The handling is quite different from previous installments which is the major reason for the bad ratings, it is a lot stiffer and takes a while to get used to. Personally after tweaking the handling saturation and linearity settings it doesn't feel that bad anymore, but again I'm not the one who tries to set lap world records or something.


The additional My Life stuff though seems typical EA crap, could have been implemented well like say Test Drive Unlimited did in the past but it's pointless here. Same with the supercar hotlap stuff which is obviously half assed and feels like a mobile game feature. Haven't faced any major bugs yet except one- the menu overlay gets stuck if you change some graphics settings which may require force closing the game.

TL;DR -- even though VR's not super well-done in this game -- it makes the game so worth it, I'm wow'd beyond what I dared hoped possible with this IP, even slightly buggy as it is.

-------------------

It's a little crashy, (like 1/3 chance of having SteamVR crash and disconnect the HMD until game-restart when coming out of a Flashback,) which is frustrating... but  VR... VR!!!  For me it is the ONLY way to play this game.  (Even though yeah, the implementation of VR here is buggy, a bit jittery, and feels like an afterthought.  The ability to see the track with both eyes, judge distances and apexes, glance at the VR wheel to see what gear you're in, and with a decent force-feedback wheel feel when the tires start to break away from the pavement when you push things just a bit too hard... wow. I was very meh about f1 21... but after logging 10 VR hours in F1 22, I'm hooked on the whole thing and am super hopeful that for F1 23 that VR gets the proper treatment it deserves.

I haven't played a lot of simulators, but this game is the most realistic that I have ever experienced. The amount of details that affect the game is huuge; The tyre's pressure, the height of the floor, the pressure on the wings and etc. 

Also, it is a lot of fun to play and go through the tracks where the real f1 championships take place. I started to watch the real f1 races with more interest and deeper understanding and because of the game I became able to recognize the tracks on different videos in a few seconds and it gives me chills. 

However, the game is not without the issues. I have different cases with bugs that really annoys the gaming process. For example the issue with tyres; sometimes the tyre compound that you have chosen before the pit stop doesn't want to change, the game instead gives you the compound that it wanted itself. Another issue with the right compounds is that sometimes the game doesn't give you an access to dry compounds even though there is no rain on the track. You can fix it if its the single company by just rebooting the game, but if it's an online cooperative, you just need to put up with it and carry on playing. Also, I had a case where Ricciardo with McLaren didn't start after the green lights and the safety car wasn't going out at all. I had a case where I couldn't change the crazy recommended strategy with like 5 pit stops. 

Also, I didn't understand why they took out the opportunity to control the fuel compound during the race as it was in f1 20.

However, I would still recomend the game, especially for those who love real f1.

PROS:

CONS:

If you like the previous F1 games, you'll like F1 22. If you were expecting something new, though, you'll be extremely disappointed. That's because its the same exact game.  Everything is basically copy pasted from old game with different car models and different graphics and colors. F1 life is something new sure, but who tf actually cares. It's more for EA to charge you for cosmetics than something that anyone likes. 

What I was really hoping for that could actually make this game a lot better was VR support. While VR works, there are a lot of game crashes that occur with high graphics settings. I know I could probably just lower all my graphics settings to the minimum, but this shouldn't be a thing for a game this big backed by a company so big. Don't come at me with "your pc s***" because I have a 3080 and i9 intel cpu, 32 gb ram, and a lot of storage on an nvme ssd. And yes I made sure my drivers were always up to date. 

One thing that was actually good about this game was cross play compatibility. I didn't play on it much so I cannot attest to  its reliability but it exists. I only have 28 hours on this game, but that's because I had over 700 hours on F1 2021 and wanted more out of this game. I am writing this review after a long period of not playing so the game crashes might be fixed, but I doubt it after reading other reviews.

Overall F1 is a good game to play if you really enjoy F1, but it really sucks when the same game keeps getting released and you have to pay $60 every year for nothing new. Please fix current issues and add something new like co-op my team. Something that wouldn't take too much work for you guys. Come on EA, please. I promise I'll buy more cosmetics :)

Well, it doesn't surprise me that Codemasters managed to get this game down to mixed reviews. This is the first Codemasters F1 game I am not recommending in my entire life. There is a lot of work needed for Codemasters to do to make F1 23 a product worth buying. I am not keeping my hopes up though considering EA's reputation of ruining content of gamestudios they acquire.

I'll start with the positive features. The warm-up lap is the best feature they've added in the game. It feels more immersive and allow you to properly warm your tires for the start. The pitstop overhaul also makes me feel in control of the process more. Besides that the co-op career feature is also fantastic if you play with friends. 

Unfortunately the cons are too many for me to recommend this product. Let's start with the features that should never have been in the first place. F1 life is absolutely atrocious and a ploy to enable more microtransaction sales. This smells like EA all over it. If I want to simulate the life of a rich douche I can play GTA online and have way more fun out of it. The supercar addition was also simply bad. They handle way worse than F1 cars in a hotlap and aren't even available for a race. If I want to race in a supercar I can play Assetto Corsa and have way more fun out of it. Classic cars were a great formula. I can't see why they would deviate from this.

AI behaviour was never excellent in F1 games, but it seems way worse than previous installments. The straight line speed of AI is way too quick for some reason. Especially with DRS being less powerfull it is very hard to keep up with AI on straights. Overtake manouvres from AI are downright suicidal. They block space when you're side by side and the risk of being punted is always there. Control of the car has vastly deteriorated. Even with diff on 50% it is way too easy for wheelspin to kick in. It has gone to the point where I hardly can finish a long race without spinning when traction control is off.
The penalty system also needs a major overhaul especially on multiplayer. I have gotten brake checked multiple times by drivers because they couldn't hold me off. They never get a penalty for it. Then again I am suicidal for joining open lobbies in the first place.

I wish I could say that this will get better, but you and I know it not to be true. In the meanwhile I suggest you buy F1 2021 or 2020 if you want a good F1 arcade experience (unless you are primarily interested in multiplayer/co-op). And since F1 23 is announced remember this gentlemen: no pre-orders.

So conclusion if you LOVE the f1 branche and want too play with the New era cars, sure go ahead and buy this. If you want a nice game: f1 2020 or assetto corsa with mods. This new entry into the F1 series I would rate as the worst by some margin. At this point in time I have every version of F1 from 2012 to 2022 each one has been their version of the champions edition including the fabled F1 2013 with classic cars and tracks. While each version usually improves upon its predecessor either in improved gameplay, graphics, ai etc with some titles having a dip in some areas to allow the improvement. This title has gone for the if it broke lets make it look all glossy, if its got something that needs fixing lets make it look glossy and oh lets spend needless time and money adding in F1 life as a utterly utterly pointless way of making it interesting. This is a racing game or is supposed to be, as part of a series you should be able to use your racing experience gained from one game and apply it to the new game, I struggle to see how buying a sofa is in anyway part of this experience!!! I wish I could tick that little box to say I received the item for free, unfortunately  I did actually pay for it in the sale at a massive reduction after playing it for on a free steam weekend. I have in the past preordered my F1 series games and was delighted and very lucky to be a tester on F1 2020 (I feel that was the last true F1 game in the codies series).

I have played F1 2018, 2021, 2022. 
2022 is extremely bloated with features nobody who is into racing is interested in (furniture, ambience, lifestyle...).
At the same time, it is very buggy, seemingly no longer maintained. The online experience - the great feature which is strongly advertised - is often frustrating. The servers are at their limits, lagging while having a strong internet connection. Getting times confused during races, get stuck before entering the lobby, after entering the lobby and during races. Very taxing! The fun factor goes down the drain with all these frustrating imperfections of the game. 2018 is the only F1 game that was/is fun and mostly working just fine. Very sad indeed. Can the developers not just go back to the basic needs of a true racing game and, what is even more important, keep improving it by fixing imperfections and providing regular updates. To me, this game was rushed out, cashed in for and forgotten. I expect the next games in this series to be at least as sloppily coded and maintained as the curent version. Racers, be aware: do not invest a cent in this one and be super cautious with the sequels!

Back in October 2022 I bought this game because it supported VR - I was getting good performance from my i7/GTX1080/Quest2 in other games such as Assetto/Project Cars 3 / Dirt Rally 2 and RaceRoom.

After two hours I assumed that the GTX1080 was just not up to the job even though I was getting 60-70 fps in everything else I could not manage anything more than 35fps with low settings which made F1 22 unplayable.

Fast forward five months and after an upgrade to an RTX 2080ti (where the performance of the other games jumped to 80-100 fps with high/ultra settings) I noticed this was on sale with an 84% discount - well, long story short its a turd of a game for anyone not running the very latest kit - I could barely get 48 fps and the shocking head movement performance is stuttery and not what I expected.

Even though it was only £7.99 I requested a refund - but the bots at Steam (I don't think they have any real people) decided that as the total play time for the game was over their 2 hours the refund was refused - so warning, unless you have 3080/3090/4080/4090 if you want to run this in VR forget it.

Its a pity as the graphical look and feel of the static stuff is really nice - although I cannot understand why in VR the cut scenes are on a flat screen that you site 10" from......its VR guys !

Not to big into f1 driving games but I thought I'd give it a burl at it's reduced price to check out the VR.
The VR is great. Super smooth with no hiccups, which is what I would expect from codemasters as they implemented VR in Dirt Rally 1 & 2 really well, perhaps the only Triple A dev team to achieve this in any game so far(there are other great VR games but rarely made well by larger studios).
On top of that, it works perfectly with my fanatec DD pro. But the game only really accels when combined with my DIY sim using simtools. With the extra movement and feedback (2dof with traction loss) the game really comes into it's own & is quite the experience.

Now I'm sure there are questionable features (f1 life, etc) but I tend to ignore such things and just go for the experience & for me at least, the game is very good.

If you have a setup like mine, your golden. The experience on a monitor and game pad might not be so hot, I have no reason to try it :P

Understeer on entry, oversteer on exit.

[h1] My Honest Opinion [/h1]

[b] LETS GET TO THE GOOD PART FIRST [b]
Graphics are amazing everything looks beautiful and so does the car. I would Recommend this game if you are either New to F1 Games or still using assists in throughout F1 BUT ONLY WHEN IT IS ON SALE. The Main Menu Looks amazing and easier to access everything so easily which is great. It is still a racing games you can still have fun alone or with your friends and you can always be faster with every step you take or lap you race. Career modes are still good however there are not much changes ever since the previous title but still good im okay with that


The Bad and the UGLY


This game is really not a fun game for those who have been playing without Traction Control for their years in playing F1. Its easier to spin in slow corners or slow to medium corners and sometimes you its very hard to predict if you are going to loose your rear wheels from that slight difference in racing line or throttle based on the last lap or other laps you have been doing. BTW if you want to be faster, just turn on assists you be more consistent and slow corners dont scare you 

AI Is a Nightmare 
they are still fast in straights and exits, VERY aggressive and yet superbly dumb if they face a problem in front of them and you will never ever be on their level if you ever try to follow their exit speed (closest you can do if you have assist). If you want to play co-op with your friends then you better even lower the AI difficulty as they maybe slow in the corners but you are fighting a straight line speed of 10 level difficulty ahead from the difficulty you choose for the AI 

Online Play
Yeah ...nah dont even bother..... just dont Bugs and everything

EA Play
Yeah you are not going to touch it. Its more like dipping your toes in the water on swimming pool that is only 1cm deep. Its just  THERE WHAT CAN YOU EVEN DO?!?!

Ouh and the Music? 70% of the songs are weird (not to my taste) or just so bad 


Conclusion :
Veterans stay away if you have not bought this game or sim hardcore fans the Bugs alongside the traction in this game are not worth your money and time 

New or returning Players it is fine for you to try out this game as long as you do not try online features so early in the game and immerse yourself into the F1 Game as long as you could handle the Bugs or ruthless AI

[h1]The EA Curse has struck once again[/h1]

When Codemasters was first bought by EA back in February of 2021, people were worried and rightly so.
EA is a company known to prioritise profits over enjoyment of the game. As long as you give them your money, they don't care whether you enjoy the game or not. And now, we have the first game that has been fully developed until the EA umbrella, and it's terrible.

[b]F1 Life[/b]

EA had to add some way to make money using in-game purchases, so they impulsively added F1 life, where you can decorate your own apartment, own super-cars and live the life of a f1 driver when they're not racing. Conveniently enough, you could also buy all of these accessories and supercars using pitcoins, which you can buy on the store. 

Why are there even supercars in a Formula 1 game in the first place, I bought this game to race with Formula 1 cars, not supercars. It is also strange how you removed classic cars, which was one of my favourite features in F1 2020. CODEMASTERS PLEASE ADD BACK CLASSIC CARS

[b]Handling[/b]

The handling of the cars are so unrealistic. Even real formula 1 drivers say that using medium traction control is more realistic to real life than without traction control. Every time you get on the throttle in the lower gears, it's like playing a game of cat and mouse. Are you going to spin or not? Before the patch some time ago, the handling was much better and true to real life, as it wasn't as easy to spin out but now we have to go into fifth gear just to not get wheelspin. COME ON GUYS.

[b]Bugs & Not listening to their community[/b]

Every year, somehow Codemasters makes the same game every year more buggier than the one before. Before EA came into the picture, F1 2020 had beta testing, where avid f1 fans could test out the games for bugs before its public release. However, EA does not do beta tests therefore the game was only given to influencers and esports drivers before release! This resulted in the game being very buggy on release. The AI had some ridiculous straight-line speed which made competing in career mode almost impossible especially in later seasons. Tyre allocation for medium tyres was broken as well, fps affects physics. The colour of the red bull was not even accurate, and there was a prominent audio bug. These issues did not take a few weeks to patch either, these took multiple months. And even their 'patches' had their side affects, as they had to change the handling to fix the AI's speed.

[b]Other issues[/b]

[list]
[*] Codemasters recycles the same game every single year, and only minor changes are added every year (Sometimes they remove features!). The game is getting pricer every year, yet we are getting less features, great.
[*] The Racing isn't fun anymore. The AI on this years game is stupider than it's ever been. Online is still a wreckfest and more than it's ever been. Slipstream and DRS aren't strong enough, so it's harder to overtake on the straights.
[*] Cheating in esports is starting to become more prominent because of the lack of anticheat.
[*] VR is terrible, and they should've focused on other features. They even had the audacity to ask the community to nominate it for VR game of the year, and considering the comments on that post it didn't go down too well.
[*] On release, Steam users who preordered the game couldn't even play the game until 18 hours after the preorder was meant to open up.
[/list]

I wanted to love this game, I preordered it ASAP, and I was avidly watching all of the videos on the game. I had high hopes, and I thought this game would be great. My disappointment was immeasurable and my day was ruined when I saw F1 Life and the bugs. This game is not worth the £69.99 I paid for it on release. Yeah sure, it may be worth £5 but it's the same game every year, and I'm getting bored and sick of it. The only way to make codemasters and ea change is to not buy the game, which is what I'll be doing until the series noticeably improves. 

If you want a good codemasters f1 game, buy 2020/2021 or find f1 2013 somewhere else, you'll thank me later.

I rarely wright (edit: drunken mis-spellings will be preserved) a review after a short playtime, but this struck me so hard in the fact I just wanna say something. As a top-tier nostalgia(fguy), who holds games like Wipeout, Nascar Thunder, Need for Speed 3, and Rollcage 2 as an untouchable ideal (mistakenly, and foolishly), I have to say this...

Use a wheel. Turn up the volume. Run a race or two. Watch the replay. Understand F1 prior to doing so.

This blows all that nostalgia BS out of the water. All these people whining about glitches don't even understand how good this is, but you have to use a wheel. No controller. Just my opinion, the force feedback and wheel is what makes the F1 2022 experience. I use a G920, cheap Logitech wheel I got secondhand for 80 bucks or something. Worth it. Without it, the controller experience is just not how this is meant to be played imo.

I've played a few sims... Automobilista2, Asseto Corsa, Rfactor2, Asseto Competitione, Dirt 2...Gt7?

This might not be a perfect sim of F1 cars in the current year, but IDK... the pure exhileration of the driving experience feels futuristic to me. Feels almost faster and more heart-pumping than something like Wipeout Remastered or whatever... the entire package you get in this (10 dollar on sale right now) game is actually mindblowing. It's FUN. It's a FUN game that FEELS fast, has incredible replay and general immersion features (announcers, EA style sports game features, etc) and just makes the whole thing amazing. Is it perfect, is it a 400 IQ simulation... no...

I love it. I truly wish EA had the rights to the NASCAR games. Imagine not feeling that way. Seriously.

Pointless bloat wrapped around a mediocre racing experience.

Game force opens an EA login in a browser every time you open the game or return to the main menu, even if you only ever want to play single player modes offline.

On first open, the game immediately makes you pick a supercar, despite this being a FORMULA ONE game.

Then it drops you into F1 Life, which is a load of pointless wankery. I'm here to race cars, not design a house.

There's a long, unskippable cut-scene when you start career mode. I watched the entire 2022 season, I don't need it hyped/explained again.

When you finally make it onto the track, the cars handle like absolute garbage. Changing assist settings does absolutely nothing to fix this. Changing car setup does not help either; now you're on ice skates, but slower. Maybe it would be better with a wheel but, considering this game has a supposedly "casual" mode, it should work properly with a controller.

I'm going back to an older F1 game, because this is no fun at all.

not even going to mention the bugs because i cannot believe how they keep coming. a game that has generally been the same gameplay with the same physics parameters from 2019 can be broken more and more every year. its an achievement honestly. in relation to the physics, the car handles like a fidget spinner no matter what kind of setup i try and no matter how gentle i am on the throttle. i am sure even though there has been a huge technical / regulation change, the car does not feel like this in real life -- drivers have said in the past that the cars have way more grip in real life than what it has in the game. there's so much more that i don't even remember from the top of my head because this game has really brought me and my friends more suffering than joy

also, don't get me started on the blatant removal of GOOD and almost ESSENTIAL FEATURES from the game, like showing the delta time from previous lap to the current and the simple "Join Game" option to let me join my friends' multiplayer lobbies on the Steam overlay. removing these and Braking Point (something that had a lot of potential tbh), fine, but what the f*** even is F1 Life?? how is that at all related to F1?? can you please spend the time developing all these bs to actually improving the game?

in conclusion, me and my friends never had a simulation game where i can be so frustrated within 10 minutes of gameplay, and further considering the fact that there wasn't much changes in the concept of the game since 5 years ago. if this review blows up and those reading that are considering to buy this game, PLEASE do not. PLEASE buy F1 2021 (i would say 2019 and 2020 as well, because they were genuinely good games WITH, i must emphasise, CLASSIC CARS as well; BUT EA has sneakily removed all of the older games from the Steam store).

Here's an immediate TL;DR: It's F1, you drive fast. The AI is..fine-ish, the handling doesn't feel as good as 2020 (to me at least, on controller,) but it might be better to you. Maybe check out 2021 or 2020 if you can, and maybe try to get one of those two if you don't care about the online public races aspect too much.

The good, though: 
* It is fun to hop in and go nyoom with funni Formula cars
* The graphics are pretty decent, maybe not ground-breaking, but they suit a modern game.
* Soundtrack is pretty solid, it's a vibe. 
* There are lots of settings you can change, so if you're like me and suck at games and don't want to mald because you're being rekt by AI- you can make it so that the AI are basically just high-speed obstacles at worst.
* This doesn't require Origin to play, unlike other EA titles.
*(I guess this is a technical positive) Due to the fact this is obviously the most recent release, there are more lobbies to get into. Just stay in lobbies with ghosting enabled, you will be PIT-maneuvered every other turn otherwise.

The bad:
* The AI, on various difficulties, can sometimes make only "artificial " fitting in A.I. By this, I mean they can make very dangerous/dumb moves against a player. Though you could argue that's just called racing, I call it a flashback moment (to a certain extent.)
* The FIA. Okay so maybe I should elaborate- there are times where the game may falsely register an illegal move or contact (should said rules be enabled,) and has happened to me a couple of times. Not the worst thing, but it can happen.
*Public racing lobbies are not that great, even if they are more active. But that's just general online racing outside of more "sim-racer"-esk communities, I think. Also, it sort of feels awkward with a lot of waiting just trying to actually get into the race, let alone getting into a race and it being so outlandishly jank. In short on this point: I feel like I could find better lobbies for games from 2010 and have an easier, and more fun time playing with whoever I end up with on there.

The..Neutral?:
* The handling. When I wrote my original version of this review, it was based on my experience of having only played this one particular F1 game. Having played F1 2020 now, my take on this is that there is more of a grippy feel (..with full-trac-control), but that it also feels like there's less control- like it is more on-rails than 2020. In 2020 for example, you can take a corner (at least as I perceive it, I'm no game journalist, much less a fully credible reviewer) at a much higher speed, and as long as you can steer appropriately into the turn, you come out mostly unscathed. In this game, you take that same concept- and you will absolutely run off the course if you're going a few kmph too fast. Now, somehow the reverse is true on just medium traction control, where it feels like you can counter-steer loss of traction in 2020, but here you start a spin- and it ends a 180, or 360, no argument to be had. Unfortunately I cannot speak on no traction control as I have very little experience with it (much less in this game, unsurprisingly.)
* The ability to customize a personal penthouse..or whatever. It acts as a showroom for your supercars at most, and is maybe or maybe not new to this game (this part I have not looked into) but it exists. It would be cool if there didn't seem to be clear issues with the game which could've had more focus put onto that, but on the other hand, maybe those got through the crack of testing entirely.
*AI are more likely to make mistakes/take worse lines. While for the most part this counts as a good thing, as battling AI in 2020 becomes a bit of a waiting game on when you can get to a straight, probably with DRS, and make a very basic pass, here AI feel more human-like, they make mistakes. Or at least certainly more noticeable ones that you can capitalize on. Though, they can happen too often according to some people. I'm a bit biased in that the handling in this game compared to 2020 is its own challenge so..eh, I can't complain.

Personally, I don't know if I would suggest buying this game for over..maybe USD$35.
And even that may be a good bit much.

Best Codemasters F1 game to date, physics-wise. Only thing keeping it from being a GREAT F1 game is that it lacks other modes. Does not have classic cars nor a story campaign like the one in F1 21, which was actually very good in my opinion - story was something that kept me moving forward, but it was the challenge that kept me highly motivated.

I see that F122 has middling reviews, but I don't think it's warranted. The meat and potatoes of the series - the Career mode, as always is still intact, and it's the main game mode for most gamers like myself. 

Controller feedback is amazing. The way the rumble and haptic triggers work (on both Xbox Series and Dual Sense) is supremely well done - you can feel your car reacting to various surfaces. Probably the best implementation of controller feedback in any racing game till date.

These games are always pretty good, this one included. I rated it down not because the game itself is bad. It isn't. It's fun. Then something between the game and Steam VR pukes and it freeze. And before any of you hard ware trolls, I rock a 3080, so it's not my set up. 

That aside, this game is fun, I just wish the VR worked smoother. Maybe allow Open VR? or Oculus VR? do not' force Steam VR? Not sure if that would make it better or not. I just notices that my other Racing titles that use anything BUT Steam VR fair better. 

A last minor gripe. It's an F1 game. Let it be that. I don't need a story mode, I don't need super cars (those are  handled  a million times better in ACC, RF2 etc). The last newest F1 game I've played was F1 2019. The handling of the cars with a controller is very different, but at the same time, exactly the same. It's pretty atrocious, really. If you want to turn in a corner, you have to start turning almost a good second earlier and if you start the turning earlier than would have been needed to, you are basically fecked. You try to ease up on that analogue just a tiny little but, but no, the steering wheel gets as straight as you can imagine, almost immediately.
I could dig up my grandma who has been dead for 7 years, sit her in my non power steering street car, that is stationary, and she could turn the wheel faster, than the ingame steering is with a controller. I can not believe what kind of fecking higher up business man is sitting at Codemasters (and now EA), who thinks to himself "yeah, this is it, this is the best we can do, perfect game, ready for sale". People have been complaining for this exact same issue for YEARS now and it's still not fixed. What's the point of ANY racing game, where the cars are impossible to handle? Nothing. You can add all the cool sports cars, the luxury mansion and all the clothes to customize. If the core element of the game is driving and it does not feel good to drive, than it's just a bad game.

Had to refund. Pit stop QE is just a joke, instead of making proper pit stopping they do quick event. Whats next? Licences, people actually miss old F1 challenges (I do not), but I enjoyed (yes kinda bad opinion) breaking point or the story parts of campaign. Instead of shorter version of tracks, historic cars, story mode, they added licensed supercars, stupid t shirts for your characters (LICENSED - Puma etc.) and EA TRAX !! WTF ? At the start I was excited to finally play the game. Now I just play it because it's fun while I drive those 30 minutes before it crashes.

I started off with disappointment when the game had a release delay, but when I got to play it I had no trouble with racing. Except when the AI drivers drove through me and threw me into the walls on Jeddah and Bahrain.

I was on vacation for a while and when I came back i couldn't even start the game. I had to literally reset my entire PC to only get into the game. When I first started playing it again, I could only play it for 30 minutes before it crashed. I have had that problem since, and it's the most frustrating when I get a perfect practice session, and when I am in the pits again, it crashes and the practice session has to be done all over again.

So now I'm just playing because I love the high speed drives and because I paid almost $80 for this game. I really hope EA fixes all these tiny frustrating bugs and all these big frustrating fucking game-crashes.

So I've been playing the codemasters F1 series since the '17 release and I've had a lot of fun.  Each year there were upgrades to every aspect of the game.  Whether it was in the car handling or the AI, you always had something to look forward to and be rewarded for when codemasters made a new F1 game.  Codemasters somewhat understood that F1 fans wanted to drive a decently realistic recreation of the F1 cars and get a little taste of what life would be like if you were a driver in the sport.  There were updates each year that made the game feel fresh and new, like classic F1 cars.  This all changed when EA bought codemasters.  EA destroys everything they touch, and this is just another franchise they killed.  The game is unfinished even now with game breaking bugs, and a 'VR' mode that will give you a seizure if you dare look anywhere else other than forwards.  When it was first was announced, I was in denial.  I wanted this game to be great.  There were a lot of promises made about the changes to gameplay and career mode, but when I downloaded the game I got F1 21 with couches and a broken VR mechanic.  Instead of classic cars, we got supercars that EA didn't even care to finish the interior models on, and oh they make you pay for all of them but one.  Somehow the supercars feel worse than the F1 cars too, driven them feels like they copied a need-for-speed car and slapped it into the game.  Classic EA story, guy into a sport/entertainment franchise they don't understand (or care to understand) and try and make you pay as much money as possible for day 1 promises that you thought were going to be included with the base game.  This review is only scratching the surface of the game too.  But I've seen enough of this game so far that I know it cannot be fixed, nor are they going to try to fix it, and I believe the game series is now doomed.  Too bad all the 'drive to survive' fans are going to eat this up as a 'fun game' because 'netflix docco exciting'.  Just stick to watching the actual races and dreaming what it would be like cause this crap ain't it.

This is by far the worst title of the series. 
I've put about 70 hrs in, 20 in career, 50 hrs in online-racing and from that 50 hrs probably 45 hrs was waiting for lobbies, getting kicked out by the game servers, lobby's being bugged - it is an absolute nightmare. And that is just the lobby-search. It cost hours  and nerves of my life I will never get back, I screamed and shouted at this game more times than I can count and I'd say Im a pretty patient person.

The gameplay itself feels horrid. Unrealistic car-behaviour, it doesn't feel like a single-seater at all (i'd recommend iRacing... but even Mario Kart feels more realistic at this point in time). 
AI is just (no matter the AI strenght, Im playing on 90-110 mostly but it happens at 30 as well) faster than you on straights, doesn't matter if you DRS open or you're draining the battery, the AI will beat you on every straight in this game, so you gotta accept it. With that being bad enough, the AI has absolutely unrealistic amounts of grips accelerating out of corners and turns where it's just impossible to keep up in 80% of the races - the 20% where you can keep up it's either cutting corners and turning into you in turns to take you out or even with corner cutting, youre just not quick enough.

Career mode is more than lackluster, but hey, we got a playerhousing mode which no one that cares for a racing-game experience was asking or hoping for and it is exactly one thing - completely useless.

I regret spending any money at all at this game, which can be understood as the underlining of EA games - An absolute failure with the solemn goal to make money and not providing a good experience for players.

0/10 if possible, absolutely horrendous.

Terrible, the game has been devolving since 2020. So, lets see whats wrong
Career mode,
The AI is broken. The developers couldnt be bothered to train decent AI so they just gave them extra grip. This means that they are quicker out of corners which give them a significant advantage over the player, but the AI's are so terrible that even though they literally have cheats, they still need help to battle players, so the developers gave them insane straight line speed. Even with the fastest car you will struggle to keep up with the AI on the straights. Besides that there is nothing. Career mode hasnt been changed at all since 2020, its just gone backwards.
Multiplayer
Its as bad as its ever been, public lobbies are full of crash prone kids that just want to make you miserable. But the servers have gotten worse since last game. So its not exactly the same. Multiplayer has the same bugs as last game, like freezing lobbies and lagging cars.
Physics
With the new regulations the game's physics model had to change. Had to, but they didnt change it at all. They just gave the cars less front end grip to simulate real life. You can test this out by messing around with the ride height of the car. Changing ride height doesnt affect downforce, despite the fact that the new regulations make the car generate the majority of their downforce by making the car sit low to the ground so ground effect can generate downforce. In game its not like that.

To sum it up: The game is bad. The developers dont change anything and the game just keeps getting worse. I mean seriously how can you mess up something you dont change? The game has been the same for the past 7 years(I'm not kidding you can check the game's files, the folders containing the teams are still dated back to several years. Alpine=renault, Aston=Force india ect) Really unfortunate that the devs exploit our love for F1, they know we will buy whatever dogshit they put in front of us. Because we love F1. Its sad...

In my opinion, and to what I have seen and heard of big content creators and esporters. This game is not good. Not even close. Its first of all, not realistic at all. And yes, its not advertised as a racing sim. Its an arcade after all. But there is a big difference between an F1 arcade and a handling model that is garbage on a next level. This game made long time esporters quit the game because its so bad. Secondly, there are so many stupid bugs. And its missing too many features. There is not option to turn off certain penalties, there is no anti-cheat system, there are no consequences for deliberately crashing into people in online races, there are no classic cars, no option to do reverse track layout races or alternate layouts. And the features it does have are just boring. No one cares about F1 life, no one cares about sports cars, especially not if you buy the game because you want to drive F1 cars. Its literally in the games name. No one wants to drive sport cars, especially not if the handling is even further off than the F1 cars themselves. The game has just been going downhill since EA took over. EA is literally the killer of games. They are too busy with greed, just make a good game for once. And no one cares if that means that there will only be a new game every 3 years or so. Just add updates and cosmetic stuff and you will make the money that way. Keeping a playerbase happy is more important than cashing in every year. And about the playerbase, listen to them for once. You're getting plenty of feedback, even from esporters. And its like you are all ignoring it completely. Create a team dedicated to finding out what the players want and then actually implement it into the game. I would not recommend this game to anyone. The little shitty features it has, are not worth the pricetag. Please EA, take your time for a game for once.

If you're a follower of the franchise, you're going to buy it anyways, but as a game, F1 22 doesn't really add up that much on top of F1 2021, funny enough, F1 2020 was better than 2021 too, as an F1 game of course.

I said "as an F1 game of course" because F1 franchise pretty much became FIFA. You're going to buy the new game one way or another because that'll be the one everybody's playing as soon as it comes out. It's just in sports games' nature. F1 22 adds things like F1 Life, where you customize your driver's lifestyle with supercars, house decorations, licensed clothing etc. but for an F1 game, these really don't add anything. I'd much prefer the classic F1 cars and the invitation events with them from the older games over any supercars in the game right now. I mean, supercars are not bad, but there are only a few of them anyways and pretty much the only thing they add into the game is the Pirelli Hot Lap challenges for the career mode, which you mostly skip because they're fun for like 3 challenges and become instantly repetitive, challenging and boring in the same time somehow after that. I honestly do them just for the funding of my fantasy BMW M F1 team.

As for the My Team car customization, it's still really fruitless. They should just leave the paid skin system in the history and switch to the free livery editor system much like every other game with cars in it right now. I mean, it's EA. We're going to have paid customization one way or another but don't limit such an important customization aspect of the game behind it. Players should be able to create their one off liveries with free shapes, patterns and characters. Right now, every My Team/Multiplayer car looks like one another and all of them looks like sh*t. Not only that, but also the fake sponsors look like sh*t either. At least make better logos and choose better names for the fantasy sponsors in the game. Maybe even add "sponsor decal requirements" for the My Team mode. More than that, we can really use a free sponsor logo placement either. No matter how many sponsors you put on the car, it always looks dull, empty, like an F4 car.

All and all, I'm giving it a positive review because if you're playing F1, play the latest one. It's not unplayable, it just can be much better. It's worth a try as it's in the EA Play program now. Just don't expect the AI to drive sensibly.

I wish i can leave more of a mixed review instead of recommend or not recommend but this is the best i can do.

Lets start with the negatives. F1 Life is probably the dumbest thing EA could have added to the game and everyone seems to agree that it doesn't add anything nor is it even fun to interact with. Super cars are cool and all but no one asked for them and you cant even race them against friends online. The only time that you can even use them is in time trail or the pirelli tire challenges that also dont really do anything outside of career modes. On top of theses features there have been plenty of bugs and glitches that make it difficult to even join multiplayer lobbies and leagues. For example, at the games launch my friends and I ran into an issue where the mail would not even load so you couldn't accept invites to leagues or even coop games. Then there is the AI, though this is more a minor gripe. The AI can be very aggressive and sometimes just go side by side with you and each other for multiple corners and on top of that, diving bombing you when there is no need. For the most part I do think the AI is a step up from what it was in 2020 and 2021. Something I would really love to see for F1 23 is an improved replay and spectator system. If you download a replay from a league race or an online race you can not switch your view to another persons view. This is absolutely aggravating because if you wanted to see what some else in the game is doing so you can figure what you can do to do better you can't simply look at what they're doing to learn what you maybe doing wrong. However, you can switch to other perspectives when it's singleplayer or career mode replays which doesn't really help anyone. The customization is lacking and hasn't really changed at all in the last few games. Yes they did add the ability to change the type of finish on the car but players have been wanting similar to GT7 or Forza levels of customization. Also EA, please bring back classic cars and tracks.

Now in terms of positives there really isn't too much. Most of the singleplayer modes that you're probably familiar with such as, My Team and the normal Driver Career modes, Grand Prix and Time Trial. The game adds the Miami track and as well as the changes made to the Abu Dhabi track that were made in the 2021 season that were never fixed in the 2021 game. The cars themselves feel pretty good to drive overall and do feel different from F1 2021. Racing wheel to wheel with friends is just as fun as ever and even battling the AI can be quite the challenge at times. The setups can be adjusted more than 2021 with the wings be the most notable change, being able to go from 0 to 50 on the wings.

As a whole package, F1 22 is ok at best and is still probably your best bet if you are looking for a modern F1 experience as whole. Assetto Corsa may have better physics and may even feel better to drive, but out of the box it doesn't have all the cars, teams, drivers, rules, single and coop career modes, and (after some patches) easy to setup lobbies to race against friends. I would recommend getting this game but ONLY on a sale.

This game is fun for both Pros and those who wants to entertain themselves. The assists can provide good gaming experience for those who wants to experience what it's like to drive the worlds fastest cars. For those who wants to play competitively they will need to turn off assists but will achive astonishing speed if they master driving with all assists off.

My average game play starting in F1 2012 onward has been about 30-50 hours per game. F1 2022 I've done 6 hours, if that tells you anything.

I LOVE the VR support. It's fantastic but, the competitive racing aspect is garbage. The NPC racers are way out of whack and they haven't bothered to try to fix it or patch it at all. Incredibly disappointed. 

The difficulty of the AI racers does not scale lineally. It will go from way easy to very hard and somehow back to easier again as you scale up the difficulty. The speeds of the AI in the straights is completely unrealistic. Garbage. garbage. garbage. This single-handedly ruined this game.
it's good, but over recent years they've spent too much time adding gimics to career mode instead of enhancing the actual gameplay

The game in it's current state is quite simply - unplayable. I don't recommend anyone buying right now, even if it would be a special deal. For all the casual players and the ones that don't want to sweat too much - the automatic gears have been completely messed up, which causes you to spin out of every acceleration zone and you are loosing up a second or even more per lap. The car simply won't change from 7th to 8th gear. The AI will blast past you on the straight like racing a jet plane against a propellor plane. Absolutely mad. Bugs everywhere. Disqualifications, deleted laps, simulated laps that are 20 seconds faster than you. It's really a shame considering this rant is coming from someone like me who had always defended codemasters in the past, but this game is seriously lawsuit worthy. Comparable to the early days from cyperbunk. Keep in mind I've spent 60 Euros on this mess! 60 Euros is a lot for everyone, but imagine someone younger spending all his pocket money on this game, just to utterly disappointed and be confronted by such a shitshow. Shame on Codemasters and EA. I won't even mention EA in this rant, because everybody knows that EA is one of the worst companies to ever hit the videogame market. 
I will update this if the future patches change anything, until then seriously don't buy this game!

Edit: 1st of September
After various patches, bug fixes and updates the game is now somehow playable. Still not perfect, but compared to the state when I wrote my review it's a million times better. SO I kinda recommend playing the game now, but there will still be bugs.

Edit: March 2023

It's really hard to recommend a game like this with the glaring issues it has. 

First and foremost, cars feel absolutely horrible. The traction model is one of the worst I've ever experienced: grip is non existent which leads to cars not feeling realistic at all, which multiple F1 and actual drivers agree on. Touching a kerb is almost suicidal. The cars always feel like they are on the verge of spinning, it's really hard to actually try and be on the limit when you cannot consistently rely on the feel of the car, which means you will find yourself in a constant struggle for grip, mainly because of the traction model, but also because of the tire model. 

Secondly, the lack of good FFB makes it even harder to feel and judge the grip of car, which subsequently means you can't be on the limit as consistently as you would like to, but I have already addressed that. FFB feels more like wheel-centering than actual FFB, and the lack of laser scanned tracks probably doesn't help either, which in itself is also another problem, but I personally don't mind hand-modelled tracks as much as the lack of proper FFB.

Last but not least, the amount of issues I have faced in the co-op career mode cannot be numbered using our current numerical system. Game doesn't feel like joining the host, getting stuck in loading screens, getting randomly disconnected, etc.

With all of that being said, I cannot deny that I have had a lot of fun in offline career mode whenever everything goes smoothly. The AI is pretty good, attacks well, defends fairly aggressively, is competitive and fast, overall really good in my opinion. You can definitely have good races. Graphics are also pretty good, and ray tracing adds a nice touch that, in all truth, you will never notice when driving.

I'm not even mentioning the fact that classic cars were removed and instead we now have F1 life and useless sofas that nobody wanted, alongside supercars that nobody ever drives, and can't even race in, but I still feel like the cons (excluding the aforementioned) outweight the pros, mainly because offline is the only way I could make any enjoyment out of this game, since public lobbies are catastrophic, as per tradition.

In conclusion, the game is not immersive at all and the only way to actually recommend it is on sale, and barely so.

Based on playing this mostly with a Simucube 2 Pro + Goodies like Buttkicker and HF8 haptic pad.

Handling is quite decent and "interesting" ONLY with the right custom profile in the Simucube 2 "True Drive Paddock" app... but handling of a top tier formula car still feels better in any other proper sim (rFactor 2, Automobilista 2, RaceRoom, etc.). Now, every single time I load this game, it insists that I have changed my Simucube bindings before I have a chance to progress to the first interactable screen... I can cancel out those phantom changes without it screwing up my presets, so its not a deal breaker, but it is concerning, and it is annoying.

BUT THEN when I finally get into the game and switch rightwards, over to the only real mode of value: Time Trial... I have to pass by the Championship campaign tab, which always informs me of the exact same initial F1 Life garbage earnings... as in the very first earnings/unlocks from when I first fired up the game... and there are other, frequent minor waiting moments for the game to connect to servers, because this game is infested with a season/battle pass for garbage cosmetics. The pass, and the need to constantly be online to verify and "reward" you for grinding around the pass... this basically bloats up the game and slows down the loading process of every "next screen". Basically the micro/pass and F1 Life are 100% responsible for your time being wasted via loading delays and other clicking-away of absolutely useless notifications.

And the telemetry is STILL backwards. Codemasters still haven't figured out how to allow their games to communicate with multiple telemetry based apps... so if you have Simhub running a custom dashboard display and you're expecting to use a Buttkicker via the Buttkicker app? The Buttkicker will not receive any data at all. Want to use a Buttkicker with the Next Level HF8 pad at the same time? Only one of those devices will work properly with their respective "official" settings apps... but don't worry, because the HF8 app is unstable and F1 22 is not supported yet anyway... and if you have a collection of proper sim racing hardware, you need to do the following: use Simhub for everything.

Simhub is an awesome and superior piece of software, and you can actually setup your Buttkicker, HF8, and whatever other custom arduino devices within Simhub... and even though F1 22 may not have intended to support a number of these devices, you can force it to do so with Simhub grabbing ALL the telemetry data coming out of the game, and gives you FULL access to how/what/where to assign it, if you really want to get into the guts of that sort of thing.

Having said that... the haptic feedback that ultimately comes from F1 22 through the Buttkicker and HF8 is... good, They definitely do the job in giving you a grounded connection to the track and your car... but those haptic bits of data, on the exact same setttings/values/activations inside Simhub, do not feel as refined or "real" as they do in any of the following: rFactor 2, AM2, ACC. I'm not saying the haptics feel cheap and nasty... but it does reinforce that Codemasters make Simcade games. I imagine there is a specific sweet spot in tweaking every single haptic assignment to make this feel amazing... but you won't care because the amount of effort and enjoyment is tainted by the "EA effect" (cheap AI, F1 Life, etc.)


I have also tried this with my old Occulus Rift and it kind of feels... the opposite of immersive. It actually felt like a disadvantage.

And as others have mentioned, the AI is psychotic. Here though, I would suggest this is a genuine "sim" dose of reality based on the current era of F1. Pro drivers racing like they're kids in go-karts, smashing into each other? AUTHENTIC! Earn yourself a harsh penalty for a collision or "something" that was perpetrated by an AI racer, meanwhile Hamilton goes on to win the race because of an unfair power and "ignoring the rules" advantage that goes unpunished? AUTHENTIC!

The only thing missing is Hamilton having a cry on camera about being the biggest pariah in motorsports when he gets caught doing something blatantly aggressive AND dangerous, and has to take a minor penalty.

I am still trying to give this some good runs every now and then with my Simucube 2 setup for the sake of time trials on these pretty, official tracks... but it does not scratch that open wheeler itch quite as well as other games. Even community made historic AND modern F1 mods for rFactor 2 feel profoundly more satisfying and predictable to drive... but the graphics here are pretty, and the track accuracy is superb.

Another thing worth noting is that F1 22 is a bit of an anomaly in the current transition to EA. If you started playing from a client/install from the EA app, the Steam version is a completely different cloud-save platform... so it's just as disconnected and not-crossplay-friendly as trying to carry over progress from an Xbox or Playstation. And unlike every other recent EA published game I have tried, this one does NOT force you to install and use the EA launcher, so it loads and plays like a proper, Steam-only game client, which is an important detail to know if you ever plan on installing this onto a Linux machine (like a Steamdeck) where you don't want to mess around with additional 3rd party DRM launcher beyond Steam to be able "allowed" to access your game.

It also seems like Codemasters games are starting to move into a strange world of confused market appeal, and F1 22 is a perfect example... built for gamepads? Absolutely! Anyone with a proper wheel wanting to drive with little to no assists on, you can expect an extremely unpleasant and unforgiving experience unless you tweak your settings JUST right... and even then when you can get the game feeling good, it still feels WAY off the mark when compared to racing the same F1 tier type vehicles using your exact same wheel setup in a proper sim (AM2, rF2, etc.)


All in all, a loud and proud statement of the future of Codemasters and the F1 franchise in the EA Sports portolio.

This game is not good. 

These games just have not been good for a long time now. Garbage AI, awful handling physics, trash online functionality. These things have been in all the F1 games I can remember playing. Codemasters promised fixes for all of these things, but almost a year into the game it just hasn't happened. The AI flip flops between being a wet noodle and being the most overly aggressive thing known to man. It took codemasters ages to fix the straight line speed of AI that was present at launch, but we're still left with an AI that is just not rewarding in the slightest to race against. The physics are a complete fraud. If you watch F1, you get a bit of an idea of what driving these cars is like. I'm not saying you'll know exactly how, but you get an idea. This game just does not match that in the slightest. I can see drivers are able to exit corners at basically 100% throttle in second gear while still maintaining grip. That's not possible in this game. You must gradually apply throttle in no lower than 4th gear to prevent violent spins. Drivers who have played the game have complained about this, and yet it has never been addressed. Beyond this, in general it just feels like you are driving the cars on ice, especially on the hard tires. Downforce physics are not calculated accurately at all. I've had problems with multiplayer since launch. I'm rarely able to just join quick matches, I always get errors. As for ranked, the only lobbies that ever fill up are 5 lap races, which are completely pointless. Matchmaking for medium length races is not working correctly, it puts you in a lobby and waits for it to fill, but it never does. 

Today, codemasters announced F1 23. I will not be buying it at launch. Until I can see with my own eyes that the physics have been completely overhauled and brought in line with industry standards, I can not justify what will likely become another $70 game that ships severely broken at launch and hardly improves throughout its life cycle. 

To conclude, don't buy this game unless it is severely discounted or you can get it for free/on ea play. It never has been, and now never will be, worth $60.

If I want to be honest, then this game sucks. The game was better at launch with the good handling and general player-base being happier with everything then than they are now. The changes to the handling in patch 1.06 was devastating to the players, as they made the game so much harder to get traction out of corners, kerb behaviour was worsened and the game was completely different, resetting the learning all the players had done to this point. This game is not and will never be a bang for the buck game as it is far to expensive for it's own good. But if all you want to do is create a career in the world of Formula 1 then I would recommend this game. If not, well there is no reason to buy this. There are many issues with this game, such as 
1) Not being able to swap from Pre-sport update liveries to current sport liveries without mods 
2) You can overtake car's under the Safety Car period (Online and Offline)
3) Formation laps are completely bugged, as referred to in Jarno Opmeer's 2 Player Career with Binham
4) Track limits in Time Trial is mixed with some corners giving that you completely cut, while gaining time not giving you a invalidation, while others give you a double invalidation.

 Online is completely busted with cars glitching all over the place even with perfect connections, general lobby instability issues and many other issue that I know I have not experienced yet.

In short, this game is not worth getting unless you want a good career mode

The core mechanics of the game aren't bad, but they missed just about every opportunity to make this game fun and interesting beyond just driving a car around.

Livery customisation is terrible, I can't even find how to change my player name (so I'm just "Player One" on all leaderboards etc), I have to manually change car setup every time I play every track because it won't let you pick a custom default, qualifying is the most boring part of the game and has none of the excitement you see on TV, when you put AI difficulty down then they just break super early into corners so you end up rear ending them, and AI CONSTANTLY block you in FP/qualy and never seem to get any penalties - I've had someone park it on the apex in Silverstone straight after coming out the pits, right on the racing line so I have to break hard and ruin my lap.

The "Life" thing is the most brain dead out of touch thing I've ever seen. Who on earth wants to play an F1 game to unlock a sofa?!

There's so many quick wins they can do in next year's game - I won't be buying another F1 title until they prove it's not just another copy paste money grab.

One huge wish is that they make the race engineer actually useful, giving you updates on the rest of the field, egging you on, giving you actual tips about the laps you're putting in etc. 

Just overall a pretty boring game with no bells or whistles that anyone cares about.
