no i deffo wouldnt not reccomend this game over previous ones. Its as if its made by people who dont watch F1 but play alot of Need for Speed lol (yes, i know) because the AI is still stupid as it gets out the way but sometimes not till the last second, usually in the braking zones lol.  they try to over take, but usually dont care where you are and end up with damage, you try to over take on a circuit like jedda on a high speed part and , yup your gonna get squashed into a wall.  According to this game F1 engineers are the most stupid engineers in the world, its shocking how much stuff fails quality control for you to waste more silly resource points to wait another few races to finally get them. It has silly pointless decisions to make which are meant to shape how your team grown but all it really does in reality is, either give you 10 per cent discount on something or a few hundred more resource points, which you wouldn't need in the first place if things didn't quality control so often lol seriously F1 teams, have you engineers even got any qualifications. lol  Then there is the music some of it is pretty good some of it is just weird noises but you can switch it off or just selected songs so its not too bad. its all stuff you would find in a very loud trendy place at night with lots of drunks teenagers lol.  Then there is the engineers on the radio during races, still as useless as ever, only giving you info that is already on the screen like your 5 seconds ahead, yes i no i can see it in massive numbers in the corner. Or in my game i am driving for Aston Martin, yes i just like the car but we all know its a rubbish team, this is where its a kick in the balls, i managed to get the car to a reasonable position of around top tenish  and i was told by radio engineer that it was useless and hopefully we can do better next time lol.   Way to motivate me.  its as if they only done radio stuff for the front teams and couldn't be bothered with the rest so when you do get a good placement with a back team your still told you done a crap job and hopefully next week will be better. its shocking  ALSO (lol) my engine was about 77% screwed going in to the Spanish GP i thought i would chance it lol, it lasted just about to the end of the race but for the last  10 races there was smoke, and i mean alot of white smoke coming from the back of the car like a destruction derby car lol. This wouldn't be allowed in real like, Either stewards would tell you to get your arse off the track or your team would call you in or the car would actually break down not drive at 200mph for another 10 laps lol.  Also speaking of stewards, its still the same as games from years ago, the AI do not get penalties of any kind.  they crash in to you and you get a warning,  they are obsessed with racing lines and no matter what you do you get in trouble so it ends up being super caution all the time coz you end up being scared of the un predictable and unrealistic actions of others.  

Anyway ive only been on it for 4 hours and ive came from f1 2020, i have played 21 on game pass on xbox but didnt see much of a difference in that to get it on pc here.  It was 20 quid so thought i would give it a go. as you can tell, im having a great time. lol

EDIT UPDATE:::  Just had another race, red bulll ring, safety car came out, was near the front, soft tires went on, the back markers didnt go in which were alphas  and williams and a macca, so when the race continued it was a race, how ever when everyone pitted it didnt register the back markers as a lap behind so my self russel and max was battling away for about 7th or something and half a minute off the lead because of the glitch of the game not relaising after the safety car had ended the back markers were a lap behind, They all went in the pits for hard tires etc and came out still at the front lol, it is a shambles of a game.  
Also the AI is now offically the most aggressive of any racing game i have played, its bonkers how many crashes there were. 
Also the year where merc finally wasnt at the front, well guess what, lewis is still at the front lol yet on alot of the races up untill near the end of the races they were only just in the top 10 lol. its like a copy and paste on certain parts of the game and the things that needed changing they didnt do and it looks like they spend most of their time messing with the menus and making the RnD screens more mixed up. what happened to the day where it was all on one screen? now its spread over loads of screens and not really utilising screen space, text is still small and lots of empty space.  if it aint broke dont try and fix it EA and if it is dont copy and past from NFS lol
Also its got for some reasons a racing mode which isnt F1 cars as if the devs are determined to make us play need for speed lol. you have to use these silly tokens to unlock super cars and then race them, it also forces this in your face even before you get to see a f1 car, its stupid, irrelevant and pointless. WE WANT F1! lol
Game files are from years ago too there is nothing much new. shiny new graphics and some different handling models but everything else is just edited and not from new, which considering how expensive these games are is a complete insult to us all.  They should update this for those of us who has bought a half arsed f1 experience with our hard earned money instead of giving free gifts like helmets and decals for them or what ever else lol.

HOWEVER and this is a major HOWEVER... when you upgrade your team mates equipment so they can do better in the simulator etc it adds stats to their stats and if you have someone like Shumacher then his stats go basically 100 on everything and an awful lot of laps by him are fastest laps of the race...  my team has the most upgraded car out of all teams and am always battling at the front but MS is always about 10 seconds up the road at least, even damaged him during a sprint race LOL so he would have to pit and start last... I chose to pickup F1 a little later at the 20$ sale because I heard how bad it was… the game itself is pretty nice although the handling model changed I’m not completely against it, but there is a lot of bad lol.

Pros
- Cars feel good (I use no assists)
- Crossplay
- Game Crashing less abundant
- VR ig

Cons
- AI is absolutely a shit show, the AI blasts away on starts no matter the difficulty. AI is very good on straights as well, this was supposed to be fixed but it’s still going on in career mode.
- AI is aggressive which can be good if the devs didn't take it too far, the AI will do things so bad I wouldn't even expect it from the average open lobby pleb. Completely throw away my race.
- F1 life is the biggest letdown of all time. The only thing that would’ve been good about it is if we could drive the super cars online… but that’s not even a thing.
- Bugs… so many bugs. Bugs will make you retire races but it’s never the same thing.
- The penalty system in open lobbies still a shit show.

I’d say pick it up if it’s on some big sale like I did. But at it’s listed 79.99 (CAD) I cannot recommend this to anyone. It really is as bad as they say. The single player experience is just horrid, if I didn’t do league racing I'd completely not play this at all.

1.	Content:
Das Spiel hat leider im Vergleich zum Vorgänger keine Neuerung bezüglich dem Spielspaß gebracht. F1-Life ist größtenteils nutzlos und verschwendete Entwicklungszeit. Die Supercars sind zwar eine nette Neuerung sind aber sehr schlecht zu fahren und wären besser durch die Wiedereinführung von Classic-Cars (siehe F12020 zb) ersetzt worden.
2.	Fahrphysik
In der Fahrphysik ist positiv hervorzuheben, dass sich die Autos deutlich weniger untersteuernder fahren als in 2021. Ebenfalls verlieren die Autos nicht komplett aus dem nichts in Hochgeschwindigkeitskurven das Heck. Ein starker Negativpunkt ist die fehlende Traktion, die sich besonders beim Rennstart auswirkt. Ohne Fahrhilfen ist es nahezu unmöglich mit der KI zu konkurrieren. Vergleichbar ist die Traktion in Trockenbedingungen ungefähr mit Nassbedingungen in F12020. Auch mit der neuen Generation an Autos ist dieser Grip nicht ausreichend und mindert den Spielspaß deutlich.
3.	KI
Die KI ist im generell sehr (oft auch über das Limit hinaus) aggressiv. In manchen Kurven hat der Spieler keine Daseinsberechtigung und wird von der KI einfach ignoriert. Resultat die KI kann munter weiterfahren und das Rennen des Spielers ist kaputt. Jede Strecke hat Kurven wo das zutrifft mit Extrembeispiel Imola. Dort kann der Spieler nicht überholen, ohne entweder schon auf der Geraden zu überholen oder von der KI abgeschossen zu werden. Ein Positionskampf mit mehr als 2 Autos ist ebenfalls kaum möglich ohne dass zumindest ein Auto im Kies steckt. Muss die KI von der Ideallinie abweichen ist das oftmals zu viel für sie und sie macht Fehler die bei einem Wheel-to-Wheel battle in einem wheelbanging enden (wobei wie erwähnt die KI nichts spürt). Weiters ist die Schwierigkeit der KI noch schlimmer als bei früheren Ablegern sehr schwankend. Wo man auf manchen Strecken um Siege fährt, kann man auf anderen Strecken auf der gleichen Schwierigkeit hoffen nicht letzter zu werden. Die Reifentemperatursimulation ist nur etwas für Masochisten. Die KI hat diese einfach nicht und so ist man zu Beginn des Stints zu langsam weil die Temperaturen zu niedrig und während des Stints zu hoch sind. Positiv ist herauszuheben dass sich die KI bei blauen Flaggen und im Qualifying meist deutlich besser verhält wie zum Ende von F12021. Sie bremsen nicht mehr die ganze Zeit um dich vorbeizulassen, wobei du sie vorbeilassen möchtest.
4.	Bugs
Das Spiel leidet leider mehr als jedes andere Vorgängerspiel an Bugs. Es sind jedoch keine kleinen Bugs die einen schmunzeln lassen, sondern Bugs die einem komplett den Spielspaß nehmen. Zweispielerkarrieren werden zerstört durch das falsche Implementieren von Sprintrennen oder gleichem Wetter in jeder Saison. Ersteres macht die Karriere wirklich kaputt, da der zweite Spieler in jedem Rennen disqualifiziert wird. Weitere kleinere Bugs wie das Neustarten des Spiels um einer Lobby joinen zu können nerven zwar sehr sind aber noch überschaubar.
Fazit:
Das Spiel kann an einem guten Tag sehr viel Spaß machen. Jedoch ist der Frustfaktor deutlich höher als in F12021, da sehr gute Erlebnisse einhergehen mit sehr schlechten.
Tips:
Wenn noch nicht angewöhnt fahren mit mittlerer Traktionskontrolle und immer viel Zeit für ein Rennen einplanen.

First of all I love this series since I played F1 2005 and every sequel after that. I want to enjoy this year's version too, but as it is now it's not worth it. To be honest, after EA bought Codemasters I thought there were good and new features, but my dreams were way off the mark. A feature brought back from old games but kept very minimal is that you have to actively press 1 or 2 more buttons during the pit stop. In 2010 the pit lane QTEs were much better. F1 21 was a very good game and I can't understand how they managed to screw up F1 22 so much.

The bad thing about this game:
- The AI ​​is way too aggressive. They drive right into you, either from behind or from the side. They're a lot worse than last year. They often destroy your car or cause it to spin.
- The risk of penalties for the AI ​​is far too small if not non-existent, making it unrealistic, especially when it's their fault.
- In my personal opinion, the graphics are generally worse than last year.
- The characters in the game should look more realistic.
- There are far too many bugs and glitches in this game that won't be fixed
- There are no updates for the game, only the podium pass always has a new season, but nothing more.
- F1 Live is a superfluous feature that you don't have to worry about.
- You lose interest very quickly
- Same game as F1 2021 only worse and some "new" little things.

The good points of the game:
- I like the new menu and background, although this is part of F1 Live and redundant, it still looks better than the basic menu over the years.
- Damage is much better visually and also more realistic when it comes to how to get it. Underbody damage can now occur when driving over high curbs. That's great.


It's sad to see how this game has gotten a lot worse (and more expensive).
I can only recommend the game conditionally, even if it is disappointing. In my opinion there is a lot of room for improvement, but nothing will change. Collectors and fans will still buy it.
The purchase price is way too high, so if you want to buy it, I recommend waiting for the next sale.

Unfortunately I have to give the game a thumbs down, although as a fan I wouldn't. The series deserves better.

I bought this game primarily for VR but now, many hours of fiddling later, I still wasn't able to run it properly. I work as a firmware engineer so I know my way around HW and SW configuration. FPS being in the 10-20FPS range. 16GB intel system, 3070RTX. A quick Google search revealed that there are loads of people who experience the same issue.

VR aside, the menu system is buggy. I ended up in a situation in which it was impossible to leave the video settings menu.

I am sure that, at least for VR racing, there are products more worthwhile of your money.

I bought this game to enhance my love of, and experience of 'F1 RACING'.  (I am not going to dwell in the horrible AI, complete lack of attention by EA/Codemasters to dealing with on-going, game-degrading bugs - take a look at the comments for a massive, detailed list of those issues.)  

Instead of serious attention to the quality of the RACING experience, we got a SIMS house we can decorate and a 'Demolition Derby'.  If the time and development costs for these silly, nonsensical additions had been put into making a top quality F1 sim, I am sure that F2 22 would be one of the best racing games available.  Unfortunately, that is not the case.  

I also race Assetto Corsa.  The driving experience is infinitely better than F1 22.  The mods and upgrades allowed me to race the new cars, teams and tracks at the start of the F1 22 season rather than waiting until it was half over to get an up-to-date version.  

I will not be purchasing F1 23 unless I see a serious switch from a polyglot, silly mess to a serious, well supported, fully F1 race orientated simulation.

Best Game!

Great in single-player, shocking in online multiplayer, ultimately a disappointing addition to the series.

Single player I've done a career, it's good fun, you can find yourself generating storylines as you go, but a lot of people (myself included) will pick this up for the multiplayer gameplay.

The game itself is a blocker to having a race online. Quite often I'll look for a race and find broken lobbies that are perpetually stuck in race results, empty lobbies and the functionality for jumping into a race is often so poor that you'll continually be connected to the same broken lobby over and over. Ranked races, you'll rarely find one.

If you do get into a race, there's often a bit of a lottery as to whether you'll spawn as a car or a spectator, and I've waited 15 minutes for a race to finish, joined the next lobby, selected a driver and found myself stuck as a spectator again, which is a huge waste of time.

As for the actual races, should you find one? Woefully inconsistent to the point of being negligently developed for such a big-name title. Safety cars are bugged to the point where less-sporting players are able to advance through the field behind a safety car, without punishment (by either ping abusing, or taking advantage of the horrendously inconsistent collision system, barging you off the track and claiming your place without warning or time penalty.) I've had numerous circumstances where I am driving behind someone and they have started to judder and warp left, right, forwards and backwards without ghosting. I've been binned into a side fence numerous times as a result of poor netcode, not even driver negligence.

Even if you manage to find a lobby, even if you manage to connect and get in-game and even if you get a good launch off at lights out, some b***end in an AM will still pull a Kvyat and wipe you out. The community and playerbase really doesn't help itself in terms of making online racing bearable. The amount of people who will escalate a little bit of elbows or accidental contact in Lap 1 into a torpedo/divebomb moment Lap 2 is unreal.

When you get a good race (once in a blue moon, where there's no idiots on the server), this game is utterly golden and shines. There is few experiences in gaming that I've had that are better than side-by-side with someone for turn after turn, really battling. But unfortunately, there is a huge amount of patience and time required to find those experiences.

As a huge GT fan who is completely focused on GT3 and VR when it comes to racing, this is the first part of the Codemasters F1 series i have ever tried and honestly, i was struggeling if i should even get it after EA took over. Before i start with the review, i‘d like to be clear about the fact that i‘m only interested in private multiplayer sessions with a few of my RL friends and that i‘m running a realy good PC for the time beeing. Also i haven‘t played the game too much so far. So pls take my statements about performance and the overall review with a grain of salt.

Since i’m a pure VR player when it comes to racing or flight sims, one thing i was primarily worried about were the reports about the horrible VR performance. My secondary concern were the reports about the bug of pedals not working when being plugged in via USB separately from the wheel base. Well, i‘m happy to say that these issues have been fixed so far. My VR performance (HP Reverb G2) is great and my pedals do perfectly work with F1 22. However, the game does have pros and cons as well as some bugs wich should be named. I will start with the cons / bugs i have experienced and will then move to the pros. Again, keep in mind i‘m only doing private MP and can‘t tell much about SP playability nor will i ever make use of that F1 Life nonsense.

Cons:

- The price. 60€ is simply way too much for a racing game, wich is more or less nothing more than a upgraded DLC of F1 2021. Yes, a few new totally worthless features like F1 Life, new cars, VR support and as i‘ve read, more polished physics and tyre model. People may argue that this is just how it is, but since several research studies have prooven that cutting the price in half triples the sales for PC-/Video-games, taking 60€ for a game like this is just stupid.

- User Interface. Why in gods holy name do we have no mouse support? Even in VR, this is annoying like hell. We‘re in the 21st century and there are still devs beeing too lazy to implement mouse support in a PC version of a game. This may be ok for console players, but for PC this an absolute no-go.

- Pit Stops. I do understand that F1 22 is not a hardcore sim like ACC or iRacing, but the automatic pit stops are totally arcade, making the manual pit limiter pretty much useless. At least an option to switch between automatic and manual pit lane control, like we have in AMS2, would be great.

- F1 Life. Although i won‘t ever make use of it, this is propably the biggest gripe i have with F1 22. Not only that it is close to scam trying to grab more money from customers by offering stupid nonsense items via mtx, it also eats a lot of development resources wich results in we‘re not getting mouse support, lots of bugs in the release version, missing realism options (automatic pit lane control) etc, etc. This clearly shows where EAs priorities are. Not in offering a great game, but ripping off their customers.

- VR accessability. While the graphics and the performance in VR is realy nice, the fact that i have to recenter my VR headset each time i enter the cockpit is very annoying. Jumping into the cockpit in the box -> recenter VR headset. Then open the car setup and get back into the cockpit, the headset is out of center and needs again to be recentered. Then starting the race, again recenter VR headset. Every other VR game or game with VR support i own is doing this better. And i realy do have a few of them.(edit: fixed)

-AI balancing. While the behavior of the AI is acceptable / good overall, they still seem to be slightly OP on the straights and pretty slow in the corners. Even while this is said to be a lot better now than it was after release. This will most likely be enhanced with future patches and is nothing i‘m too worried about.

Pros:

- VR immersion. This is just amazing. Besides the VR headset needs to be recentered each time entering the cockpit, Codemasters realy did a great job implementing VR. Graphics (set on high for me, 100% Steam SS, running a 12th gen i9, 64GB DDR5 and RTX3090) and performance are great. Not a average system in 2022 so again, take that with a grain of salt. But for me it is absolutely stunning. Nothing more to say here.

- Sounds. These are also very good imo. I like the option to switch between TV and driver layout, making the car sound like they do during a F1 TV broadcast or having them sound like they do for the driver itself, including wind sounds and different engine sound due to the different position and wearing a helmet compared to a TV camera. I also like the option to choose the language of the engineer radio separately to the language of the game and the broadcast narrator. I do have the narrator set to my native language (german in my case) and the radio voice to english. This highly enhances the immersion. Good idea, i realy like this option. Well done!

- General AI behavior. Besides the bots beeing slightly OP on the straights and UP in the corners, as mentioned under cons, the overall AI behavior is realy good. They fight for positions, defend and also doing mistakes on the track and with the strategy. This resulting in great races and a lot of fun during the sessions. I haven’t played too much yet, but so far me and my friends already had great times racing against each other together with AI on the track. They are sometimes a bit too agressive for openwheelers imo, but nothing to realy worry about.

- Graphics. I’m not too focused about graphics in general and there are definately games with better graphics, as well as the diffence to F1 2021 isn’t that huge, but imo the graphics of F1 22 are top notch in the racing genre. In 2D the graphics are great but, as already mentioned, also stunning in VR. The VR graphics are definately better than with ACC and at least on par with AMS2, if not better. The image is crisp and the steering wheel display is perfectly readable without leaning forward, making the HUD completely obsolete in VR. I have deactivated the complete HUD wich also adds a lot of immersion.

- Option to create your own online MP league. This is genius IMO, especially when you´re doing private MP. This option allows you set up a MP championship with (almost) all of the settings you have access to in a SP championship. Number of races, race length, flag rules, AI strength... whatever you wish to adjust.

- Physics and tyre model. Even while F1 22 is not a hardcore racing sim, the tyre model is great. I do not have a comparison tbh, but it feels accurate and realistic. Same for the driving physics. Without driving aids, controlling the cars is realy a challenge and exactly what i would expect from a F1 car, not having traction control nor anti-lock brakes. Realy good.

- Accessability. While the game is a real challenge without any driving aids, you can also make it almost arcade and therefore making it easy to enter for beginners. Overall you can say that F1 22 is easy to learn, but hard to master. Definately a better entry for beginners than the hardcore sims. These are difficult to learn and extremely hard to master for beginners, even with driving aids activated.

So overall F1 22 is a good racing game and a perfect mix of simulation and game, providing amazing Formula 1 action and great fun, especially together with some friends. If you are looking for a hardcore sim without compromise, F1 22 is not for you. But for those who want to have a semi-simulation as i would call it, F1 22 is highly recommended imo. The price is definately debatable, but once it is on sale for like 50% off, it is definately worth the money. Just one thing about that F1 Life nonsense. DO NOT BUY ANYTHING THERE. We customers do have power. If EA does not get enough money out of it, they will hopefully skip this bs next year and instead focus on the realy important part: racing!

As a fan of the franchise, it is a great game. With the new era of cars, I can understand the issues some users are having with car control, but if you already know how to navigate previous F1 games without any assists, you will not have any issues and catch on rather quickly.

However... the penalty system could use a bit of work. Outside of bogus penalties as a result of other users on-track, Codemasters seems to be hit-or-miss with track limits. At times, I question whether Codemasters understands the concept of track limits. 

Additionally, I cannot speak for everybody, but the super cars seem to have been a miss. Generally, it seems that most of us would rather have previous generations of cars back in the game for use in local and online play.

Always loved the F1 games since Codemasters did them.  This latest is very much more of the same, a few extra bits here and there but nothing earth shattering.  The ability to drive a handful of super cars is interesting and i understand what they are trying to do but its perhaps best avoided in future.  The ability to have your own custom area is ok but not really that much choice of customisation and its pretty pointless.  Like that you can do the formation lap for added realism. If you've got the last F1 game and aren't too fussed about the up to date teams and drivers, its not really a must have.  If however you like playing online or want the up to date stuff, its well worth it.

I didn't realize this was going to be boat simulator 2022

The handling model is worse than ever before. The cars are heavy, slow, and aren't a lot of fun to drive. They oversteer like crazy and turn in extremly slow. They feel like a boat. 

Generally, this series is similar to that of Fifa, you pay the full price every year for virtually the same game except that the cars change, and this year it got worse.

If you own F1 2021, it's a far better game than this in my opinion. Online lobbies on PC also seem to have gone quiet, I find maximum 2 lobbies under browsing, and Ranked has virtually no players in the long race format, with typically 3-4 players in the Short sprint format. 

The penalty system in Ranked is an absolute joke. You get a penalty because someone hit you?????????????

It's by far the worst optimized and bugged game we've had in years. The general handling of cars is absolutly unenjoyable, many wheels don't function properly,
I don't play online, yet I only heard really negative things about it.
I own a Logitech G920 which is by far not a good wheel (as all Logitech wheels) but it's just frustrating to use in this years game. The Force Feedback resets completly every 15 minutes or when tabbing out or steering too much or pausing the game, which forces me to completely reconnect the wheel and restart the game. Not enjoyable at all!
As I mentioned before, the handling is terrible. You don't have any control or feeling over your car and it's mostly random if your car spins unless you're a e-sport driver.
The AI is also for some reason worse than last years one which I can't understand at all.

I played F1 2020 today and it's such a huge difference. Driving without TC in F1 2020 feels 10x more stable than medium TC in F1 22 which is so far away from a real formula 1 cars handling. Curbs actually punish you hard and not cut every single apex with half your car as you unrealistically do in F1 22.
You steer to the left or right and your car really goes into the direction instantly and doesn't feel like you're driving on ice with 2s input delay..
Let's just hope we get a finished game this year which is somewhat worth close to 60€ and don't waste any time or money on this game please.

I really want to love the game. I really do! But this game embodies what modern gaming has become. Smaller studios taken over by large corporations, then turned into soulless money grabs.

- The gameplay is boring, which shouldnt happen in a racing game. It feels less intense than F1 2020, for example, where the camera moves, as if you're getting thrown around with the Gs. You feel quick in that game, you feel bored in this one,
- The AI drive their racing line, regardless of whether you're on it or not. Expect to be driven into.
- F1 Life and Supercars are a colossal waste of time. There's no point even trying them out. 
- Multiplayer is riddled with bugs, and errors.
- Customisation is literally identical to the last game. Same avatars, same concepts, same everything.
- THERES A BATTLE PASS????????

Truly truly, save some money and time and just get F1 2020, or maybe 21. If you don't mind the shadier things in life "accidentally" download F1 2013 from somewhere.

Avoid this piece of $#!+ like the plague.

I pre-purchased the Champions Edition to support and experience the VR integration. I couldn't play the game in VR for more than 15 minutes without the game crashing to desktop with the infamous EGO Dumper message. After several weeks of tinkering, forum posts, and waiting for patches, I gave up, and decided to shelve it for a few months and see if they would clean it up.

I tried playing yesterday for the first time since and, to my absolute f#@%ing astonishment, the game won't even launch. And this isn't even in VR mode, just regular display. I click Play in Steam, get a black screen, and an EGO Dumper crash message. After all this time, it's actually gotten *worse*. So I essentially gave EA/Codemasters $70 for nothing, and I can't get a refund from Steam. Turns out I'm not the only one having this issue, but EA/CM have been absolutely silent. 

I have a more than capable rig (i9 10900K, 32GB RAM, RTX 3080), and have no issues with any other games, not even past F1 titles. But ever since EA took this over, it's been a frustrating, rage-inducing headache. 

I'm going back to ACC, and writing this series off. Everything EA touches turns to $#!+, and F1 is no exception.

Just look at the reviews here, or the Discussions. There are a lot of bugs, a lot of issues, a lot of bull$#!+, and a lot of dissatisfied customers. I've been buying Codemasters products since TOCA, almost 20 years ago. No more. I'm done. There's only so much abuse I can take.

The series of Formula 1 titles has been quite similar for the last few years. In this installation, the main new features are the addition of VR (which I have not tried), and a limited selection of supercars (which handle quite poorly).

Other than this, if you want a clean F1 racing experience, this game delivers all of the circuits, liveries, and game modes you may want. There is a strong career mode which allows you to act as a racer/manager for your own F1 team, a solo grand prix mode to jump into quick races and create your own custom championships, and a time trial mode to beat lap times against your personal best drivatar. 

Overall, I would say this game is great to play in short bursts, where it might get mundane for some people over the period of multiple weeks, but still provides enough updates and online incentives to bring you back after a break. 8.5/10.

F1 22 has been my first racing simulator experience and racing game in general.
I bought it while it was on sale after gaining interest in F1 in general. I could say that it made me enjoy sim racing a lot and I will play more in the future. There is a skill part that is quite interesting versus what I expected  for a racing game. 
I played the first 60 hours with a controller and got great improvement removing all the assists one by one and improving at the game. At that point it was hard to improve due to sensitivity issue on the controller. 
I decided to buy the G920 driving wheel and pedal and I had more fun improving.

Overall, I think it is a great game, it has great features and game modes for variety of the game. The multiplayer is fun, but can be frustrating when people get you off track and get no penalties. I cannot compare it to other sim racing games but for my first experience, it is a great game.

Although I have not that many hours on this game, I can say that even while on wireless wifi I have not run into any significant connection issues in multiplayer casual races. The AI in MyTeam / Driver Career also seem to be reasonably beatable when set to the correct difficulty for my respective skill level (which is not very good granted, but nonetheless still fair.) Compared to the reviews I saw when this game first released I can say this game has improved quite a bit.

Join bugged lobby. Repeat 10x because that's how matchmaking works. Finally enter loading screen. Alt-F4 because it bugged out while loading and there's no other escape. Relaunch game (which in fairness is pretty quick), eventually find non-bugged lobby. 

They just finished qualifying so instead of placing you at the back of the grid you get to spectate the whole thing, which you might do for two reasons: the fear of being placed in another bugged lobby, or Codemasters insists you can only join that lobby no matter how many times you try to find another.

You've now watched an entire race, made it through the ending screens, track vote, players who won't ready up, miraculously the lobby didn't bug-out, and you're finally safely qualified. While on the starting grid, you attempt to buff your framerate by dropping a dynamic resolution scaling value by a hair. You notice that system is bugged too. The menu is stuck to your screen, no button combination can save you, your game is totally bricked. Alt+F4.

Then one time you get 5 laps in and it's almost all worth it - and once they fix the multitude of issues, it definitely will be. Until then, cannot in good conscience recommend.

In a year in which Formula 1 has seen so many changes, it seems reasonable that the majority of the effort for F1 22 has been on duplicating the plethora of regulatory changes in order to give the anticipated realistic racing experience the sport has been renowned for. In this aspect, F1 22 succeeds, providing a satisfyingly difficult method to maneuver these extreme racing cars across every Formula 1 circuit on the season. F1 22 falls short due to its exclusions and mediocre additions, with less content than last year's edition and a battle pass-like subscription system that locks away numerous cosmetic things behind a barrier. There are a few odd failures for a series that has been consistently terrific for so long, but happily it delivers where it counts most: in the high-octane action on the track.

F1 22 is a racing video game developed by Codemasters and published by EA Sports. It is the thirteenth entry in the F1 series by Codemasters. The game holds an official license of the 2022 Formula One and Formula 2 championships. The game was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S on 1 July 2022. It would also make its debut on EA's Origin platform as their main platform, which is also playable in the EA Desktop app, as well as the Epic Games Store. In previous entries, Steam was the only platform available for PC players. The game received mostly positive reviews from critics, with most criticism aimed at the lack of innovation compared to previous titles and the new "F1 Life" mode.


Due to new technical regulations for the 2022 Formula One World Championship, F1 22 features new car models with updated physics.[1] The game also features an updated track list, including the revised layouts of Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya for the Spanish Grand Prix, Yas Marina Circuit for the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix and Albert Park Circuit for the Australian Grand Prix, as well as adding the new Miami International Autodrome for the new Miami Grand Prix.[2] The Algarve International Circuit, home of the Portuguese Grand Prix, along with the Shanghai International Circuit, hosting the Chinese Grand Prix, was subsequently added to the game with an update.[3]

Formula One sprints, a new addition to the sport, are also included in the game.[4] F1 22 features adaptive AI, which would adjust the pace of AI cars according to the performance of players to ensure players are competitive from race-to-race. The game also introduces a customisable hub mode called F1 Life to allow players to collect supercars, clothing and accessories.[5] The game is also confirmed to support virtual reality for PC via Oculus Rift, or HTC Vive, virtual reality headsets.[6] F1 22 also features immersive broadcast options, designed after televised Formula One broadcasts, as well as interactive pit stops.[7]

EA and Codemasters also added Supercars to F1 with "Pirelli Hot Laps", which is accessible through the new "F1 Life" mode.

F1 22 was revealed on 21 April 2022, with both Codemasters and EA Sports returning to work on the game.[8] It is an official video game of the 2022 Formula One and Formula 2 championships,[9] alongside F1 Manager 2022 of Frontier Developments.[10] The game was launched on 1 July 2022, for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S platforms via Steam, Epic Games Store and Origin, which is on the weekend of the 2022 British Grand Prix.[11] The Champions Edition of the game was released three days earlier, on 28 June 2022.[12]

F1 22 received "generally favorable" reviews, according to review aggregator Metacritic.[13][14][15]

Eurogamer praised Codemasters' implementation of simulation elements such as dynamic weather and wrote in favor of their exclusion of porpoising but called the game "overly familiar" and "overly bloated", writing that "there's a feeling 2022's regulations have introduced as many problems as they have fixed, and that the positive impact of the new ruleset will not really be seen for some years to come."[16] GameSpot praised the increased level of player agency, host of assist settings, and the authentic recreation of the new era of Formula One but criticized the lack of iteration, hollow F1 Life mode, and the inclusion of microtransactions.[17] IGN liked the inclusion of the Formula One sprint race format, virtual reality support, and the game's rejuvenation of the franchise's stagnating elements but panned the "vapid" F1 Life mode's replacement of the predecessors' Braking Point mode. Regarding its monetization, the site wrote, "It's probably a sad sign of the times that while previous Formula One games featured iconic cars from the sport's history, F1 22 features an extensive set of ... designer rugs, lounges, and lamps."[20] PC Gamer praised the inclusion of real-world standings updates, sprint races, the skill tree system, damage models, and wealth of player choice but criticized the aging graphics, inconsistent AI, console controls, and lackluster addition of super cars, while noting that "the annual release has not felt this unnecessary since F1 2014."[22]

PCGamesN found itself "dulled to [F1 22's] charms" and lamented the "cumulative fatigue of having been through this experience so many times before in previous iterations, and having so little meaningful new content in F1 22 to relieve it."[23] Polygon stated that "F1 22 is not [a transformative work], but it did not need to be one — creating new cars, and the organic challenge of learning how to drive them on the limit, was transformation enough."[29] Push Square gave praise to the quality handling, good visuals, deep career modes, novel supercars, and robust customization while criticizing the numerous bugs, crashes, and screen tearing, as well as the aging game engine and insubstantial F1 Life mode.[24] Shacknews lauded the overhauled racetracks, new circuits, remixed audio, new commentary, VR support, and the integration of new regulations and car designs but disliked the "terrible" feel of the supercars, difficult AI, and persistent series issues.[25] The Guardian gave the game a score of 3/5 stars and wrote, "F1 22 is technically stunning, and that, combined with the chance to drive this year’s cars on this year’s tracks, should make it irresistible to Formula One fans. As long as they manage to ignore the egregious F1 Life."

The game topped in the United Kingdom sales charts.

Release was rough and buggy for the first several weeks afterward. Though much improved, far from acceptable for a game that has been recycled from the 2020 template TWICE now (with less pertinent features each iteration to boot). 

The AI at least somewhat behaves in single player. In multiplayer (two player career and custom lobbies with friends. Public lobbies are a s***show and out of the question when i could literally play any other game and have a better experience), the AI will maintain their line at their pace, no matter what. They overbrake when in front of you, and try to outbrake you if they're behind. At any remotely challenging AI diff, you have to be in the fastest car on the grid to ensure you aren't pit maneuvered. Simply no incentive to "rags to riches" in a back marker. 

F1 life is stupid and hollow, and I would rather crap into my hands and clap than drive the supercars. They handle like a yacht, and...oh yeah this is AN F1 GAME. The community wouldn't be so pissed about it if it weren't at the expense of dev time for the reason anyone plays the game in the first place. EA/Codies could at least do a better job at disguising their greed.

Don't get me wrong...I've had some great fun with this one, but there are moments that are just so deeply disappointing. So, I give this game a tired sigh and a nod.

After 215 hours by the the time I wrote this I found it fun but understandable why people wouldn't like this game. It has numerous amounts of issues and glitches, nothing new or unique enough to even call it new. EA has lost themselves in yearly release titles and I think they should step back and look at their marketing strategy. To take specifics the physics model is trash, if you've read some other critical reviews the game hardly feels like reality ever. Even as a sim-cade there is no glimpse of reality in the game, like many who bought this on pc we have played many other hard core sims and for me I have hundreds of hours racked on those too. I find it harder to push limits and drive on F1-22 than in any other sim I own, as a seasoned driver by now I can get used to a track in any sim with a decent five laps, with f1-22 I need to have the racing line on. Not only that but i feel like the game limits styles and creative driving, the way the physics is set up is extremely basic in how you spin so trying new things can punish you harder than even realistic sims. I honestly think ea needs to hire a team that can actually produce a decent F1 physics model for these games. I find it almost impossible to push beyond my limits other than becoming more robotic with my racing. And that's only the physics side of things, the ai are ok sometimes but tend to glitch out mid corner or on entry when you try and make a move, they won't evade sometimes and continue to turn in on you. The f1 life options and accessories are completely useless and wastes of money and development time for the team. The online servers suck, they just do, i have ethernet connection with perfect wifi and I never seem to be able to connect decently to a server. There is nothing new, not even a story or more historic cars and tracks, the my team is stale as always. My team gets boring because it is just a grind for championships and i play long form races so each takes about an hour and a half each weekend, no upgraded visuals for when you upgrade the car, no real choices and options for building a car, and my biggest problem with my team is not being able to form your own teammates strategy. The ai formulates its own strategy on what it thinks is best when us as the player should be able to take control.

Too many more problems to say like the audio and visual bugs and loading  bugs but hey who's complaining, not me.

Where to start...

The EA influence was hard on this game. Useless features like supercars, F1Life and vr which doesnt even work properly. Development was obviously rushed and marketing made a priority. EA finally got their greasy, money grabbing little hands on this game sadly. I had high hopes being that this is the new generation F1 car that promotes closer racing. F1 22 is a step down from the previous title F1 2021 in every aspect, even with the desync problem that raked havoc across the online and league racing community. Grip in this game has been changed recently. Before the handling change there was somewhat of an indication when the tyre was reaching its maximum grip and was starting to slip. Its was much easier to tell where the limit of grip was. Now however you find the limit of grip when you spin out. There is either grip or no grip, no middle ground where you can feel the tyre stressing. You just switch ends. Catching the slide is possible in some circumstances, but coming out of a high speed corner in a high gear such as 5th, 6th or even 7th, you need a miracle to not go round. Kerbs seem to be made of ice. Even 1 tyre just on a kerb is enough to go round. Every F1 game i can remember has had some bugs. 2020 with is "online services" screen stuck on during a race and 2021's dsync. F1 22 has some interesting ones. If the host of an online session disconnects or crashes, there is a very good chance the lobby is done for. Cars appear dync'd to each other and safety car deltas go instantly to -20 seconds. Also formation lap tyre temps were broken just until the last patch.

There was loads of potential for this game but it just wasnt meant to be sadly.
Buy it when its on sale, i cant recommend paying full price for this title.

This is my review for F1 22, this simcade has been a mixed bag but overall I would recommend it to people who want the fully licensed F1 experience. Now lets get into the details, the handling (physics) overall has been a improvement over last years F1 2021 game the aero system is a bit more predictable  (but still needs a overhaul, traction is inconsistent and sometimes aero can be unpredictable), slight graphics bump (the only difference with the graphics this year and last year is that F1 22 has got slightly better lighting effects), but those are probably the only improvements well yeah there is VR but apparently optimization isnt very good (i wont comment on VR since i dont have a VR headset). This is where things start to fall off, once again codemasters adding useless features and not actually fixing the game for example F1 life is just a waste of development time, what the hell is the point of adding supercars and furniture, if i wanna drive supercars ill play assetto or forza, not the OFFICIALLY licensed F1 game, they should just add back classic F1 cars or add F3 cars. Once again, year after year, multiplayer hasnt been touched, its still broken as hell, it takes 5 years to join a server, 5 years to enter a race, then your just gonna be taken out by a dirty driver, the contact system in multiplayer is wayy to sensitive (you tap a car and they are sent to mars). Also the ranked system in this game has not been touched for a long time, and it has potential but has been done poorly, if they add a system more like iRacing (safety rating (i know its already there but needs improving), some sort of iRating system, and put lower rated driver in F2 or F3 (if they add F3)). Once again the customisation in this game is very bad (F1 mobile has a better customisation system for god sake?!?!) I dont wanna have to mod the game to have awesome liverys this game was not intended for modding (they block you from multiplayer (i know there is modular mods but still...)) also console players are stuck with the bad liverys in the game, the only good on is the Audi livery but of course you need VIP pass to get that. Career/Myteam dont get me wrong career/myteam can be really fun but i havent really been playing it this year due to being the same for the last few years (it just got a bit boring) they need to add more variety to driver market (more drivers), they need visual physical car upgrades (only for the FOM car because due to the licensing of the real cars), a fully customisation calendar (asking this for years). Finally the last part, they need to use a new game engine (they have been using the current one since 2015) some bugs have been in this game for atleast 6-7 years, the game is starting to show its age now, if F1 23 doesnt have a new game engine, ill probably give it a miss for next year. Overall I recommend this game to anyone who wants a officially licensed experience but other than those group of people, I would recommend assetto corsa with the Race Sim Studio Formula Hybrid 2022 or the VRC equivalent. But if you have the money get iRacing and buy the W13.

A complete turnaround from what it was at release. This game has fixed a lot of the major bugs in a pretty short time in comparison to other developers with similar games.

They have also added a cool new 'elimination' mode for multiplayer which is really good to just have an arcade-esque mode for an otherwise realistic simcade. The handling is the main issue for me and a lot of others, but I believe its due to because its the first year of new regs, the handling can't exactly be perfect. I would imagine that it'll be a lot more refined in the next iteration.

Another good thing is the game is explicitly not pay to win, with only the Podium Pass and the Champions edition existing which neither do you need at all to get further or benefit compared to others who don't bring their wallets out for games. 

Personally, this is my favourite F1 game out the 2 others I've played so far (F1 2020 and F1 2021 on console). I think the realism and graphics have been perfectly refined, and the game runs like a dream without needing a beast of a PC. I can play on max graphics with a GTX 1060 and i7 7700k and average 80 FPS which is incredible.

The game is still a bit buggy, but it varies from mode to mode. They bring out a patch every 2-4 weeks which is a lot better than most devs, so I'm hopeful all or most of the major bugs will be remedied at some point in the near future.

Overall, the mixed reviews on the game were at one point deserved, but a few months after release I think the game has definitely turned itself around and put itself on the right foot. It can only go up or down from here.

Been playing F1 since 2016 and really enjoyed the games of the last few years. But F1 22 disappoints. It's nice that they tweaked the career practice programs. They were getting really boring. But the level of difficulty changes enormously. Most of the time it's completely impossible to pass them, even if you go full beans. So you expect to do bad in the following race. None of that. You can drive a perfectly fine race and finish way ahead of the position the car should be in. The correlation between those practice programs and the race is way off.

Also the AI keeps ramming you and the handling model seems to give you 0% rear end grip. And that F1 life part is very superficial. It does not add anything to the game. It feels like they had to add something new to sell to you.

Overall it's just not a enjoyable experience.

The handling model on this game is beyond awful, and makes the game completely unplayable, or at least takes all the fun out of playing, I know it's not a sim, but every corner you are rolling the dice whether you'll just spin out of control and lose the race or not. corners that should be able to be taken flat out you might just randomly spin and crash, or corners where you should be taking in first gear you now have to take in 3 minimum at 5-10% throttle and you'll still run the risk of spinning wildly and crashing, the care also understeer far more than they should. So basically the game is a constant stress dealing with spinning because of nothing, spinning because you short shifted and now your car drives like the track is full wet, shifting too early and the throttle spinning you out, Touching a curb and loosing all grip and spinning out or understeering so badly you have to drop down to first to make a corner you should be able to take in third at high speed. Also the game is still buggy and f1 life and the constant popup notifications makes navigating the main menu annoying. Save your money and buy literally any other f1 game than this one, it's nice to drive in Miami, but with the rest of the game being as it is, it's really not worth it.

This is a quality game. Obviously I enjoy it, as at the time of review I've clocked 137 Hours.  F1 Life seems to be a fair waste of time but yet another attempt for EA to conduct their micro-transaction model.  I would like to see the game bring back the "Braking Point" mode as that gave a short story line to differ from the usual career/multiplayer modes.  The introduction of VR has been fantastic if you have a graphics card to suit.  I have had the occasional crash whilst using SteamVR on Oculus Quest 2 via Link Cable.  Multiplayer modes are fun but I feel to separate casual players from the more experienced the server ranked lobbies should have defined assist sets.  The weekly events are the best game mode as it provides either a ranking of time trial or puts you in a situation to overcome and can be quite challenging.  You're really pushing the limits of the car and it's heaps of fun.  **Side  note to developers:  Data needs to be reviewed during online multiplayer/weekly event play as I've noticed a fair amount of players just holding rev limited as they go around the track and are exponentially faster than most of the lobby.  Not sure if this is just a glitch that someone has figured out to gain lap-time but it is quite noticeable in the weekly event as there is always easily a few that are 10-15 seconds faster than those at the top of the leaderboard**  Overall 100/10 game and I thoroughly endorse the games this franchise has produced and look forward to the future.  Cheers

Overall - DO NOT BUY this joke of a game. The AI is utterly and beyond broken ( NFS AI is ages ahead of it in terms of how it acts and actually detecting you ) - get a real life like time in terms of qualifying on 70% AI, the AI is 2 seconds faster. The control of the car - tyres in the green operating window, the car slides and is all over the place like on ice. 

Final REVIEW - the game is a 3/10 due to core features being beyond broken and unbalanced by the developers. The only reason it is a 3 - the likeness and how the tracks are in the game, realistic enough. Only for AI, how the driving feels overall - 0/10. 
                      - will not buy future installments even tho i have previous games. This is a joke towards players and enthusiasts.


AI :

- AI is unbalanced and chaotic, dive bombing when they are 0.5s+ behind you and almost ending their and your race or session. 
- AI corner exits regardless of difficulty its beyond perfect on new or used set of tires. 
- AI completely disregards the player existence - in online or single player
- AI cars on equal performance run laps around player with DRS and overtake ERS regardless of how you take the corner or engine manufacturer(not that it would matter in equal performance grand prix session). This was at 75% difficulty and on a track i'm confortable with.  

Career ( My Team / Single career ): 
- Practice programmes after patching have sky rocketed into impossible season regardless of upgrades or the car performance ( playing in a back end car for passing the program i'm asked P15 and P12 for perfect program in a back marker- second to last car performance wise ). Thats simply put thats an awful change in patching.
- Wear - 25% races and 30 minutes sessions, you go to Quick Practice to do the programs as you cannot complete them due to the reason above, starting with fresh components and going into practice with at least 20% wear on upgraded reliability. Sim is still broken, it has passed from F1 2021 to F1 22, the issue is still not solved.

Controller feeling:
- Default settings seem inconsistent, not taking inputs sometimes. Tried different setting for controller, this was not fixed. 

Conclusion: After 16.5 hours of playing, i do not recommend the game on controller. Wait for it to be patched especially the AI behaviour and speed, but as well the overall career practice programs.

Edited on 07/07/2022 after 1.1GB patch. 

AI: 

- Seems to have nerfed the AI out of corners,but its still a bit unrealistic top speeds and acceleration for realistic performance for AI - around 50% reduction from previous patches.

Career:

- Practice programs seem to have the same amount of nerfs for the time, from getting +1sec on qualy program on a track i performed well, to consistently repeating the session and program at around 0.4sec at 65% difficulty. Wear after quick practice seems lower than previous races. 

Controller:

- Input seems better now and much more responsive ( Day 0 was decent, patch 1.05 did change it for worse, now seems better than day 0 ). 

Performance: 

- Low to almost no "mini freezes" that were present in F1 2021 and F1 22 at launch. It seems mostly fixed. 

Conclusion: Changed to recommend the game as the AI difficulty and practice programs is just a fine tune thing, the overall performance of the game and responsiveness even when having other windows eating resources from pc is MUCH better ( on medium and on high settings it was a steady over 100fps).

Edits:
* post 1.06 patch : - car controls better, but overall the changes have made the AI even more broken... waiting for a fix as this made the game unplayable. 
* post 1.07 patch - AI performance is more balanced, they dont blitz into the distance as they exit the corner. 
                           - handling seems a bit floaty, not as planted as before ( on controller ) and the gears seem odd. Besides this the game seems overall balanced and playable, but wait for discounts.

Overall the experience is good with friends, but the AI issues need to be addressed as thats the major part of the game.

TL;DR: Decently good F1 game when its 30 euro's or less on sale.

The game is what you would expect from an F1 game ánd more... But that 'more' is basically useless clutter and the game itself has its fair share of issues that dont help with the enjoyment of the entire game. I will put some of my findings below.

The Campaign, the ability to do this in coöp and the way you upgrade YOUR car/team throughout the campaign is amazing. You want to be Gunther Steiner ánd be able to drive your piece of sh*t car and upgrade it? This game allows you to do so! Alone or with a friend! It's amazing fun.

The handling of the cars is also done amazingly well. Curbs punish you greatly now, low speeds can cause the car to lose traction quickly when applied to much gas and
Love the 2 player coöp and the way the new cars handle. It's different than before, should be different than before and you do notice it.

The graphics look amazing and you can run it from a low spec PC all the way to a high spec PC without issues. I mean, its Codemasters' ancient old same race engine, so dont be too worried about that.

But those were the positive parts of the game...

... now for the negatives parts and oh boy... There are a lot at the moment.

Starting with connectivity issues. For some reason, even when you're just playing coöp, you can sometimes get desync'd out of nowhere. Why? Dont no, no reason given. The game blames your connection of course, but no matter what you do or test, you will see that the problem is not your connection, but is with EA's servers. Will they ever fix this? We dont know. Did they acknowledge it? We dont know, probably not. After many months in, I can not say for certain it's fixed. Sometimes you get a night without any issues, the next day it could be constant desyncs.

AI is horrid? Or not? Or are? There's no telling what the AI will do and/or behave like per race. In one race they feel nearly real, some are more agressive, some are more passive, they try to outbrake you, you try to outbrake them, it can be pure bliss. But not even a few laps later, they can be complete idiots. Braking at random spots on the track when you are close behind them, sometimes braking so far before the corner that you can not even anticipate the correct braking point and you punt them from behind or when you slam hard on the brakes very late in to the corner... And the AI still managed to punt you off as if they suddenly know what their braking limits are. It's madness.

Multiplayer is still pure chaos. If you end up in higher ranked matches, you will see that people try to make it less chaotic, but latency issues, connection issues and other small problems keep Multiplayer from becoming anything but a fun "yeah, lets do a few races multiplayer and play something else after.".

And dont get me started on the whole retarded "F1 life" BS they crammed in. It's bad, it's sad, it's completely unecessary to have in the game.

F1 22 is very similar to 2020, and thus continues to provide by far the best offline career mode in the racing genre. Extremely well put together with propper TV-style presentations of each Grand Prix, that really gets you in the mood and makes each race feel like an event. The gorgeous graphics and impressive sound design does a wonderful job of immersing you in the world of Formula 1. 

Unfortunately some of the cool small details seen in F1 2020 are missing in this game. For instance you no longer see leaves being blown by the wind of the cars hurling past you, and the sparks flying from underneath the cars in front of you have been toned down quite a bit. The raindrops on your visor are also no longer being blown to the side by the wind. This is quite disappointing, as these details are what makes these games so immersive. 

Fortunately most of the details remain, such as the marshals waving flags during on-track incidents, your driver occasionally adjusting his grip on the wheel, fireworks going off at the end of night races etc. Another great new feature is the option to choose between different audio mixes to tailor the experience to your liking.

F1 22 also sees the new addition of music being played by the crowd in the grandstands around the tracks, which unfortunately only works in Time Trial. I wish it worked during the race weekends as well. The songs can also be listened to while browsing the menus, but I personally chose to have the traditional theme playing instead, as it is arguably the best in the history of the franchise and just sounds incredible! 

The race engineer has also finally been updated. It has always been one of the best features of these F1 games, but has admittedly been slightly buggy. But for some reason they just re-recorded the exact same voice lines as we had before with no improvement to how the race engineer actually works. They also removed the interview cutscenes, which is a shame as the idea was great, only the execution could’ve been slightly better. 

One very welcome addition is that we can now finally take manual control of the formation lap procedure. Unfortunately we still don’t have manual cooldown laps and the new “manual” pit-stops are also very disappointing, as they aren’t manual at all. The game still takes control of your car with janky and robotic movements. The only difference is that we now have to press a button to turn into the pit-stop, which is ridiculously easy to do and makes the otherwise great addition of pit-crew errors useless, as you always get a perfect stop. We can also no longer change the parameters of a race during the loading screen like in 2020 - and we somehow still don’t have mouse support for the menus... 

The single most baffling decision made for F1 22 however, is the addition of F1 Life. It is as stupid as it sounds… They also replaced the beloved Classic Cars from F1 2020 with modern Super Cars instead of expanding upon it with full Classic Seasons.

This all sounds very negative - so how come I still recommend the game? 

Because we now finally have VR support, which was sorely missing from the previous entries, as VR just matches so perfectly with racing games. The implementation isn’t perfect though, as there are a few small annoyances. For instance there is an annoying bug that causes your vision to "jitter" up and down when being parked on the grid waiting for the lights to go out. It disappears once you actually start driving. Then there is how the game insists on resetting your view all the time whenever it loads something.

Thankfully they got rid of the "please put on your headset" screen that used to appear when you took off your headset - so you are now able to navigate the menus, watch replays etc. on your regular monitor if you want to. One annoying bug is however how the image is squished when you are parked in your garage watching the live TV feed in the menu screen of your opponents racing around.
 
My final complaint is how the game displays your VR view on your regular monitor. Games like Project Cars show a perfect fullscreen image that fills the whole monitor. This game however only displays a squished circular cutout of what your right eye sees, which doesn't look as good if you want to show your live view to your friends, and means I have to manually crop and stretch the image if I want to record my VR gameplay.

All that being said, the racing itself is just utterly fantastic in VR! The F1 games have always had a great level of detail that combined with the stunning visuals - especially the night races - really makes for one hell of an immersive experience. VR improves every single racing game tenfold - and this is no exception. And while other racing titles do a better job with the physics and VR implementation itself - what we have here is still super fun to play. 
 
The new ground effect cars are significantly more challenging to drive than their predecessors - but extremely satisfying to race once you learn how to drive them right on the limit. They don’t quite handle like a propper simulator, but it’s close enough to be challenging and still intuitive and predictable. It generally works well both when using a gamepad as well as a steering wheel. The only issue is that a stupid “speed sensitive filter” is applied to gamepad users. Whenever you are driving at high speeds, a delay starts to occur from when you physically move the thumbstick on your gamepad until the wheel actually turns in-game. This effectively means you have to turn into corners way before you actually reach them. This makes chicanes and S’s almost impossible to drive, as you need to rapidly change direction in quick succession. If Codemasters would simply remove this filter and give gamepad users 1:1 input just like how it works for steering wheel users, the experience would be near perfect. 
 
The AI didn’t quite work as it should at launch, but now that it has been fixed we are left with the best offline wheel-to-wheel racing this franchise has ever seen. Once you find a difficulty level that suits you, racing against the AI becomes such a phenomenal experience. Especially since they are now able to occasionally make mistakes when you are racing against them, which makes close battles much more realistic and intense - especially in VR. I only wish they would occasionally mess up their race starts as well, since getting a good launch off the line is arguably a bit too difficult in this game. Fortunately we are now also able to tailor our career experience in much greater detail than before by altering the rate of progression for both ourselves and the AI, the rate of mechanical failures, determining how often safety cars will be deployed and so on. This helps to improve the already brilliant offline career mode - that you can now also play in co-op with a friend, which is great. 
 
We now finally also have additional tracks to choose from on top of the scheduled 2022 season. So far only Portimao and Shanghai have been added - but I’m crossing my fingers we will see tracks like Hockenheim and Nurburgring added in the future! But even if we don’t - the current selection of tracks is fantastic! 
 
In conclusion, despite the very frustrating flaws that sour the overall game - the improved wheel-to-wheel racing and the much requested addition of VR support simply makes for one of the most incredibly atmospheric and intense racing experiences to date. No other game immerses you as well as this game in VR in making you feel like you are not just racing a Formula 1 car - but are racing in an actual Formula 1 season.

Remember For Honor? Remember shitty Peer-to-peer mutlplayer? Well it's back baby. Codemasters somehow managed to create the most fundamentally broken multiplayer experience I ever had the absolute misfortune of having to experience. It's truly beyond words how immensely non-functional every aspect of multiplayer in this game is. 

Finding a lobby is best described as throwing a dice. 5 times out of 6 one of the following will happen:

* You're thrown into a lobby that's already in a race
* Error: No response from host (the most common one, yay p2p)
* Error: Session already fully
* The session never starts despite everybody being ready and the "timer" hitting zero

And the most beautiful thing about this, if you decide to leave one of those broken lobbies and start looking for a new one, there's about an 80% chance you'll just end up in the same, broken or already running lobbies again.

Sorry, did I say that's the most beautiful thing? Actually, this is: Codemasters will __never__ fix any of these bugs or even experiment with dedicated servers. Why? Well firstly because ALL OF THESE ISSUES ARE FROM F1 2021 AND F1 2020. And secondly, of course, because dedicated servers would be way too expensive for a yearly release. Lmao. 

WHY ARE THERE HOT MICS BY DEFAULT, I DON'T NEED TO HEAR EVERYBODY'S FUCKING PC FANS OR PARENTS ARGUING IN THE BACKGROUND

WHY ARE THERE FUCKING TIMERS EVERYWHERE IF NOTHING HAPPENS ONCE THEY REACH ZERO

WHY DO I NEED TO GIVE THE POSITION BACK TO SOMEONE WHO LAGGED BEHIND ME BECAUSE PEER TO PEER IS FUCKING AIDS

WHY CANT YOU TELL ME **WHY** VOICE COMMANDS ARENT AVAILABLE

WHY DOES CHANGING HOSTS TAKE 5 MINUTES AND FUCKS UP THE ENTIRE SCOREBOARD AND TURNS EVERYBODY INTO GHOSTS

WHY DO YOU STILL THINK PEER TO PEER IS A VIABLE MULTIPLAYER TECHNOLOGY FOR A TRIPPLE-A GAME IN 2022, GET A FUCKING GRIP

See you next year guys

It's a fun game BUT some stuff seems unjustifiable given that it is a big and popular AAA game by a well known game studio. 
-The AI is partly TERRIBLE. They have a tendency to just ram into you in corners going for gaps that don't exist, just ruining your race. 
Getting to a multiplayer game also seems to be pretty painful, took me at least 10 minutes to find a single lobby where I could drive. 

As of typing this- I've spent probably the last 10 minutes waiting for someone to load into the game with nothing to do as you cannot open any menu when it's "waiting for players..."  Pretty ridiculous. You also can't really tell me that's it'd be difficult to implement some working system, literally every other game does it fine, but seems like EA struggles with it. Would make it 20 minutes of waiting for a game... Great. 

If the issues are fixed then it's great, but unless you really know and need the F1 22, I wouldn't particularly recommend it in it's current state.

Update: Still lots of occasional bugs such as losing the DRS indicator lights from the steering wheels due to an update which broke it, taken very long to fix it. 

Don't regret buying it though.

To make it worse this was already a big problem with F1 2021 and this game has the exact same issues. Also the gameplay is really similair to 2021. Same game modes, same feeling, same bugs. Online also still has the exact same problems, strange penalties and a standard safaty car for 30% of the race.

To sum up they did literally copy the previous game and changed the handling of the cars a bit, while not adressing any issues.

What a launch this game had. Champions edition buyers got the game like 8 hours later than the promised time. Jesus the game is buggy af! Locked inside the menu during gameplay, constant crashes you name it. It's really an early access build at this point. Cars are nice to drive, AI is hell of a lot aggressive and some post race cinematics are nice. Apart from that nothing great really.

EDIT:

Tried out multiplayer. Turns out it's worse than single player. A lobby with over 10 players is a recipe for disaster. It gets stuck on the loading screen because of one or two people and rest of the lobby has to wait for them to load in or quit the game. These were last year's issues ported into this game.

Wanted to try out MyTeam. Guess what? The game is stuck at loading screen for FP1.

EDIT 2: Single player Gran Prix mode is also stuck in loading screen and never starts the race. I'm done with this game!

FINAL EDIT: Built a new PC but this time on the Intel platform. Game works as expected. My laptop running an AMD CPU with an RTX 3060 still doesn't load into certain game modes. I'll leave that here. Get the game if you like to play every instalment in the series but only if there's a huge sale. It's not worth the full price.

More development on furniture than the actual game, like come on, no classic cars but we get a new lamp, bugs all over the show but we get a new couch... tiny selection of tracks, can't even make a custom order to your season, or make a fully custom season. Handling is meh. You can really see why the game is worth the $60 price tag *sarcasm* EA really rubbed their "polish" on this one hey, battle pass, pitcoin, furniture and clothes in a racing game, THE FURNITURE ISN'T EVEN DRIVABLE...
The amount of bugs in this game is astounding. You should buy F1 2020 or F1 2021 before those get removed from Steam as well..

Even after multiple patches, I would still say it's a "Mixed" review.

Okay, let's start with Pros:
[list]
[*]New 2022 cars, New Miami track
[*]Big update for Australia and Abu Dhabi, slightly smaller update for Spain, some small updates to a few other tracks
[*]New handling is challenging at first but good enough when you get at least some hang of it
[*]VR is finally available
[*]You can have F1 Sprint races now
[*]There's a soundtrack now which isn't too bad (general Theme still remains as usual)
[*]Plenty of options for game configuration
[*]You can finally select Tyre allocation again (in a way)
[*]Cross-Play!
[/list]
The Cons though...
[list]
[*]Almost no changes to Career Modes when compared to last year - even more, I think the game potentially went backwards?
[*]Supercars - Enough said.
[*]F1 Life - pointless. Literally there to push microtransactions.
[*]Very few Multiplayer changes
[*]Accessibility Options went BACKWARDS after1.05 update (Voice-to-Chat and backwards options were REMOVED)
[*]AI is still meh (they seem a bit stupid rather often)
[*]A rather high amount of game glitches and bugs, plus usually a good amount of NEW bugs with every patch
[*]Audio has some issues and it looks like they are not going to be fixed
[*]Issues with various control devices (gamepads, wheels)
[*]Graphics seem a bit worse than last year somehow, but that may be just me
[*]Generally high game price on Steam
[*]Cross-play is generally glitchy unfortunately
[*]Maybe something else, if I remember something I'll add later on
[/list]

Honestly, I would like this game. I enjoy the handling much more than in F1 2021 - and I could recommend the game just for that. However it is hard to justify the price for this game when I have already seen everything back in F1 2021, plus there REALLY isn't anything new.

[b]Verdict:[/b] Generally now worth buying, but rather wait for sales.

I'm going to write an actual review for this game. I like this one more than 21, EA actually did good on this game after having full rights over production for the first year, even on the marketing leading up to this game, it lead me to be so hyped up for the release that I even bought the Champions Edition for 3 days early access. As soon as I loaded into the game I was quite pleased actually, amazing changes in the look of the game, mechanics and even the music. So far EA has actually propelled this franchise in the right direction over the wrong, and I hope that this upward trend continues into the next years of the franchise. Overall I believe that this game has been amazing so far from the hours that I have played so far, a little sad that there is no story mode, but F1 Life is not as horrible as what a bunch of other people say.

OK it's got issues, bugs that should have been eliminated within the first couple of months but this is the first F1 VR game and it's a cracker mate (as Webber would say)! I've got a good mixture of low to high with SS in SteamVR at 160% and it looks great. My rig is a 10900k, 3080 with 64GB RAM using a Vive Pro and the frame rate is solid, the graphics are good (not amazing as it's VR) and the handling is decent. I would have to say that this is the best F1 game so far and at Steam Sale price of £25 it's worth it, granted if I'd have paid £50 like the early adopters I'd have been a little more cheesed off with the bugs but that's what you get when you can't wait and now'a days anything that's released is a buggy mess for a few months. Overall a solid 8/10.

F1 22 isn't going to blow your mind with its new features, especially when it comes to F1 Life. Bugs and glitches which can hamper the overall presentation and realism.

Champions Edition Owner, BEFORE YOU READ FURTHER IF YOU THINK EA MADE F1 22 STOP READING, EA PUBLISHED F1 22 CODEMASTERS MADE THE GAME, ANY ISSUES ARE CODEMASTERS FAULT NOT EA.

Here's my personal thoughts on F1 22, agree to disagree that's fine.

I've played Driver career, MyTeam, Online, Time Trail and played a bit with the F1 life.
I have really enjoyed this game, potentially making this one of the best F1 games for a very long time. For me this beats all other games made by Codemasters, and for me 2020 was the best codemasters game until now. 

Besides a few bugs here and there which by the way is standard for Codemasters to do, just think back to f1 2021's release, the game is amazing. At first I was having crashing problems with VR however this wasn't F1 22's fault it was SteamVR after a quick uninstall of SteamVR to then reinstall all my issues were sorted. Playing this game in VR with the Quest 2 is the best thing in the world. I'm not a huge fan of single player I tend to do Two Player Career mode most, but since launch I've played MyTeam the most. 

Pros - VR is very good
        - AI are more Aggressive 
        - Racing is alot cleaner and nicer
        - Kerbs aren't stupidly harsh
        - Is a lot closer to being a Sim

Cons - Non

Now I might be biased here, but for me there are no cons, yes I'm not a fan of F1 life and the Supercars however that doesn't make them a con, but also I've had little to no problems with the game but that might be due to my insanely overkill computer.

Overall one of the best games Codemasters has made.
