F1 22 is the best game in the series, but not by a distance. The improved handling and supercar challenges are cancelled out by the lack of a story mode and the superfluous new F1 Life mode, making for a game that gives as much as it takes away.

For a number of years now the F1 games have been delivering rock-solid recreations of the sport, meaning anyone expecting an enormous overhaul anytime soon is setting themselves up for disappointment.

This year, however, things are a little different (but only a little). With the real-life F1 seeing some notable changes to its regulations and aerodynamic rules this season, F1 22 has undergone a revamp.

The new car designs mean that instead of ‘flat floors’ there are now aerotunnels on their undersides. This means the car is pulled down more as air flows through it. The result is a game that does handle somewhat differently, though not to the extent that it’s a completely different experience.

There’s more grip on corners and there’s minimal drag on straights, to the extent that players who put a lot of time into F1 2021 will notice a difference, but adjusting to it will take no more time than adjusting to the fact that the title formatting has gone from ‘2021’ to just ‘22’.

There may be minor differences on the track, then, but it’s the new F1 Life mode that EA and Codemasters are trumpeting as the latest big addition to the series.

The most interesting part of the new F1 Life mode is the addition of supercars, which can be driven in time trials or a series of 40 special ‘Pirelli Hot Laps’ challenges.

The unlocking process for these supercars is surprisingly restrained, as players simply earn tokens by racking up mileage. There’s no way to buy them with real money, and there’s a separate mode outside of F1 Life which lets you take on the challenges anyway – the tokens are only used to ‘buy’ the cars for display in your hub.

F1 Life seems fairly throwaway at the moment, then, but thankfully the Career mode remains present and accounted for. It isn’t enormously different to that in F1 2021, meaning players who’ve already thoroughly rinsed that game may get a strong sense of deja vu.

Naturally, there are new additions to fit the F1 2022 season. There’s a new Miami circuit, some circuits have been modified to match their real-life tweaks, and a few events have the new Sprint qualifying rounds which have proved popular with the F1 fanbase. For the most part, though, it’s business as usual.

In fact, our biggest takeaway (for want of a better word) isn’t what’s been added to F1 22, but what’s been removed from it. The ‘Braking Point’ story mode in F1 2021 may have been a bit on the clichéd side, but it was still an interesting way to play through an F1 career.

This time there’s no story mode at all, meaning solo players will have to make do with the existing Career mode, the 40 Pirelli Hot Laps supercar challenges and the regular daily challenges designed to give XP for the Podium Pass unlockables.

The net result of all this is that in a season notable for its attempts to push the sport to the next level, F1 22 feels more like a game in which progress has neither been gained nor lost.

For some titles, this would be potentially catastrophic, but the reality is that F1 22 is still an immensely impressive take on the sport, with Codemasters’ trademark pedigree on full display with some of the most satisfying racing action you’ll find on console or PC.

If you’re the sort who put 100+ hours into the last game you may be underwhelmed at the relative lack of new features, but judged on its own merits F1 22 is the best in the series to date, even though it comes down to a photo finish.

I think F122 is a good sim. I like the vivid graphics and the forced feedback is very impressive on my GT-DD pro. 
I'm using V3 Pedals and a V2.5 wheel.   Things I don't like are how in time trial mode, what's this "Fast Lap" throw us on the track all about?!  Why can't we drive out from the garage and to the track like real drivers?   I also turn off all my assists. I don't want any race line of any kind!  I turn off all assists to the car, but the problem then is that it will bump you up to expert mode from what i can tell, unless there's a way I can have all the assists off, so I can practice reading the track to learn, but then I don't seem to have the ability to turn down the AI separately?  If I turn down the AI then assists are automatically turned on to various degrees of ease from controlling my throttle to painting that race line in front of me!    To me that's not good!   Also, should be able to select amount of other race teams on and off track in Trial mode instead of being deserted.
But I do really enjoy the action the way the car handles and there are some set up options I like.   I like driving in the cockpit using my TrackIR v5 as it adds a nice ability to look around and lean my head while driving. It's not VR but it's better than a fixed position while in the cockpit.  I want to be in the car , not on top of the car.  I think driving on top of the car in TV cam view is sort of like cheating. Or if it's not cheating it's easier to see and drive.
I like what's presented here for the 2022 season, but I wish with the graphics and feedback quality which EA is known for, I wish EA would add DLCs of older classic tracks like Laguna Seca, SPA, Watkins Glenn and more of the classic tracks with the EA quality that exists.    I really wish EA would create an Indy tour circuit for 2023 with all the tracks and circuit features within the North American F1 , basically Indy car with set ups for road course and Oval 500!
But back to F122.  I think there could be some more freedom with cars and pit crew while driving in trial mode, practice pit stops with crew available.  Drive in and out from garage and allow multiple cars out to practice at different AI levels without any assists forced back on so I can practice competing with them in something other than Expert level.
But I really enjoy what we have.

The game (of course) shares a lot of similarities with previous F1 games, however, due to the new cars, it feels completely different. I myself really like the changes that have been made, and feel like it has been a major improvement. The new cars look amazing, and it's very nice that you can even choose the coating of the car (matte, metallic, etc).

The addition of F1 Life and the Supercars is also a neat change. However, when on the topics of these additions, I had higher expectations. 
- The Supercars were quite easily earned, and new supercars never released. I hoped for some more additions in this field as part of updates or even as part of the Podium Pass, but unfortunately.
- F1 Life could have been more... At the moment it's just a customizable field, but there are not a lot of interactive elements. Sure, you can customize your player and your house, as well as show off your earned supercars, but that's about it. Would have liked to see some more interactivity on this addition. Also, most F1 Life earnables can only be bought, with some obtainable in the Podium Pass. Would have liked to see some challenges, making some incentive towards playing.

Support for the game has been good however, and the updates have improved the game even more over time. Nice addition of giving some freebies from time to time. Overall a great game and I love it to bits.

If you like to buy a pair of virtual sunglasses for a few IRL bucks, this is your game
If you like to buy some virtual brand clothes and look at them, this is your game
If you like supercars and want to experience to drive them about, this is your game
If you like to fall off the chair laughing about super car physics, this is your game
If you want to experience, how F2 cars do not handle and drive IRL, this is your game
If you like to look at outdated graphics engines and DLSS ghosting, this is your game
If you are crazy for FFB and driving physics changed with every other patch, this is your game
If you like to take a laugh about how EA rates F1 drivers and their skills, this is your game
If you are looking for an epensive, fully licensed annual title with micro transactions, this is your game
If you want to see drivers dance and hop their way to an F1 podium, this is your game
If you want to see 3x the identical female character model celebrating your podium, this is your game
If you are fond of dull engine sounds, lawnmowers and the like, this is your game
If you are fancy being disconnected from multiplayer lobbies all the time, this is your game
If you want to go up against a ton of cheaters and crash derby drivers, this is your game
If you have fun with braindead AI taking any chance to hit your car, this is your game
If you like to see your car breaking down in simulation mode, while AI is indestructible, this is your game
If you are looking for features getting streamlined every annual release, this is your game
If you like to get your backsided handed by AI who has 3x the grip in the wet, this is your game
If you want to experience tyre simulation models that do not work at all, this is your game
If you want to see badly implemented weather effects, this is your game
If you want to support EA company buying more smaller developers, this is your game
If your prefer inaccurate non laser scanned tracks over the real thing, then this is your game

Revisiting this old review I gave the game after the first two weeks... and I'm afraid to say it's basically the same thing, but worse. I especially don't rec this game to anyone seriously interested in improving their driving or joining a league.

Bottom line: The game is loaded with bugs that aren't fixed from patch to patch.

Let me explain briefly: Leagues are not cross-platform. In the cross-platform "league" I'm currently in, we have to create a custom lobby and invite everyone from there. But here's the kicker: invites to servers only work about 70% of the time. That's extremely disappointing when you practice throughout the week, set aside time once a day to race in the league itself, and then you can't even participate. And even if you get into the game itself, you might get kicked, or your game might crash unexpectedly. 

I'm not sure what the issue is with this release. The last few F1 games have had their fair share of goofy bugs and kinks, but they were never this game-experience breaking before. I sincerely hope CM and EA figure out how to fix this, or else I really see this franchise going in a downward trend.

I would like to give this a thumbs up, but i just can't...
Single player could be fun, if it weren't for the bugs. Apparently some of them have been there in 2020 and 2021 and still not fixed.
For example AI cheating in wet races. they just flat out do not care about conditions when the accelerate (in corners they do, but only there), its like if they are driving on dry tarmac. just not fun, when at start half the grid just flies past you and you have no chance of catching up. Also you cannot adjust the AI to compensate for that, cause thats not allowed on race events, only between them... 

Multiplayer is usualy a pretty bad experience, in every race you get people, that just intentionally try to rear end people, spinn them around or try to crash them if you try to overtake them.
and that is IF you get into a lobby in the first place. this game has some bad netcode. if you try to find a specific lobby that you know exists (like from a streamer) it is a gamble, for it to even show up in the list. also if you try to join, in about 90% of the time you get a time out and error message that the host is not answering. they have a button to cancel the attempt, which is not working, the game just locks up until you get the error message...
before the latest patch the game could be discribed as "waiting simulator" in multiplayer lobbies (in between loading screens). they claim to have improved their netcode, which is true, but only marginable.

all of this for 60€? luckily i got it on discount, but 30€ is still too much at this point.

oh i almost forgot, F1 life and supercars... yeah right... that is forgetable, a waste of development power, they really should have fixed their bugs instead.
If you are an F1 Fan, this game is very addicting. On sale, you should get this.

The game managed to cover the basics of the essence F1 has to offer, but still more to be done by the developers. The previous releases had much more to offer, and not some swag to put on you character in a game and super cars which should maybe appear in a different scenario, rather than in pre-race sessions which is pointless from my perspective. F1 22 should have brought more of the F1 experience only, with the focus on the AI balance, team balance, players balance, physics and mechanics of the F1 cars. The example to point it out, while playing the carrier mode your engine just dies in the second race if you managed to win the first grand-prix, and your, potential rival ended up in the midfield in the second race, you simply have to retire your car due to engine failure. I find that discouraging in a moment where you are striving to make progress you are destined for a set back which doesn't seam realistic at all.
A side of the small flaws the game is awesome, with awesome graphics and sound effects, leading you to hardly make any difference with the real race being broadcasted live.

This is my first, and probably the last time that I'll write a review on a video game . F1 22 is the worst racing experience I've had in my life. Disregarding all the multiplayer bugs that have been going on for almost a decade now, even the singleplayer is unplayable now. The AI is so quick on the straights, even the most dominant car in Formula 1 history ( 22 Redbull ) wouldn't stand a chance against them. Even if you do manage to stay side by side going through the corner, they will simply turn in on you, and spin you around. I am starting to feel like Vettel driving this game. If you want to be quick on this game, forget driving like a normal human being. Try using 5th or 6th gear through the slow corners , that will probably gain you a couple of tenths. But hey, at least  I managed to get myself a very nice black sofa, so now I have something really cool to look at when I am exiting this horrendous game. F1 Life is very useful, and definitely helps your decision not to buy any future games.

Overall, I'm really enjoying this game. I've integrated this game into my F1 watching experience; I've been running a race in the game before watching the races on TV which helps me learn the nuances of each track. The previous F1 game that I played was F1 2018, so I've been enjoying the upgraded visuals and driver lineups.

However, there are several bugs that should have been fixed. I'm currently stuck in career mode because the game doesn't remember that I've changed my tires. I'm racing in Imola, and with 2 laps to go my race engineer tells me that I need to use 2 different compounds (despite having gone from soft to medium 5 laps ago). I ignore the warning and get black flagged on the last lap.  I rewind, try to pit, and they replace my mediums with other mediums, and am black flagged again, without the ability to rewind far enough to fix this. So I restart my race, thinking it's a one-off, and it happens again. So I pit again on the last lap for a Soft -  Medium - Hard tire strategy, and I get black flagged on the last lap anyway. So now I've wasted a good 45 minutes trying to complete this race but can't because of this bug.

Like I said, overall it's fun, and I feel like I will get my money's worth, but it occasionally has game-breaking bugs.

One Sentence Review - EA is ruining every sports game out there and sadly, F1 isn't an exception.

I've played 160+ hours of F1 20 and 300+ hours on F1 21, and while F1 21 was itself a letdown from 2020 (except for the Braking Point storyline), F1 22 breaks all records on number of bugs a fully finished game from a professional studio can have. If you're a patient person, it will still be a tricky situation as every update somehow makes the game worse than last one. EA developers need to listen to the gaming community on what's working in the game and what's not, but instead they keep messing up every aspect of the game that runs well and leave the bugs intact. 

The handling is worse than the last game, the simulation is pathetic, and don't even go for the online lobbies if that's what you're buying this game for. I have never had as many bugs/glitches in online lobbies as this game. Stick to games like iRacing if you're buying this for online competitive races.

The only aspect I can recommend this game for is that it's unintentionally funny. Weird incidents will keep happening during online Two Player Career mode (which is way worse than F1 21) as well as lobbies, which will make you laugh if you're not seriously racing. For all other purposes, this game will give you more migraine than the latest MCU movies. 

EA needs to stop treating gaming/sports fans with utmost disrespect just to churn out new games every year that don't work. If your developers need more time, it's fine, we can wait. They seem not to care anymore though.

Price - With its current state, it's not worth even a $10 investment (I pre-ordered it for more than $40).

First impression of the game from a player with 200 hours on F1 21 and 150 hours on F1 20.
1. F1 22 car's rear is just too unstable to drive without the traction control. Driving with the traction control takes lot of joy out of driving so this is a dilemma.
2. I am using Thrustmaster T300RS Racing Wheel and whenever I pause or start on drive out wheel's feedback pressure is gone for 2~3 seconds  for some reason. (Did not happen in any of previous F1 game series.)
3. You start out with even less clothing and customization options to begin with, compared to any of the previous F1 game series.
4. If you are into just Racing then there are basically no new contents beside new F1 car that have a terrible rear traction.
I am going to give it some more play time but I am not enjoying the experience.

Lets be honest F1 games are rubbish. They have had the licence for years and are still shit at making games get better EA you should be able to make a good game especially considering the budget you get.

A mixed bag, F1 2022 doesnt offer anything ground breaking in the genre that makes it worth the price EA are asking for. 

Much of the game feels like a carry over from the previous titles, although I do like the immersive additions added to pit stops and formation laps. I just wish they had spent more time and effort developing  new ways like this to make the game even more immersive. But no, instead we got an ironically lame "sims" F1 life mode with a super cars hot laps facade that tries to rip of Grand Tourisme, but fails. 

Firstly, this is an F1 game, wtf do I want to drive super cars? And secondly those should have been older / vintage F1 cars. F1 has a huuuge heritage, why EA doesn't draw from the sports history, like including a historic F1 campaign mode (driving in the 1970's for eg as Nikki Lauda or James Hunt) is still a mystery to me. 

Anyway, graphics are great and I havent had any major performance issues yet. But if you're a fan and just want to drive the new 22 cars, wait for a sale.

This game had so much potential to be a great game, but for me sadly, it falls just short. F1 2021, while not being the best F1 game, was still solid and a good amount of fun, Same goes for F1 2020. But Sadly, I don't think I can really say that about this game, it has its moments, but for the most part, I find myself getting bored after just a few laps. My biggest problem with this game is the lack of innovation, and just overall lack of change from F1 2021 & F1 2020. After F1 2020, F1 games have been slowly removing content from the newer games. F1 2021 lacked Classic Cars, which is one of my favorite parts of the F1 games. F1 22 (from what i can remember) didn't remove anything that we had in previous games, but they spent WAY to much time on the new things they added. The Pirelli Hot Laps seemed neat at first, but after about 2 drives in the cars, i didnt care anymore, and anytime i was asked to do them i would just get annoyed. This is an F1 game, not Forza, there is no reason that Supercars should be in the game, but not Classic Cars. Second is F1 Life, which seemed like it could be cool at first, but is just a huge waste of time and money, Im trying to play an F1 Game, not Sims. why is the Item Shop usually littered with all this F1 Life stuff instead of Liveries, Overalls, Helmets, Etc.? For me, the only really cool/good thing they did, was finally adding VR support for PC users. But that in itself isnt very well optimized, its got better since launch, but it still has its fair bit of small problems. And dont even get me started on the lack of ANY changes to My Team, they didnt change anything, other than a UI piece here and there, but other than that, nothing is different between My Team in this game, and in F1 2021. With all that being said, the game is very meh, and i feel no want or desire to play this game, and im pretty disappointed.

[b]4/10 A Decent Amount Of Fun, But Not The Best Experience Overall[/b]

I love the Formula 1 races and as such have been playing the Formula 1 games since the '97 version. I have played both 2020 and 2021 before this one.

First let's talk about the good things about the game. It looks really nice and has a lot of new interesting features. It even played really well in the beginning, and then came the patches....

First thing I noticed are the horrible commercials from EA now that they taken over Codemasters, the obnoxious connection to EA game server on about every screen as well. But hey I could get over this. Then came a patch that changed the AI behaviour and not for the better.

Now the AI is super annoying and difficult, but not because he actually drives better, but because he clearly cheats (I know AIs are supposed to do this a little, but it should not be so obvious). Also the AI is now very idiotic, it even slams in the side of me during start and then takes me with him on the front bumper until the next corner. By that time I have even gotten a penalty for obstruction, even though I have no option to get out of the way.

These things did not happen before and have taken all the joy out of the game for me. I will not stop playing it entirely and check up on the game in the hope it gets fixed. But at the current state I simply would not recommend this game. Just stick with 2021 until this is fixed.

If you have F1 2020 keep it, it's a far better game with loads more content to choose from. The game is a major step back from years past with the only big perk being that it has the new cars.

What I'd like to see:
1. Return of historic F1 cars
2. New tracks added every so often that don't disappear when the next F1 game comes out (they are doing this to an extent which I respect).
3. Adaptive AI or a way to easily determine your AI level. I constantly struggle with trying to get the right balance so it's actually competitive relative to the car I'm in so I'm not running away with the race in a McLaren but also not feeling uselessly slow.
4. F3 cars
5. Much more advanced livery editor with real sponsors that are on the F1 grid.
6. Custom Helmet Maker
7. More custom race features that let you try unique rules (reversed grid orders, number of required pit stops, etc). 
8. Red Flags

What you get:
1. Cross platform co-op available (probably the best new feature added)
2. HGTV Million Dollar Dream Home
3. Better Homes and Gardens Magazine subscription
4. Super cars in an F1 game

So far, I am giving this the thumbs up.
I wasn't going to bother buying this until it was heavily discounted, but as it was a free weekend, I gave it a try in VR, and then I couldn't resist buying it at half price.

The first thing I notice is, if you already have F1 2021 and no interest in using this in VR, then it's not really worth buying, though I have already noticed one or two differences after the first few hours:
 - the handling is different, not better or worse, just different - possibly it's a bit easier to wheel spin out of corners so I have to be a bit more careful on the throttle, but so far I have no complaints about that.
 - second, if you cause any damage, the repair time is often much longer than previous F1 games, so you can be sitting in the garage for 20 minutes, which is more realistic than the previous 4 minutes I used to regularly see.
 - difficulty is much harder, but that doesn't matter, it just means starting with a lower setting - (I used to play on 85 to 90, but i'm starting my F1 22 career at 65). 
 - the radio engineer sound mix has been adjusted, & Jeff has been replaced with a new voice, and I think it's somehow slightly more realistic sounding.

But my main reason for buying F1 22, and for bothering to review it, is the VR experience. The game runs just fine for me in VR, and after testing it in a few GPs, at Australia and Monaco, I was impressed enough to buy it, and I am definitely planning to run most, if not all of my career in VR. I have the HP Reverb G2 headset, Gigabyte Z390 Gaming X motherboard, i7 4770K, Windows 10 64bit, 32GB ram, Gigabyte 3080ti GPU. 
I do see a very slight amount of 'judder' in my vision during pitstops / when sitting on the start grid before the race / or when sitting in the garage. BUT otherwise, for the entire race, the whole experience is smooth, even at a traditionally power hungry circuit like Monaco.

Of course I have many graphic details turned down to medium or lower, compared to playing on the monitor, but the experience (and graphic appearnace) still easily matches or beats my other race sims in VR (I regularly play AMS1 and Raceroom in VR, & they are great but do not quite match F1 22). I don't know what else to tell you, for me, it just works. I have had VR for a number of years, and this is the first time in a while that I have been 'wowed' by VR, and I'm driving in an F1 car with a permanent grin.

So the bottom line for me is, if you want to try it in VR, then buy it and give it a go. If your system doesn't want to run it smoothly, then you can always refund it, but I'm very happy with it.

As for the non-VR side of things, it's time Codemasters thought of something else to add. It's not worth £50 just to change the car shapes & liveries each season, while copying and pasting everything else, you should be ashamed. Of course, not much changes from year to year, but £50 ? No, it's too much. 
I mean, how about expanding the 'My Team' mode to include a 'Manager mode', so I could control both drivers' strategies and sit back and watch/control them during the race weekend if I want, rather than actually drive every session? That would be better than the pointless 'F1 Life' that someone thought was worth investing time & effort into.

I bought this for it's baked-in VR support. Unfortunately, things are never that simple and once you have the VR headset on, you then get hit with confirming access to your EA account, via emailed code. Take the headset off, go to email, get code, headset back on, try to find a way to input code in VR... blah blah blah. In sort, if you're gonna play in VR, it might be best to play out of VR the first time just to get everything setup. Luckily, despite complaints about supported controller not being available, my Logitech wheel worked fine, as did my mouse and keyboard when required. Once in, the visuals are great, although I still need to find an option to remove the halo strut from my vision. Authentic or not, it's annoying. Gameplay (and this is a game, not a simulator) seems very forgiving and perhaps I need to look for other options to make it more challenging. There seems to be a fashion for countless menu screen these days and they are not always intuitive. Most of the time I just want to jump in and race without all of this window dressing and "full experience" nonsense. Maybe the first screen show offer you a UI selection of "Just Play" or "Waste my time with additional content" options. I should say that I did the weekend free trial of this title and I was 50/50 on whether to buy it but as it was half-price, I decided to pull the trigger. I would have never payed full price. I can see the work that has gone into it but most of it I will never use, so buying at a discount made sense for me.

the f1 games are so far out of date its no longer funny. ai is broken, audio is broken, graphics from the xbox 360 and a physics model that feels like its from roblox. utterly unacceptable for a triple A title and ea should be ashamed of themselves.

The AI is by far the most agressive thing since Doom Eternal and/or Metal : Hellsinger. It WILL push yo off the track and it doesn't care about loosing a front or back wing at all. 

With this out of the way, the game overall is quite good. Compared to 2021 it has some nice upgrades in RTX graphics and overall car handeling. However the F1 Life feature seems kind aout of place and doesn't bring anything usefull to the table. Same has to be said about the Pirelli Races. They just take up time and "supercars" are really..really bad. I owned cars that were faster and better in ALL regards, that I would not consider supercars at all. Come on...140-150 kmh in a corner...I'm German, those are rookie numbers. Seriously Codemasters, you should try our Autobahn...you'd be surprised.

It's a good game however but you shouldn't expect too much and if you played 2021 it pretty much feels like the same game with different textures (even some...if not most...of the audio queues are the same). 

Would I reccomend it? Well yes and no. Not if you already own 2021 or 2020. You won't get your money's worth. If you're new to the series it's a good start but if you're willing to wait, do so and maybe 2023 will deliver a better experience.

Great game

If you can look past the gimmicks that EA has thrown into the game and get lost in a Career or My Team mode, then this game is for you. I might've looked through the house decor and clothing stuff once to see if any of it was cool (it wasn't).

The customization of the liveries and team colors is pretty good, the more you level up it seems the more patterns you can unlock, and you can throw your custom team color into a patterned livery however you see fit. 

This is my first sim racing game, so I'm using a cheap wheel from GameStop. Still, the car responds fairly well and throttle/brake response is good. Once I developed my trail braking (esp for Bahrain T9/10), even my cheap pedals worked well and are very sensitive. Tire deg is super real in this game, you can be throwing it through high speed turns no problem but after a 4-5 laps depending on the conditions you start going wide and feel understeery through most of the lap if you push. 

I started with most of the assists, and was going to wean myself off each assist one by one. But getting rid of one while having the others enabled felt really unnatural, so I turned them all off except for racing line to learn the tracks, and eventually I got the hang of it. I run the full length races with all practice sessions and quali, and I can easily burn 3-5 hours per session just driving and improving. I love getting lost in that flow, and managing my pitstops on the fly. 

The AI are a little dumb, they will allow you to pass for a blue flag and then shoot for a gap. They'll go for any gap. I've left only half a car width on the outside just to have an AI push it and pit me into the barricade. Don't forget to scale up the difficulty as you go, because you'll go to send it through a chicane and a dumbed-down AI that's way too slow will cause an accident real fast. 

My set up is incredibly basic and won't get me close to the professional times, but that's ok. Set the AI and assists the way you need it and you'll be good to go. 

Also. the music isn't that good.
Superb graphics, feels immersive, adrenaline rush guaranteed.

I purchased the game this year because I have desperately wanted to play F1 in VR.  However, from patch 1.6 to 1.10 hotfix the experience has gotten worse for me.  I can now no longer play the game for more than 10 minutes without Steam VR locking up (Gamepad issues) and this kicks me from the game, each session takes longer than 10 minutes so I cant finish a session.  There seems to be no investigation or incoming patch for this issue after looking through the forums, some people have suggested using other software but I cannot  get this to work either.  If your looking for a VR F1 experience, look elsewhere!

v1.12
I have managed to finish a race in career mode finally, just short of 1 month after the game became unplayable.  New issues, when racing close to another car the game becomes jittery in VR, when restarting after flashback the game lags and then speeds up meaning unless your on a straight you lose all progress you wanted to back track to.  I had one lockup in FP1, started a race pace practice session, the game started as normal when selecting start on track, as I went to assume control its just froze, full shut down and restart and it worked with the previous bugs.  Its better and I hope there is a hotfix following closely behind remedy the new lag issues in v1.12

I'll try and make this as short and informative as possible. If you have F1 2021 should buy this game? No, unless you really want the updated cars/ team colors and want to experience VR. Or if this is your first F1 game, this is a fine entry point. There's nothing I'd call actually bad, but there's not enough meaningful updates from 2021 to justify buying this for the average gamer. The game is really solid and most importantly, fun to play! There's just not enough separating this game from last year.

The Good:
Pit stop errors are a great, if sometimes frustrating, addition!
VR, at least for my Rift S, is cool, but could do with more HUD options.
The driving feels pretty good for someone who runs with very minimal to no assists.
AI having more mistakes I think was a good call. Makes some races really wild!
My Team and Driver Career are solid as always.
Still one of the most replayable racing games for solo players. Managing your car and/or team throughout multiple seasons, changing your team, changing season lengths and tracks used, all keep me coming back to this series. 

The Bad:
Crashes. I've had every F1 game since 2018 and this is the first time where at launch, the game is frequently crashing during loading screens. I'm sure devs are working on it, but still, it's an issue that should always be noted.

F1 LIFE. Oh boy. Aside from it being a clear EA cash grab, I believe this could have been solid. Showing off/ driving exotic cars and making a personalized living space sound pretty cool. But here's my biggest issue with this mode. Whoever came up with F1 Life is not an F1 fan. Instead of giving us exotic cars that you can play in almost any other racing game, return the classic F1 cars and collect those instead. It probably would have been relatively easy to do since the assets probably still exist in F1 2020. At least then fans get classic cars from various eras of F1. Oh and you could add more classic cars as DLC. I could honestly rant more but I'll end it there. TLDR, F1 life could have been easy fan service.

Car/ player customization. There's still a lot to be desired with changing the look of you and your My Team car. Having preset designs is great, but I'm pretty sure everyone would appreciate more control that games like Forza and Gran Turismo offer.

Like most annual franchises, new F1 games can feel samey, and the same is true now, if maybe a bit more so. Despite the cars handling differently compared to last year, the physics still feels very much the same. Overall the game needed more or better features to make it stand out from last year's title.

I wanted badly for this game to be good. Unfortunately it seems that this is getting the FIFA treatment, an absolute downgrade in terms of quality overall from the previous entries in the series. 

For a game based on a sport where fractions of fractions amount to meaningful performance it's sad to see there is still no support for analysis or training. I would really like to see some training featured to help you understand the inputs and control that is required of an F1 car to really be fast or efficient. 

There's also no telemetry provided back in the game for you to review why your car may have been doing what it was doing. 

You can definitely muscle through all of the bull to find a gameplay loop that is fun in all of this. But for full MSRP it is insane and should be criminal that this is what players are receiving.

Time for an short review.

Okay game start with an crash,
Restart the game again and alt tab and another crash, okay classic.
Changed over to windowed borderless, no crashes since then.
Turn off Ray Tracing and Dlss ( use the amd version instead) and u can avoid crashing.
If all set correct the game shud run smooth and flawless.

F1 life is something we really didnt need, supercars is little meh. 
But with traction off and a wheel, supercars acualy got little fun to drive. 

Career mode is nearly same as 2021, not much new or changed, just little.
Most of the interviews are gone.

Then we come to the f1 driving.
At start cars feels very slippery, This year changes to aero and other stuff made the cars somewhat harder to start drive with.
But when u learn it, amazing game.

Using fanatec GT DD pro 8nm with csl pedal (loadcell),
Amd 3900x, nvidia 3070

Fast verdict: if u have f1 2021 i cant really recommend to upgrade, 
but I still recommend it from my own experience, I enjoy 22 more than 21.

Edit: after near 3 weeks playing now, i acualy enjoy this even more.
Recommeded to play with traction off, only with an wheel and pedals.

Edit2: After playing this after an fair amount of hours, over 170h now when i write this edit, i stand for most i wrote above but, when it comes to the AI i cant anymore recommend this game. they had an fix for over aggresive AI in patch 1.10 i beleave, what happen?
Well for me it feels it got more aggresive instead, feels like the AI kinda ignore you on track. 
So im such a person, i always play solo or with 1-2 friends.
Still dont get me wrong, still love this game but cant recommend it anymore untill this been looked over.

Going to write my initial review since I've played it a bit. 24 hrs at review.

----------------------------
Update at the bottom
----------------------------

The UI is essentially a rip from F1 2021... but the car models are new (obviously), track updates are current, and the new handling is much improved.

They did add a lot of F1 Life crap that you expect now in most major EA games titles, where you can customize your living space and add supercars to your living space. Kind of a cool touch, but honestly, I would rather have the man hours spent in game development, it's really just another honeypot for people to pour money into.

The one thing I will critique - it would seem AI cars physics are much different than the players. Case in point, during a race, someone turned in front of me going into a corner, and I spun out. I then proceeded to test my theory and attempted to spin someone out by hitting one of their back wheels and again I spun somehow. They seem to be the immovable force no matter the situation. Anytime they squeak a wheel up the inside of a corner you're committed to, you spin and they will actually push you down the track as if you're not there.

Otherwise, this is a pretty good F1 game. If the new F1 regulations were not a part of the game, I'd say skip it, but the new cars and track layouts are worth the upgrade. I'm excited to see how VR grows as I think that could be a huge step in the franchise, especially with licensed brands wrapped into the deal.

UPDATE

After playing this game for a bit longer and joining leagues, I have to say that the bones of the game are still what I described above. However, the online functionality is very much broken.

I'll skip mentioning the lobbies and how poor everyone treats each other, and make note of a league I was in.

First, inviting in this game is just broken. You cannot invite from Steam Overlay, it has to be done in game, which would be fine, if it worked half the time. There were issues with invites going crossplay in our league, so we mostly disabled it. Not to mention the very regular server issues and people disconnecting.

Second, we had to recreate our league several times because we could not make changes to the settings of the league after creation. It might not matter for those more experienced with leagues, but we ended up just doing custom matches for the length of our season because it was easier.

Third it would be cool if people could rejoin games they DC from. A DC is obviously not the fault of the player, but they get punished and depending on if the league wants to restart the session, everyone gets punished.

I am actually finding this game enjoyable, feels very immersive. Only problems with the game at this current stage is:

-No updated driver models (same ones used for a couple years now)
-Cannot choose the shape of your My Team car, I feel like this is a missed opportunity
-Many bugs within the game at launch such as my audio cutting in and out (literally doesnt happen with anything else literally just F1 22 audio)
-Graphics are not that different but raytracing actually looks good this year
-Colours and textures are very off on certain cars such as the Redbull in particular, the silver on the Mercedes looks more grey than silver. 
-Supercars are very pointless in this game
-AI is broken at the time of this review, they go for unrealistic divebombs and they have invisible drs and infinite ers meaning they gap you on straights by a second even whilst I would have my drs and ers on
-Bought Champions edition of the game meaning I should've got the game 3 days early when in fact the game was released about halfway through the first day on steam even though it was supposed to be released at 7am BST.
-You can buy clothes and furniture for PitCoins which is absolutely ridiculous, seems to be a very common trend with EA games unfortunately
-I am very confused why there isnt a main menu fps limiter as it makes my gpu go crazy when its not even doing anything.


Overall, it is a good enough improvement and I am genuinely enjoying it. However, the devs (probably just EA) need to stop using the exact same assets from the previous games, it just comes across as very lazy. And no, I will not be spending my irl money on some digital furniture XD

At this current time I will not recommend until these bugs are addressed.

   push you off the road or make you spin, and overall, just a lot worse than last year.
- In my personal opinion the graphics in general are worse than last year, at least when you're watching as a spectator. The 
   if you watch the road on a long straight, it doesn't load correctly, and it looks like the cars are just floating around.
- They should be able to make the in-game characters look more realistic. We are in 2022, and some games have 
   cinematic clips where it is almost getting hard to differentiate between the game and a real person. But the drivers look 
   like characters in GTA V, a 10-year-old game. We should be able to get something better.

Good:
- I like the new menu and the background. I don't see why they added the supercars, especially when they seem to have a 
   lot else to improve, but the office thing is a nice feature to look at.
- Damage is visually much better, and maybe also more realistically when it comes to how you get it. Now I get floor 
   damage when I drive over high curbs, which I don't think I got before. That's good.

At his point, my friend and I decided to go back to f1 21, hoping that this game will get fixed one day. And it's sad to see how this game has become much worse (and more expensive) after EA got into the picture. So in a conclusion, wait a bit before you buy, or at least don't buy it for the full price.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Sad to see how Codemasters and EA ruin the only fully licenced F1 racing game.
Release was a desaster. It took them weeks to make it semi playable. AI was and is completely broken in MyTeam mode, VR (main reason I bought this game) is utter trash. RTX 3080, I still get massive stuttering and only 70 fps with my G2 while 80% downscaling on lowest settings.
You can get it running by using some mods from racedepartment, but by the next update its unplayable again.

FFB is okay, highspeed sections feel very dull, low speed feels great. (Fanatec DD)

Multiplayer was so awful I havent tried it since patch 1.07 (lobby not even starting, cant exit loading screen because someone had a dc,...)

Supercars are okay, but the historic cars were way more fun. Its a fun gimmick inbetween MyTeam but they get boring pretty fast and the FFB feels terrible. 

BUT if you like spending real money on a fancy couch, lamp or some clothes for your ingame character, this game is great.

For 10-15€ you can give this game a go. (atm) Anything more feels like burning money.
If you want to have fun driving F1 cars, get AMS 2 or Assetto Corsa. Maybe even get F1 2021 or 2020 (No VR)
If you want the most realistic F1 experience, get IRacing and the W12.

Honestly, this game is a huge dissapointment. Bad to the point that it forced me to write my first ever review. I played F1 2020 before, skipped 21 and waited specifically for this one. Gutted as certain driver would say. So the hugely game affecting bugs that are still here (1.10 patch as we speak) after 4months of release:

- AI still has unmatched traction out of certain corners in my team career; most noticable in Miami, Monaco, Baku, Bahrain, Monza, Brazil and to lesser extent on other tracks. Lowering the difficulty just makes the game unrealistic (I can gain 1second in 2nd Miami sector just to lose it in 3rd sector)
-related to above, the need to constantly shift difficulty level
-I have not had A SINGLE wet weather session in my teams career (4th season atm, % always say 1-4% rain chance, never more)
-minutes ago I finished 1-2 with my teammate (my team career again) and after crossing the finish line game registered him as DNF'd for absolutely no reason (on replay car appeared to just keep going as if the race never ended)

Not to mention the absolute joke that F1 Life is. Failed attempt at getting some more cash out of players. Failed because nobody cares about that mode. Rather get some F1 scenarios like in previous games than another sofa skin.

Overally, I am very dissapointed in this game and surely not going to buy the next year's edition. Gave this one some time as I believed the bugs will be fixed. Sadly, it does not seem like they will be. Didn't even see the weather problem adressed anywhere, AI traction was claimed to be fixed while it's clearly still a problem. Tough luck.
